Home  Research Training  College Students or Recent College Graduates  Summer Internship Program (SIP)
Research Training
Summer Internship Program (SIP)
This program is available to:
College Students or Recent College Graduates
Research Training
An opportunity for students in college, graduate, and professional school to perform a summer research internship in the Intramural Research Program at the NIH.

On this page

About this program
Eligibility criteria
Stipend and other compensation
Before you apply
How to apply
Selection process
Contact NIH Principal Investigators
About this program
This program is for college, graduate and professional students interested in exploring careers in research and healthcare. These are full-time research positions within one of the NIH Institutes and Centers (IC) in the NIH Intramural Research Program (IRP). Research groups are located on all NIH campuses, including the main campus in Bethesda, MD.
Summer interns work in a research group directed by a Principal Investigator (PI). We offer research opportunities in the biomedical, behavioral, and social sciences with opportunities to explore basic, translational, and clinical research. Students interested in biology, engineering, epidemiology, psychology, mathematics, chemistry, pharmaceutical sciences, nursing, physics, computer science, bioinformatics, and other health-related fields are invited to apply. Summer interns may not work in administrative offices or outside of the NIH IRP.
In addition to an intensive research experience, our summer interns have access to:
professional development programs focused on core competencies needed for success in healthcare, research, and other science careers.
educational and career programming.
a comprehensive well-being and resilience program.
We also sponsor a Graduate and Professional School Fair in July and Summer Poster Day in early August, where our interns share their research with the NIH community.
Eligibility criteria
To apply for the NIH SIP, and SIP subprograms, you must be a U.S. citizen or permanent resident. In addition, you must be one of the following:
18 years old by September 30, 2026. If you are a graduating high school senior who will be 17 years old as of June 1, 2026 but will turn 18 by September 30, 2026, your permanent home address must be located within 40 miles of an NIH campus.
AND, one of the following:
enrolled at least half-time as a senior in high school at the time of application and have graduated high school before the start of the internship.
enrolled at least half-time in an accredited community college, college, or university as an undergraduate, graduate, or professional school student at the time of application,
accepted into an accredited graduate program for the fall semester with the expectation of attending at least half-time. High school graduates that have completed a single gap year and are starting community college or college in the fall, are also eligible to apply.
Individuals who are U.S. permanent residents must be attending or have been accepted into educational institutions in the U.S.
Applicants with a family member working at NIH should be aware of the strict nepotism policy, which may limit your ability to work in certain NIH institutes, centers, or research groups.
Stipend and other compensation
Stipends for summer interns are adjusted annually and are based on educational level. There is free parking on each NIH campus; summer interns on some campuses may be eligible to participate in the Transhare program.
All summer interns must present proof of health insurance to participate in the program.
Before you apply
The decision to come to the NIH as a summer intern is an important one.  These are full-time research positions, and it is not possible to take summer classes or tend to other responsibilities during work hours.
Research groups are located on several different NIH campuses, including the main campus in Bethesda, MD. Before you begin your application, we encourage you to learn more about:
the Intramural Research Program and the mission of each NIH IC.
the various campuses and the specific focus of the work performed there.
If you decide the NIH SIP is right for you, pay careful attention to our extensive frequently asked questions (FAQs) to support you in the application process.
How to apply
Opening and closing dates

The application will open on December 8th, 2025 by 9 am ET and will close on February 18th, 2026 at noon ET. The reference letter deadline is February 25th, 2026 at noon ET.
Complete your application
You must use the NIH Application Center to apply for this program.
Complete your NIH Application Center profile. Any information submitted to the profile will be stored for use on future applications. (Your profile is NOT the application.)
Indicate that you are interested in applying to ‘Summer internships.’
Find the program you want to apply for in the ‘Open Programs’ list. Complete the Eligibility Screener.
If you are eligible, use the ‘Apply’ link to begin your application.
Import any relevant information from your profile. You must also submit:
Coursework - a list of all coursework and grades
CV/Resume - a list of your education, experience, and other relevant history
Personal Statement - a statement broadly describing your research experience, current research interests, and career goals as well as how the Summer Internship Program (SIP) would help you achieve your goals.
References – Enter the names and contact information of two references. Note that your references will receive a request to submit a letter of recommendation after you submit your application.
Review all of your materials carefully before you submit your application.
Start your application
Selection process
There is no centralized selection process; applications are reviewed by individual Principal Investigators (PIs) who select their own summer interns and provide the funding to support them. PIs begin interviewing candidates and offering positions in early January and the selection process is completed by April 1. Successful candidates will be informed by their PI and on-boarding paperwork will be done by the hiring IC.
Remember that the application and selection process for SIP and specific IC programs may differ, so read information specific to programs that interest you.
Contact NIH Principal Investigators
Please read our recommendations on finding mentors in the Intramural Research Program, which provide important information on how to find research groups and factors to be aware of as you interview and consider positions.
To be considered for a SIP position, you should reach out to NIH Principal Investigators (PIs) and direct them to your completed application.
Search databases and develop a list of PIs in the Intramural Research Program whose work interests you. Note that PIs may reach out to you to see if you are interested in working in their group.
Send personalized emails to PIs expressing interesting in their research group and highlighting why you are a strong candidate for their program.
Interview, virtually or in-person.
Watch the How to Find an NIH Research Mentor video on the OITE YouTube channel.
Have questions?
Check out our extensive FAQ list to support you in the application process.
Contact
Reach out to us at SIP@nih.gov.

enhanced_description: The NIH Summer Internship Program (SIP) provides full-time research opportunities within the Intramural Research Program for U.S. citizens or permanent residents who are enrolled in college, graduate, or professional school, as well as eligible high school seniors. Interns work under the direction of a Principal Investigator to conduct research in the biomedical, behavioral, and social sciences, spanning diverse fields such as biology, engineering, psychology, and bioinformatics. Participants receive a stipend based on their educational level and gain access to professional development, well-being programming, and events like the Graduate and Professional School Fair and Summer Poster Day. To be eligible, students must provide proof of health insurance and commit to the program full-time, as concurrent summer classes or other work responsibilities are not permitted. The application process involves submitting a CV, personal statement, coursework list, and two references through the NIH Application Center, after which candidates are encouraged to contact Principal Investigators directly to discuss potential placement.

title: Management & Technology Summer Institute
subtitle: University of Pennsylvania Wharton
raw_text:
M&TSI is an extremely rigorous, non-stop, fast-paced college course that introduces students to the fundamental knowledge and skills necessary for successfully linking technology and management concepts in just three weeks.
Highlights of M&TSI include:

Courses taught by full-time Wharton and Penn Engineering faculty
Attendees explore Penn’s business and engineering offerings, hearing guest lectures from prominent faculty recognized as leaders in their field
Students build and present a prototype and go-to-market plan for their own high-tech venture
Project presentations are evaluated by Penn faculty, receiving feedback from seasoned entrepreneurs and investors
Students participate in simulations led by industry innovators such as Google
Attendees receive a full Penn college-course credit for successful completion of program
enhanced_description: The Management & Technology Summer Institute (M&TSI) is a rigorous, fast-paced college course that introduces students to the fundamental skills necessary for linking technology and management concepts. Taught by full-time Wharton and Penn Engineering faculty, the program features guest lectures from industry leaders and interactive simulations led by innovators such as Google. Throughout the three-week experience, students build and present a prototype and a go-to-market plan for their own high-tech venture, receiving professional feedback from Penn faculty, seasoned entrepreneurs, and investors. Upon successful completion of the curriculum, attendees explore diverse business and engineering offerings while earning a full Penn college-course credit.

title: TASS Summer Seminar
subtitle: Telluride
raw_text: The Telluride Association Summer Seminar (TASS) is a free, six-week summer educational experience for high school sophomores and juniors. TASS prepares and inspires promising young students to lead and serve through transformative educational experiences rooted in critical thinking and democratic community. Telluride Association covers all program costs for every student, including tuition, books, room and board, field trips, and facilities fees.

title: Science Explorations Program
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: The Simons-NYU Science Explorations Program is a summer program that brings together students from diverse backgrounds with a passion for the physical and life sciences. This free program is for academically motivated students with a demonstrated interest in any/all of the following subjects: biology, chemistry, neural science, physics, and psychology. We strongly encourage applications from individuals who are under-represented in the sciences, across race, ethnic and national origin, physical ability, gender and sexual identity, or any other legally protected basis.

title: CAALS3D
subtitle: NCSU
raw_text: The CALS Office of Diversity and Inclusion aims to grow diversity within agricultural and biotechnology disciplines and careers. Countless studies confirm that conducting hands-on research is one of the best ways to increase student knowledge of STEM disciplines. CAALS 3-D (Creating Awareness of Agriculture and Life Sciences Disciplines, Degree Programs and Discoveries) is a program designed to provide participants with opportunities to gain such knowledge.

title: SSRP
subtitle: Hofstra
raw_text: Hofstra University's Summer Science Research Program offers high school students opportunities in science research under the guidance of professionals in science and mathematics. For more than 15 years, HUSSRP has provided selected research-oriented high school students the opportunity to work with our science faculty during the summer in an on-campus research program. The program runs from early July through mid-August culminating in a science "poster session" in early fall where students display the work they performed during the summer. The poster session is open to all students in the program, their families, and their teachers. Students are selected for this program based on their academic qualifications, a teacher's recommendation, and the availability of research mentors in their area of interest.

title: SEEing Art
subtitle: Emory
raw_text: Use art to connect with yourself and others with SEE (Social, Emotional, Ethical) Learning facilitator and teacher Jillian Minarich. Campers will explore art as a means of expressing emotion through color, create pottery that meets their practical personal needs, or those of others, identify and use patterns to experiment with mindfulness, and create textiles that honor their inner selves.

title: ENLACE Summer Research
subtitle: UCSD
raw_text: The ENLACE summer research program at UC San Diego aims to encourage the participation of high school and university students in research in the sciences and engineering, while promoting cross-border friendships between Latin America and the United States.

title: Summer Session
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: Georgetown University's summer programs offer a variety of academic and enrichment opportunities for high school students. Participants can take courses in different subjects, explore college life, and gain valuable skills and experiences. The programs typically include interactive classes, workshops, and activities designed to enhance learning and personal development. Students can engage in both on-campus and off-campus experiences. For more details on specific programs and application requirements, visit their website.

title: Discover Nursing and Its Vital Role in Healthcare
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: Nursing is a dynamic field that is greatly in demand. This online course invites you to explore the core skills critical to the profession while delving into the various types of nursing specialties including nurse-midwife, nurse anesthetist, and nurse practitioner. Identify the skills required for advanced degrees, and learn about innovations in nursing education such as using high-fidelity mannequins for medical simulations. Enjoy dynamic video lessons where you’ll witness care for a variety of patients.

title: USAJMO
subtitle: MAA
raw_text: The United States of America Junior Mathematical Olympiad (USAJMO) is a prestigious math competition for high school students who excel in mathematics. It is designed to test students' problem-solving skills with challenging math problems and to identify potential candidates for international math competitions. Participants are selected based on their performance in earlier qualifying rounds and engage in a rigorous exam that assesses their mathematical reasoning abilities. The USAJMO provides an opportunity for students to showcase their mathematical talents and earn recognition for their skills. It is a key step for students aiming to compete in higher-level math olympiads.

title: Parrhesia Ambassador Program
subtitle: UChicago
raw_text: The one-week Parrhesia Ambassador Program aims to introduce pre-college students, who are earlier in their academic journey, to the fundamental principles and practices that prepare students to communicate in a variety of contexts. Course assignments and exercises actively engage students in the rhetorical process of argument construction and presentation preparation and delivery. Selected participants will be tasked with serving as ambassadors and changemakers by sharing the principles of discourse and freedom of expression in their schools and communities.

title: Business Summer Institutes
subtitle: UHouston
raw_text: The annual summer enrichment program consists of two different weeklong residential camps focusing on preparing students to study and work in the areas of energy and sustainability as well as business solutions. The EXPLORE program allows students to fully immerse themselves in what college looks like, giving them an inside view of what to expect Students get a chance to participate in projects that focus on teamwork, implementing what they’ve learned throughout the week.

title: Pre-College Programs
subtitle: USC
raw_text: From business to life sciences, our goal is to make sure that high school students are given access to USC’s renowned education while providing an opportunity to explore their academic interests and passions. Upon completion, you’ll earn a certificate of completion, add to your college applications, make new friends and peers from around the world, and gain a better understanding of who you want to become during your college experience.

title: Student Leaders
subtitle: Bank of America
raw_text: Since 2004, Student Leaders® has been part of our ongoing commitment to youth employment and economic mobility. We’re helping prepare a diverse pipeline of community-minded young students to be successful in the workforce through leadership training and work experience. By driving responsible growth, we deliver for clients and address pressing societal issues, including advancing employment opportunities for youth and young adults. Through our Student Leaders® program, we annually connect more than 300 community-minded high school juniors and seniors from over 100 communities to employment, skills development and service. The students hail from many diverse backgrounds, but are united by their drive and commitment. Through paid internships with local nonprofits and participation in a national leadership summit, they gain practical work and life experience. Every year, hundreds of community-minded high schoolers are accepted into the Student Leaders program. They get first-hand experience in serving their communities through a paid eight-week internship with nonprofits like Boys and Girls Clubs of America and Habitat for Humanity. They also get to see how nonprofits, governments and businesses collaborate to meet local needs by participating in the national Student Leaders Summit in Washington, D.C. Many of the students use their new-found skills to create more change and improve more lives, with inspiring stories of enthusiasm and commitment.

title: Smash Academy
subtitle: SMASH
raw_text: SMASH Residential, our flagship program, is a FREE, 1-year, intensive CS-focused program that empowers students to deepen their talents and pursue CS careers. Scholars are immersed in tuition-free studies in partnership with leading universities throughout the country for one summer. During the program, scholars build relationships with facilitators and CS professionals that reflect their same demographics. Because of their common background, students connect more deeply with gain true mentorship from these CS professionals. As they go through the program, scholars not only develop their skills and network – they also further develop their voice & build the confidence to become who they want to be.

title: Research Experiences
subtitle: Northwestern
raw_text: REACH (Research Experiences in Astronomy at CIERA for High School Students) is a highly interactive program that provides high school students experience with astronomy research in an atmosphere of team-style learning, hands-on training, and mentorship from professional scientists. Sessions consist of a 3-week Core program followed by REACH Further, a limited-availability, 3-week extended research project with a mentor.

title: Verizon Innovative Learning STEM Achievers Program
subtitle: Shawnee State University Kricker Innovation Hub
raw_text: Every student deserves access to a better future. That’s why we’ve launched the Verizon Innovative Learning STEM Achievers program– an engaging, hands-on program developed to enrich learning through design thinking, 3D printing, augmented reality, social entrepreneurship and mentorship. This program creates a more diverse pipeline for future careers in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) fields; no prior knowledge or experience is required.
enhanced_description: The Verizon Innovative Learning STEM Achievers program is an engaging, hands-on initiative designed to provide students with access to a better future through enriched learning opportunities. Participants explore a variety of cutting-edge fields, including design thinking, 3D printing, augmented reality, social entrepreneurship, and mentorship. This program aims to build a more diverse pipeline for future careers in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) by welcoming all interested students regardless of their prior knowledge or experience.

title: Summer Humanities and Social Science Program
subtitle: Amherst
raw_text: The Summer Humanities & Social Sciences program(SHSS) is a five-week program for talented incoming first-year students with a passion for the humanities or social sciences who are from underrepresented minority groups and/or who are first-generation college students.

subtitle: Technovation Girls

About us
 

Technology is the fastest way to innovate solutions to humanity’s biggest challenges. But right now, young people in underserved communities are systematically denied access to tech and AI education because of geography, gender, and privilege. When those closest to the problem are excluded from solution-building, the world loses transformative solutions, untapped economic power, and brilliant talent that could reshape our future.

Investing in Innovation

Technovation empowers young innovators around the world to become leaders, technology innovators and real-world problem solvers.

Technovation has been pushing the boundaries of education and innovation for almost 20 years. From the beginning, our focus has been on staying agile and preparing students for the technologies shaping the future.

This track record of innovation has shaped who we are today: the world’s largest technology accelerator for young people and one of the largest global communities of alumnae, mentors, and ambassadors.

Our recipe? Analyze, execute, prepare for tomorrow.

Evidence-based evolution. We don’t guess what works. We rigorously analyze learning data, collaborate with diverse researchers, and recalibrate our curriculum based on what the evidence tells us.
Community-powered impact. Our network of local organizations, mentors, and ambassadors understand what their communities need. They help us stay relevant, bringing real-world insights that keep our approach grounded and responsive.
A lifetime of support. Our alumnae don’t just graduate—they return as mentors, advocates, and innovators themselves, creating a living feedback loop. They show us where the world is heading because they’re building it.
Our Impact

Users icon
300,000 students across 160+ countries

Users icon
Global network of over 80,000 mentors and volunteers

Users icon
21,000 startup ideas

Our Promise

Technovation doesn’t stop at sparking interest in STEM—we are committed to breaking down barriers and expanding access for all our participants and community members. We focus on:

Resources: Expanding access to material, human, and social support systems.
Agency: Building participants’ abilities, confidence, and voice at home, school, work, and in their communities.
Achievements: Driving meaningful improvements in well-being and life outcomes that come from increased agency and cognitive skills (Kabeer, 1999).
A Movement of Innovators

The impact of this model is best told through the journeys of our alumnae.

Take Aruzhan Koshkarova from Kazakhstan. As a teenager, she created QamCare, the country’s first personal security app, ensuring women could quickly alert trusted contacts in moments of danger. Winning the Technovation grand prize in 2017, she proved that local solutions could drive global change - and today, as a software engineer, she continues building tools that keep communities safe.

Our Story
Technovation began in 2006, when Tara Chklovski – then a PhD student in Aerospace Engineering at USC – saw a way to change the world. She believed education could break the link between where you’re born and what you can achieve, and that STEM offered a powerful pathway to unlock that potential. Driven by this conviction, Tara founded Iridescent (now Technovation). The name “Iridescent” reflected her vision: when you understand the science and engineering behind how the world works, fear gives way to curiosity, and everyday things reveal new layers of beauty. A flower, for example, becomes breathtaking not only for its colors, but for the physics that makes it bloom. The world, in turn, becomes brighter, more colorful – iridescent. Iridescent’s goal was to bring the most cutting-edge technologies and engineering marvels to underserved communities so that they would be inspired and equipped to become inventors and innovators.

Our first program, Family Science, began in 2006 at a single school in Los Angeles. From there, it spread across Southern California and eventually to San Francisco and New York. In 2010, we launched Technovation Girls. For almost 13 years we experimented intensely, running different types of programs with students of all ages, gender and from all communities across the world. For each program we collected and analyzed learning data to see which one was resulting in the deepest and most durable impact. One program quickly rose to the top – which was Technovation girls. Over the course of a rigorous three-month curriculum, students worked in teams – guided by a mentor – to identify a pressing problem in their community and design a technology solution to address it. They tested their ideas with real users, refined their prototypes, and built a robust business plan to bring their solutions to market.

Multi year longitudinal studies showed that the model was the most cost-efficient way of helping students develop durable identities as problem solvers. For just $250 – about $4 an hour – a girl received 100 hours of a world-class, cutting-edge technology and entrepreneurship curriculum, guided mentorship, and the chance to participate in a global program. Beyond those 12 weeks, she gained lifelong access to a vibrant alumna community of innovators and leaders, plus a prestigious certification of participation that helped unlock entry into top colleges.

Recognizing this, in August 2019 we committed fully to this model, changed our name to Technovation, and focused on scaling the program with the greatest proven impact. Today, Technovation is the only global program with longitudinal data proving the effectiveness of this approach. But the impact goes far beyond the numbers: students don’t just learn skills—they are transformed. They develop a lasting identity as problem-solvers, innovators, and leaders. Our alumnae are now running startups, pioneering new technologies, and driving progress as leaders across industries and communities worldwide. And what makes this transformation possible is not just the skills we teach, but the mindset we cultivate—the conviction that anyone, anywhere, can be an innovator.

Our Team, Community & Partners

Technovation is a global community of innovators and volunteers who come together to make the world brighter and better.

 

Join Us

Whether you’re a student eager to explore technology, a mentor ready to inspire, or a supporter who believes in the power of education, there’s a place for you at Technovation.

Join us today and be part of the movement to inspire the next generation of innovators.

The Technovation Girls Competition takes place at the end of the Technovation Girls season.

Teams work on their projects throughout the Technovation Girls season and, if they are eligible to compete and choose to do so, submit them to a global competition for the opportunity to win awards and educational scholarships.

Submissions are then judged in Quarterfinal, Semifinal, and Final rounds, with top-scoring teams advancing to subsequent rounds. Quarterfinals may be judged at in-person Regional Pitch Events or online. Semifinals are judged entirely online.

The Final round of the competition is held at World Summit, where Finalist teams (5 from each division), pitch their projects to a panel of judges.

While the Technovation Girls competition is not open to boys or participants above the age of 18, the curriculum is free and available to use by learners of all ages and genders.

All teams who submit to the competition are required to agree to the Honor Code when they submit. This agreement is made on the my.technovationchallenge.org platform, but the full text of the Honor Code can be found below for review.
enhanced_description: Technovation is a global technology accelerator and extracurricular program that empowers young people, particularly girls, to become leaders and problem-solvers through STEM and AI education. Participants work in teams over a rigorous three-month period to identify pressing community issues and develop corresponding technology solutions, which include building functional prototypes and comprehensive business plans. The program is supported by a global network of over 80,000 mentors and volunteers who guide students through the 100-hour curriculum, helping them refine their ideas for real-world application. Eligible teams can enter a multi-round global competition—consisting of quarterfinal, semifinal, and final stages—where they pitch their projects for the chance to win educational scholarships and awards. While the competition is specifically for girls under 18, the curriculum is free to all learners, and graduates gain lifelong access to a vast international alumnae community of innovators and industry leaders.

title: Design
subtitle: Carnegie Mellon University
raw_text:
Design has never been in greater demand than it is now. Businesses, government, and local communities are turning to designers for innovation and problem-solving, creating new roles for designers in every sector of the marketplace.
Pre-College Design introduces students to the discipline of design, provides a foundation of skills, and gives a clear idea of what to expect from a college-level accredited program. Pre-College Design students will have the opportunity to attend classes taught by full-time Carnegie Mellon faculty where they are given an introduction to the design principles and practices that are the cornerstones of the undergraduate School of Design program.
Modeled after the first-year college experience, sessions will consist of studio learning, lectures, and critiques, as well as guided work sessions with faculty. Students will be assigned their own personal studio space, providing them with their first foray into “studio life.” By the end of the program, participants will have portfolio pieces that have been critiqued by the School of Design faculty. There will also be a showcase that will feature all the work students have completed during the program, for fellow classmates, faculty, and parents to see.
enhanced_description: Pre-College Design introduces students to the fundamental principles and practices of the design discipline through a curriculum modeled after a first-year accredited college program. Participants engage in studio learning, lectures, and guided work sessions led by full-time faculty, allowing them to build a foundation of skills while experiencing the realities of "studio life" in their own assigned personal studio spaces. Throughout the program, students develop portfolio pieces that receive professional critiques, culminating in a final showcase where their completed work is presented to classmates, faculty, and parents.

title: Fellows Scholarship Competition
subtitle: Davidson Institute
raw_text: The Davidson Fellows Scholarship provides recognition and financial support to exceptionally gifted high school students who have made significant contributions in their fields. The scholarship awards are given based on outstanding achievements in areas such as science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and the arts. Davidson Fellows receive financial grants and opportunities for further education and development. The program aims to support and encourage young talents to continue pursuing their passions and make a positive impact in their fields. It provides resources and recognition for exceptional students.

title: National Science Bowl
subtitle: OSTI
raw_text: The National Science Foundation's Workforce Development for Teachers and Students (WDTS) provides educational programs and resources to enhance STEM education. WDTS focuses on improving science and engineering education through various initiatives, including student programs and teacher development. The programs aim to increase student engagement in STEM fields and support educators in delivering high-quality instruction. WDTS strives to prepare students for future careers in science and technology. The initiative fosters a strong foundation in STEM through educational resources and opportunities.

title: Stones & Bones Program
subtitle: UChicago
raw_text: Join the Field Museum for a four-week intensive practicum in paleontology in Chicago and Wyoming. Go into the field and behind the scenes at the Field Museum to learn how fossils are collected, analyzed, and conserved, as you work alongside museum scientists in the lab and in the field. Stones and Bones gives you a unique opportunity to participate in the paleontological study carried out by the museum.

title: Pediatrics Internship Program
subtitle: Stanford PIPS
raw_text: The Pediatrics Internship Program at Stanford (PIPS) is a 6-week program in which high school students from diverse backgrounds learn about science, medicine, and research with Stanford faculty, postdoctoral fellows, students, and researchers by completing a research project.

title: UCSF
subtitle: Lowell High Summer Program and Symposium
raw_text: The Lowell High Summer Program and Symposium offers high school students an opportunity to explore the field of medicine through hands-on activities and mentorship. Participants engage in interactive sessions with professionals and gain insights into medical careers while developing essential skills for future studies.

GWC CHALLENGES
TAKE THE AI + CYBERSECURITY CHALLENGE
AI can now copy anyone's voice, face, or artwork in seconds, making it hard to tell what's real. But here's the twist: the same AI creating these threats can help protect you and your community. This year, we challenge you to explore how people can use AI to protect their identities and creativity online in our Cybersecurity + AI Challenge!

You have questions, we have answers! Check out the FAQs
WHAT ARE GWC CHALLENGES?
GWC Challenges are annual community competitions in which participants can build a project addressing a real-world problem and win prizes.
The deadline to submit is February 11, 2026 by 11:59 pm ET. Winners will be announced in April.
Anyone based in the US between the ages of 13-26 is eligible to participate. You don’t need to be a current program participant or alumni to win!
This year, participants have access to exclusive resources from IBM SkillsBuild!

enhanced_description: The GWC Challenges are annual community competitions open to US-based individuals between the ages of 13 and 26, including middle schoolers, high schoolers, and college-aged participants. This year’s AI + Cybersecurity Challenge tasks participants with building projects that explore how artificial intelligence can be utilized to protect digital identities and creativity online. To support project development, participants have access to exclusive resources from IBM SkillsBuild along with comprehensive guides tailored for students, educators, and families. Teams of up to four members can compete for prizes including gift cards ranging from $300 to $500, branded swag, and social media spotlights for winning projects across three age-based categories. Interested individuals can enter by reviewing the submission checklist and completing the official challenge form once their project is finalized.

title: PULSE
subtitle: PSU
raw_text: PULSE is a semester-long educational outreach program for high school students (grades 9-12) who are passionate about healthcare and biomedical sciences. It was established in 2008 and is run by a Penn State College of Medicine medical student interest group by the same name. The PULSE program aims to cultivate interest in medicine, biomedical science and health care systems science by introducing passionate learners to medical students, biomedical researchers and practicing clinicians. Medical students and participants in the 2021 cohort helped reconceptualize the meaning of the name PULSE to reflect the importance of, and commitment to increasing diversity in medicine; PULSE is now an acronym that stands for Pre-health program for Underrepresented Leaders in STEM Education, reflecting the institutional goal of reaching students who come from historically marginalized backgrounds.

title: NC Youth Institute
subtitle: NCSU
raw_text: All high school youth are invited to join us for the 2024 North Carolina Youth Institute, an exceptional opportunity that ignites a passion for solving global hunger through an engaging exploration of agriculture and food systems. The North Carolina Youth Institute is an educational initiative of the World Food Prize Foundation and is designed to spark emerging leaders in developing innovative solutions for our world’s most pressing grand challenges surrounding feeding a growing population. Dr. Norman Borlaug, the world’s greatest scientist and humanitarian hero developed a hybrid of wheat that critically increased global food production levels and is credited for saving the lives of one billion people. For this accomplishment, he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize and subsequently founded the World Food Prize to honor those who dedicate their lives to building food resiliency across the world. Dr. Borlaug’s life is a remarkable example of what youth can accomplish through scientific and humanitarian efforts.

title: Upward Bound
subtitle: UNC
raw_text:
Serving 102 eligible high school Scholars in select schools in Durham, Chatham, and Lee Counties. The Upward Bound Program helps Scholars build the skills and motivation necessary to pursue and succeed in college and attain a Bachelor’s degree. Upward Bound is a part of the Office of the Provost at the University of Chapel Hill at North Carolina.

Upward Bound serves high school students from low-income families, and high school students from families in which neither parent holds a bachelor’s degree. The goal of Upward Bound is to increase the rate at which participants complete secondary education and enroll in and graduate from institutions of postsecondary education.
enhanced_description: The Upward Bound Program, an initiative managed by the Office of the Provost, serves 102 eligible high school scholars who are from low-income families or are first-generation college students. This program focuses on equipping participants with the essential skills and motivation necessary to successfully pursue higher education and attain a bachelor’s degree. By prioritizing college readiness, the program aims to increase the rates at which these students complete secondary education and ultimately enroll in and graduate from postsecondary institutions.

title: HIR Academic Writing Contest
subtitle: Harvard International Review (HIR)
raw_text:
Who We Are
The Harvard International Review is a quarterly magazine offering insight on international affairs from the perspectives of scholars, leaders, and policymakers. Since our founding in 1979, we've set out to bridge the worlds of academia and policy through outstanding writing and editorial selection.
The quality of our content is unparalleled. Each issue of the Harvard International Review includes exclusive interviews and editorials by leading international figures along with expert staff analysis of critical international issues. We have featured commentary by 43 Presidents and Prime Ministers, 4 Secretaries-General, 4 Nobel Economics Prize laureates, and 7 Nobel Peace Prize laureates.
The Contest
Inspired by our growing high school readership around the world, we have run the Harvard International Review Academic Writing Contest since 2020 to encourage and highlight outstanding high school writing on topics related to international affairs.
Contest Format
Participants in the contest submit a short-form article on a topic in international affairs. Each submission will be read and scored by the Harvard International Review.
A number of contestants will be selected as finalists, who are invited to participate in a virtual HIR Defense Day. At the Defense Day, students will have the opportunity to give a 15-minute presentation and oral defense to Harvard International Review judges.
Submission Guidelines
All submissions must adhere to the following requirements, as outlined in the Submission Guide below.
Participants will have a choice of three different themes and must note which prompt they have chosen at the top of their submissions.
Theme A: Global Commons and Stewardship of Shared Resources
Theme B: Emerging Powers in a Changing Global Order
Theme C: Resilient Cities and Urban Futures
Contestants may choose either topic above when writing the article.
Content: Articles should address a topic related to international affairs today. Potential categories include (but are not limited to): Agriculture, Business, Cybersecurity, Defense, Education, Employment & Immigration, Energy & Environment, Finance & Economy, Public Health, Science & Technology, Space, Trade, and Transportation. Articles should examine the theme from a global perspective rather than focusing on the United States.
Length: Articles should be at least 800 words but not exceed 1,200 words (not counting diagrams, tables of data, or authorship declaration).
Writing Style: Submissions should present an analytically backed perspective on an under-appreciated global topic.  
AI Policy: The usage of ChatGPT and other AI tools is strictly prohibited. Judges will be running all articles through multiple AI checkers, and articles that receive high AI generation scores across multiple checkers will be disqualified.
Excellent contest submissions will aim to present a topic holistically from a balanced perspective. Evidence and nuance are critical. Submissions should be well-researched, well-informed, and formal in style and prose.
The HIR does not accept op-eds, otherwise known as editorials or opinion pieces for its competition. Articles are expected to have a thesis but should not have an agenda. Submissions should also not be merely a collection of facts.
enhanced_description: The Harvard International Review Academic Writing Contest invites high school students to submit short-form articles on critical topics in international affairs to be evaluated by a quarterly magazine founded in 1979. Participants must produce a well-researched, formal article between 800 and 1,200 words that addresses one of three specific themes: Global Commons and Stewardship of Shared Resources, Emerging Powers in a Changing Global Order, or Resilient Cities and Urban Futures. Submissions should examine global issues—such as cybersecurity, public health, or trade—from a balanced, non-US-centric perspective, focusing on evidence and nuance rather than opinion-based editorials. After an initial scoring phase, selected finalists are invited to a virtual Defense Day to deliver a 15-minute presentation and oral defense before a panel of judges. To ensure academic integrity, the contest strictly prohibits the use of AI tools like ChatGPT, and all entries are subject to rigorous verification through multiple AI detection systems.

title: Business Research
subtitle: UCSD
raw_text: The following course is designed to prepare students for careers and advanced education in business innovation, entrepreneurship, and management with a solid grounding in fundamentals. While learning about topics of business innovation, design, venture financing, and growth strategy, students will gain the knowledge necessary to build an innovative business proposal and gain economic acumen.

title: Summer Art Camps
subtitle: UMD
raw_text: Looking for a fun, immersive and interactive summer arts experience for your kids that won’t break the bank? Studio A at the University of Maryland offers 4 one-week Summer Art Camp sessions, open to children ages 6-12. The Studio A Summer Art Camp runs from 9am-4pm, with After Care available from 4:30-5:30pm. Each week, campers participate in three art specialties with trained arts professionals, from drawing and painting to sculpture and media, to music and dance. Specialties change each week, so campers may register for more than one session to explore more mediums. Every week culminates in a showcase for campers’ artistic achievements. Please note: this camp will be primarily be indoors with small outdoor activities such as lunch or crafts.

title: EAOP
subtitle: Pre-College Academy
raw_text: The Pre-College Academy at UC Berkeley offers high school students a chance to explore academic interests develop skills and gain exposure to college life. Participants engage in interactive workshops and activities designed to enhance their educational journey and prepare them for future academic success.

title: Sports Business Academy
subtitle: UCLA
raw_text: During your class time, you'll be taught by experienced university instructors who know that lectures are old school. Through hands-on experiences, you'll develop 21st century skills like teamwork and communication and won't be watching time tick by. Outside of class, our highly trained staff will help you to explore new cities, lead you on excursions, and plan activities to maximize that summer fun. With a 35+ year history at UCLA, Summer Discovery ensures you have the summer of a lifetime.

title: International Physics Olympiad
subtitle: IphO
raw_text: The International Physics Olympiad (IPhO) is a prestigious competition that tests high school students' knowledge and problem-solving skills in physics. Participants solve complex problems and perform experiments to demonstrate their understanding of physical principles. The IPhO aims to foster interest in physics and identify top students for future academic and research opportunities. It provides a platform for students to showcase their talents and gain international recognition. Success in the IPhO can lead to further educational and career prospects in physics.

title: Genomics Research
subtitle: Stanford GRIPS
raw_text: The Genomics Research Internship Program at Stanford (GRIPS) brings summer internship opportunities in  computational  genetics and genomics to Bay Area high school students. GRIPS offers highly talented high school students a unique research experience, professional development, and community building opportunities. GRIPS is a twenty hour, eight week long research intensive experience for high school students. Program participants will be placed in a research laboratory for the summer and conduct genomics research under the supervision of a lab mentor.

title: Computational Biology Research
subtitle: UMich
raw_text: This camp is for students interested in math, science, medicine, and computation. The camp will focus on the role of genome and transcriptome in diseases and symptoms and guide students in performing computational biology research using patient RNA expression data to identify RNA biomarkers related to certain diseases. If you have not taken first-year high school biology, we expect you to study the basic transcription and translation process using materials that we provide before the camp.

title: UCSF
subtitle: Fresno Summer Biomedical Internship Program
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to gain hands-on experience in biomedical research. Participants will work alongside researchers and learn about various aspects of the scientific process. The program aims to inspire students to pursue careers in science and healthcare fields.

title: Computer Science Summer Academics
subtitle: UTAUS
raw_text: Immerse yourself in the world of coding and problem-solving by applying for the Scholars Academies, where the spirit of inquiry and a passion for computer science converge. Dedicated to making computer science education accessible to a broad and varied audience, these free residential academies for high school students offer a taste of collegiate life. Join us to learn the ropes of programming or enhance your existing skills right here on UT campus.

title: Kent State University
subtitle: Emerging Engineer Camp
raw_text: The Emerging Engineer Camp at Kent State University provides high school students with hands-on engineering experiences. Participants engage in design challenges and learn about various engineering fields. This immersive program fosters creativity and problem-solving skills essential for future engineers.

title: Cornell University
subtitle: Cornell Summer Scholars
raw_text: The Cornell Summer Scholars program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in hands-on research experiences in agriculture and life sciences. Participants work closely with faculty and graduate students while developing their research skills and gaining insights into potential career paths in these fields.

title: NASEP
subtitle: Keys Research Internship Program
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in hands-on research experiences in various STEM fields. Participants will work closely with mentors and gain valuable skills while exploring scientific inquiry and problem-solving in a supportive environment.

title: UWM
subtitle: Quest Project
raw_text: The Quest Project is designed for middle school students to explore academic and career possibilities through engaging activities and mentorship. Participants will develop skills in various subjects while fostering a sense of community and support. The program aims to inspire students to pursue higher education and personal growth.

title: University of Wisconsin-Madison
subtitle: Engineering Summer Program
raw_text: This program offers high school students the chance to explore engineering through hands-on projects and activities. Participants will engage in team-based challenges while learning about various engineering disciplines. The program aims to inspire future engineers and provide insight into college life.

title: National Academic League
subtitle: NAL
raw_text: The National Academic League (NAL) is an academic competition for high school students that tests their knowledge across various subjects. The league promotes intellectual development and teamwork through competitive quiz-style matches. Teams from participating schools compete in multiple rounds, answering questions related to science, history, literature, and more. NAL aims to foster academic excellence and encourage students to excel in their studies. The competition provides a platform for students to demonstrate their academic skills and collaborate with peers.

title: Young Innovators Program
subtitle: UChicago
raw_text: The Young Innovators Program empowers high achieving students for academic and career success in STEM innovation. In partnership with Invenergy, an industry leader in renewable and clean energy generation, and the Polsky Foundation, students have access to experiential learning opportunities, mentorship from industry leaders, and a network of entrepreneurial peers.

title: UBMS Summer Program
subtitle: Binghamton
raw_text: The UBMS Summer Program is a free six-week initiative aimed at preparing 30 students for college. It provides participants with a taste of college life at Binghamton University, including hands-on courses, outdoor activities, and field trips. Students will stay on campus and engage in both local and overnight excursions. The program also includes a 2 or 3-day end-of-summer trip featuring a college tour. Current participants should check Remind or mailings for more details.

title: Summer Scholars Program
subtitle: Broad Institute
raw_text: The Broad Summer Scholars Program (BSSP) invites highly motivated high school students with a strong interest in science to spend six weeks at the Broad Institute. We match students with Broad scientists to conduct original, cutting-edge research projects in areas such as: cancer biology, psychiatric disease, chemical biology, computational biology, infectious disease, and more. In addition to original research, students will get to explore scientific careers; attend interesting scientific talks; present their research to the Broad community in a scientific poster session; attend a college fair; participate in fun social events; and meet other students who share similar interests.

title: University of Vermont
subtitle: UVM Summer Enrichment Scholars Program
raw_text: The UVM Summer Enrichment Scholars Program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in hands-on learning experiences in STEM fields. Participants will explore various scientific topics and gain valuable skills through interactive workshops and mentorship from faculty. This program aims to inspire future leaders in science and technology.

title: Washington & the World Academy
subtitle: Georgetown University HOYA Summer High School Sessions
raw_text:
With the creation of a new world order after World War II, the United States came to be the indisputable leader of the so-called Free World. However, over the past several years, new forces in global and domestic politics have called into question the role of America in a changing world. This has especially been the case since COVID-19 pandemic. What will be the future of American leadership? What will happen to the Atlantic Alliance? Will other great powers—like Russia and China—fill the possible void? What will be the future of American ideals, such as democracy and freedom?

As a student in the Washington & the World Academy, you'll spend your day immersed in a blend of classroom lectures, activities, and group discussions. Throughout the week, you'll have the opportunity to explore subject areas such as these:

The evolution of Washington’s engagement with the world
The American Constitution and the world
Congress, the president, and foreign policy
The role of the press and foreign policy
The future of the Atlantic Alliance
The U.S. and the developing world
The U.S. and the great powers
The U.S. and Asia
The U.S. and terrorism
American music and politics
The current U.S. Administration and foreign policy
The future of American foreign policy
enhanced_description: The Washington & the World Academy is an immersive program for students that explores the evolving role of the United States as a global leader in the post-World War II era. Participants spend their time engaged in a blend of classroom lectures, interactive activities, and group discussions throughout the week to analyze how domestic and global forces shape international relations. The curriculum covers a wide range of critical subjects, including the constitutional framework of foreign policy, the influence of the press, and the nation's relationships with the developing world, Asia, and other great powers. Students also examine contemporary challenges such as terrorism, the future of the Atlantic Alliance, and the impact of the current administration on American ideals like democracy and freedom.

title: CReSIS
subtitle: CReSIS Summer Camps
raw_text: The CReSIS Summer Camps provide high school students with hands-on experience in science and engineering related to ice and climate research. Participants engage in interactive activities and gain insights into the research process while working with scientists and educators in a collaborative environment.

title: Anson L. Clark Scholars Program
subtitle: Texas Tech
raw_text: The Anson L. Clark Scholar Program is an intensive seven-week summer research program for twelve highly qualified high school juniors and seniors. The Program at Texas Tech University helps the Scholars to have a hands-on practical research experience with outstanding and experienced faculty. The list of research disciplines available for Summer 2024 will be posted in the next few weeks.

title: Pre-College Connect
subtitle: UChicago
raw_text: This summer, connect with UChicago both online and in-person! In Precollege Connect, students explore subjects like biology, psychology, and art through three-week intensive courses that start online, with real-time interaction with your UChicago instructor and fellow students, and culminate in a one-week capstone on-campus experience. Make the most of UChicago’s online and in-person resources by combining virtual activities with in-person labs, museum trips, and more!

title: Tri-Valley Clinical Academy
subtitle: Stanford SHVCA
raw_text: The Stanford Healthcare Tri-Valley Clinical Academy is a program designed for the Tri-Valley community. A two-week program aimed for high school juniors and seniors with a strong interest in medicine as a career. Students will participate in an enriched curriculum consisting  of various medicine topics (ex, cardiology, nephrology etc.), basic skills such as taking vitals, and obtaining a history and physical, splinting, and suturing just to name a few.  The students will also have an opportunity to hear from current Physician Assistant and Medicine students to gain an insight of their experiences as well as network with different medical professionals.

title: Learn How Entrepreneurs Identify and Solve Problems
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: It is said that entrepreneurs can see a need before people even have it on their radar. Entrepreneurship is also the story of success and failure. In this course, you will learn what goes into launching a business. You will identify your target customers, create a story for your product, write a business pitch, and practice leadership behaviors that can inspire a team, prove out ideas, and test your brand concept. If you want to know how to take an idea all the way through to an on-the-shelf product or service, this course is for you.

title: Yale University
subtitle: Pathways to Science Summer Scholars
raw_text: The Pathways to Science Summer Scholars program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in hands-on scientific research with Yale faculty and graduate students. Participants will gain valuable experience in a research setting while exploring various scientific fields and enhancing their academic skills.

title: UTA
subtitle: Gateway to Engineering and Bridge to Engineering Summer Programs
raw_text: The Gateway to Engineering and Bridge to Engineering Summer Programs at UTA offer high school students hands-on experiences in engineering fields. Participants engage in activities that enhance their understanding of engineering concepts and develop skills through collaborative projects and mentorship from faculty and industry professionals.

title: Summer Prep
subtitle: UPENN
raw_text: The Penn Summer Prep Program allows ambitious students to enroll in two undergraduate-level modules from across disciplines while benefiting from the rich educational resources of the University. Students can also experience college life on Penn’s historic campus and explore the vibrant city of Philadelphia. Penn Summer Prep instructors are a combination of University of Pennsylvania graduate students, faculty, and staff.

title: Patricia Grodd Poetry Prize
subtitle: Kenyon Review
raw_text: The Kenyon Review Patricia Grodd Short Fiction Contest invites high school students to submit short stories for a chance to win recognition and publication. The contest aims to encourage young writers and provide a platform for showcasing their creative work. Participants are evaluated based on originality, writing style, and narrative quality. The competition offers opportunities for students to gain exposure and experience in literary arts. Winners receive prizes and the chance to be published in a prestigious literary journal.

title: Yale
subtitle: Oxford Royale Academy
raw_text: Oxford Royale Academy offers a summer course at Yale University where students can explore various subjects enhance their skills and meet peers from around the world. Participants will engage in interactive lessons and activities designed to foster creativity and critical thinking in a prestigious academic environment.

title: Screenwriters Workshop
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: Develop your skills writing for film and television through this dynamic online course at the NYU Tisch School of the Arts. The Online High School Screenwriters Workshop will introduce students to the fundamentals of scriptwriting for the screen.

title: HPREP
subtitle: Harvard
raw_text: The Health Professions Recruitment & Exposure Program (HPREP) at Harvard Medical School is a high school science enrichment program aimed at recruiting high school students from the Boston area, particularly those from underserved and underrepresented backgrounds, into science and medicine.

title: Kentucky Forest Leadership Program
subtitle: UK
raw_text: KFLP is offering an Entomology option in addition to the Forestry and Wildlife options. This option is for the student that has a serious interest in learning more about Kentucky’s insects and their impacts on the states’ forests. Students enrolled in the Entomology option will not only learn about insects but will also complete a survey of the insects in the same 80-acre forest plot that is being investigated by the Forestry and Wildlife students. At key points during the week, the Entomology, Forestry, and Wildlife students will share their findings and work together to solve real-life forest management problems while creating a forest management plan.  Students are busy from dawn ‘til dusk (and beyond) during the program. The major project for the week is an investigation of impacts that insects have on the forest that surrounds the Leadership Center. The full schedule of activities for the week will also include:

title: Changemakers Pre-College
subtitle: UCB
raw_text: The Berkeley Changemaker® Summer 2024 Pre-College Program offers international and domestic high school students the opportunity to live on campus and enjoy the summer at Berkeley. Since its inception, UC Berkeley has always attracted changemakers whose vision challenges the status quo and whose contributions make our world a better, more equitable place. The Berkeley Changemaker pre-college program draws from, and builds on, elements that make UC Berkeley unique, including a singular history for leading inclusively and an agency for making society better. Our curriculum activates our students’ passions and helps them to develop a sharper sense of who they want to be and how to make that happen. Regardless of what interests you, there is a place for you here in our learning community.

title: Apprenticeships in Science & Engineering
subtitle: ASE
raw_text:
The 2026 ASE Application will open January 12, 2026.

The Apprenticeships in STEAM Exploration (ASE) program connects motivated high school students with mentors in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) pre-professional internships. The driving value behind the ASE program is that the interns should contribute to and learn from the mentor's work.

Internships are eight-week, full-time or part-time summer positions, designed by mentors themselves. These internships take place throughout Oregon and Southwest Washington, including Portland, Eugene, Corvallis, and Vancouver. Mentor organizations include universities, hospitals, research institutions and private companies. The application process is competitive, with more than 400 applicants each year for approximately 100 positions. ASE internships attract rising sophomores, juniors and seniors from throughout the Northwest, and roughly 70% of interns are from backgrounds historically excluded from the sciences. ASE interns have been listed on published research, helped to design and test commercial products and spent countless hours in the field and in the lab.

title: SDSU
subtitle: Summer Leadership Academy
raw_text: The Summer Leadership Academy at SDSU is designed for high school students to develop leadership skills through interactive workshops and activities. Participants will engage in team-building exercises and learn from experienced leaders in various fields. This program aims to empower students to become effective leaders in their communities.

title: Plant Signal Transduction and Reproduction
subtitle: UMass
raw_text: Our competitive Research Intensives program places high-achieving high school students in professional working labs alongside distinguished faculty, graduate and undergraduate students. Research Intensive in the Plant Signal Transduction and Reproduction (Cheung Lab) Our lab's primary interest is understanding how plants reproduce to make seeds. While this is an important problem, since plant reproduction feeds the world and maintains an ecological balance, the process involves fascinating biology. Unlike animal sperm, plant sperm cannot swim – how does it travel to find its mate, the egg, for fertilization? Our research depends on experimental approaches ranging from molecular biology, genetics, cell biology and biochemistry, not unlike research in other systems ranging from bacteria to animals, normal development or development into the diseased states. Also plants need to grow to reach maturity in order to reproduce. Plant growth is complex and depends on a large number of hormones and other regulators. We also study how plants perceive and respond to these regulators to orchestrate growth and development.

title: High School Research Program
subtitle: BNL
raw_text: e High School Research Program (HSRP) is a highly competitive six-week educational program for students interested in pursuing science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) studies.

title: Summer Journalism Program
subtitle: Princeton
raw_text: The Princeton Summer Journalism Program (PSJP), which is housed in the Emma Bloomberg Center for Access and Opportunity at Princeton University,(Link is external) (Link opens in new window) is the only program of its kind offering a free, year-long college preparation and journalism program for high school juniors from limited-income backgrounds. Our mission is to diversify the fields that impact our democracy through the exploration of the important connection between journalism and critical social and political events. Every May, we admit up to 40 students from across the country, who commit to completing a rigorous summer intensive during the summer after their junior year and working with a dedicated college adviser on their college application and selection process through the end of their senior year.

title: Mathematics Project
subtitle: Rice
raw_text: The Rice University School Mathematics Project's 2024 summer math camps and programs for students are currently closed. These camps include sessions for various math levels, such as Calculus, Algebra I, Geometry, Algebra II, and Precalculus, held on the Rice University campus, as well as camps for students in grades 1-8 at other locations.

title: American Legion Camp
subtitle: Boys State
raw_text:
The American
legion
the world's largest veterans organizationRENEWJOIN NOW
 
HOMEABOUTDEPARTMENTNEWS & EVENTSMEMBERSHIPPROGRAMS & SERVICESRESOURCESCONTACT
Boys’ State
A most rewarding experience

Boys State assembly
Boys State general assembly.

American Legion Boys’ State is a week-long program that immerses high school youth (currently completing their junior year) in citizenship and leadership training. They learn the practical aspects of government as it exists in New York State, and come to recognize that the individual is integral to the character and success of government. They also participate in physical fitness, team work and other activities under the guidance of American Legion counselors and U.S. Marines.

Boys’ State takes place at Morrisville State College usually the last week in June. In 2026 it runs from Saturday, June 27 to Thursday, July 2.

If you or a youth you know would like to apply, contact your local American Legion Post to inquire about sponsoring you to Boys State. Once a Post agrees to sponsor you, you will receive a notification to go ahead and submit the online application to this year’s Boys State program.

Check out this orientation video, which gives an overview of what to expect at Boys State.



Look over the information packet (below). Once the online application is completed, print out a copy and then hit the “submit” button.

Download the Commitment/Certification Statement (doc and PDF versions available).

Boys State graduation day
Passing in review on graduation day.

The Commitment statement must be signed by applicant and parent or guardian, and notarized. The Certification form has to be completed and certified by a school official.  You will need to deliver a copy of the completed application, the Commitment Form and Certification Form, with original signatures, to the sponsoring American Legion Post.

It is recommended you read the Boys’ State Handbook.

If applying for the SAMSUNG SCHOLARSHIP, the application may be filled out online at https://www.legion.org/samsung-scholarship-application

Complete the online Boys’ State application (see link below):

Do not complete application until you have been approved by your local American Legion Post.
All citizen information must be provided.
All parent information must be provided.
All sponsoring American Legion Post information must be provided.
Once the application is completely filled out, press Ctrl P to print a copy, then press the Submit button to send the application to The American Legion Department of New York.
After submitting application, if you find a mistake was made on the application, do not submit another application.  Make corrections on the printed application and the information will be updated when received at American Legion Headquarters.
 Online application (2026)
(Note: D.O.B. must include 4-digit year; e.g. 1998.)
