enhanced_description: American Legion Boys’ State is a week-long leadership and citizenship immersion program designed for high school students currently completing their junior year. Participants learn the practical aspects of New York State government through hands-on training while also engaging in physical fitness and teamwork exercises led by American Legion counselors and U.S. Marines. To begin the application process, students must first contact their local American Legion Post for sponsorship approval before submitting an online application. Required documentation includes a notarized commitment statement signed by a parent or guardian, a certification form from a school official, and a physical exam certificate, all of which must be delivered to the sponsoring Post. Additionally, participants have the opportunity to apply for the Samsung Scholarship and are encouraged to review the official program handbook and orientation video to prepare for the experience.

title: Discovery Program
subtitle: Microsoft
raw_text: During this 4-week internship, Discoverers will have the opportunity to experience the Design phase of the product development cycle, develop foundational skills while gaining mentorship from Microsoft employees and community building. You will discover how your passions can evolve into a career in tech at Microsoft and beyond. Microsoft’s High School Discovery Program is open to rising first-year students of a bachelor’s degree program (graduating high school seniors) that live around Redmond, Washington OR Atlanta, Georgia who have an interest in technology.

title: Pre-College
subtitle: PSU
raw_text: High school students are invited to step into their potential with hands-on programming in leadership, business, career development and more. Students will benefit from high-quality programs customized with the appropriate mix of educational and fun activities and taught by instructors who are experts in their fields.

title: DSAP Program
subtitle: UIUC
raw_text: The Discovering STEM in ACES Program (DSAP) is a one week (July 14-20, 2024) in campus program that exposes students to immersive experiences to showcase what the College of Agricultural, Consumer, and Environmental Sciences (ACES) has to offer. Each student will participate in a series of STEM-related learning activities designed to support their understanding of how food, agriculture, human, and environmental systems are connected to their career goals.

title: ASU
subtitle: Cybersecurity Internship Program
raw_text: The Cybersecurity Internship Program at ASU offers students hands-on experience in cybersecurity practices and technologies. Participants will work on real-world projects with industry professionals enhancing their skills and knowledge in a rapidly growing field.

title: International Relations Academy
subtitle: Georgetown University HOYA Summer High School Sessions
raw_text:
As one of the oldest universities in the world and long considered a hub for international dialogue, Georgetown is where international leaders often choose to state their positions and calls for action. During the one-week International Relations Academy, you'll have the opportunity to learn from world-renowned faculty, gain valuable experience, and explore today's global issues and challenges.

As a student in the International Relations Academy, you'll spend your day immersed in a blend of classes, off-sites, activities, and group discussions. Throughout the week, you'll have the opportunity to explore subject areas such as these:

The Structure of the International System
The Instruments of Foreign Policy
Intelligence and Foreign Policy
Ethics and International Affairs
International Law
Competing Philosophical Frameworks
Terrorism
Nuclear weapons
The Environment
Global Health
International Development
The Future of the International System
enhanced_description: The International Relations Academy provides students with an intensive one-week program focused on exploring contemporary global issues and challenges through the guidance of world-renowned faculty. Throughout the week, participants engage in a dynamic blend of academic classes, off-site visits, interactive activities, and collaborative group discussions to gain practical experience in the field. The comprehensive curriculum addresses a wide array of topics, including the structure of the international system, foreign policy instruments, intelligence, ethics, and international law. Furthermore, students delve into critical global concerns such as terrorism, nuclear weapons, environmental policy, global health, and international development, ultimately examining the future of the international system.

title: CCRI - Snow
subtitle: NASA
raw_text: SnowEx is a multi-year field experiment, which includes extensive surface-based observations to evaluate how to best combine different remote sensing technologies to accurately observe snow throughout the season in various landscapes. The team members will contribute to the development of the SnowEx meteorological data archive. This includes evaluating data collected during the 2017-2020 snow seasons for errors and assisting in formatting and analysis to prepare the data for archival. The candidates should have some experience with data analysis and scripting. Experience working in snow research is highly desired. The candidates will also help in preparing metadata, charts, and presentation material to introduce the data to the larger snow community.

title: Precollege Online Program - Entrepreneurship
subtitle: Dartmouth University
raw_text:
Ready to turn your ideas into a business? This online course guides you through the entrepreneurial journey, from identifying pressing real-world problems to developing compelling solutions. You'll learn essential skills like designing a minimum viable product and understanding customer needs, while gaining insights from industry experts. Cultivate an entrepreneurial mindset and discover how to create real-world value.

APPLY TO ENTREPRENEURSHIP
PROGRAM DATES

Multi-length sessions available throughout the year
ELIGIBILITY

For students ages 13 and up
INDIVIDUAL COURSE FEES

$1,895
Transform Ideas into Real-World Solutions

DISCOVER YOUR ENTREPRENEURIAL DRIVE

Explore what entrepreneurship means and its potential to drive meaningful change. Examine your own values and goals to see how they align with entrepreneurial paths. Identify personal skills of successful entrepreneurs.
PINPOINT PROBLEMS WORTH SOLVING

Learn to identify real-world problems through observation and research. Differentiate between surface-level symptoms and deeper root causes. Develop a focused problem statement using empathy-driven inquiry to understand genuine user needs. 
DESIGN AND TEST YOUR BIG IDEAS

Generate and test creative solutions for defined problems. Learn what makes a solution viable and how to test ideas quickly without building a full product. Draft and refine a minimum viable product concept.
CONNECT WITH CUSTOMERS AND THE MARKET

Discover how to conduct effective user conversations and interpret insights so you can validate assumptions and gather feedback. Begin strategically positioning your idea in the market, identifying what makes it unique.
CRAFT YOUR COMPELLING STORY

Learn to communicate your entrepreneurial vision through compelling storytelling and effective pitching. Craft a narrative highlighting your product, mission, and team. Explore what investors and stakeholders look for in early-stage ventures.
SHOWCASE YOUR VISION

Develop and pitch a business idea addressing a real-world problem of your choice. Create a business model sketch, audience analysis, and a pitch presentation.
Student taking Dartmouth's precollege online entrepreneurship course
How You Will Benefit

Understand the core principles and process of entrepreneurship and explore the personal skills of a successful entrepreneur.
Develop the ability to identify real-world problems and generate viable business ideas, culminating in designing and communicating a minimum viable product (MVP).
Explore foundational business strategies, including customer discovery, value proposition, and branding, to develop and pitch a complete venture concept.
Explore diverse career paths in entrepreneurship and gain insights directly from industry founders, tech innovators, and educators.
Complete a Final Capstone Project to demonstrate what you’ve learned.
Earn a Certificate of Completion from Dartmouth.
enhanced_description: Designed for students ages 13 and up, this entrepreneurship program focuses on transforming innovative ideas into real-world business solutions for a course fee of $1,895. Participants engage in a comprehensive curriculum that covers identifying pressing problems through research, designing a minimum viable product, and conducting customer discovery to validate market assumptions. The course also emphasizes essential professional skills such as storytelling, pitching to stakeholders, and creating business model sketches under the guidance of industry experts and educators. Upon successful completion of the final capstone project, students earn a Certificate of Completion from Dartmouth to showcase their ability to drive meaningful change through entrepreneurial action.

title: Scholastic Press Association Contests
subtitle: NSPA
raw_text: The National Scholastic Press Association (NSPA) awards recognize excellence in student journalism across various categories, including writing, design, and multimedia. The competition is open to high school and college journalists who submit their work for evaluation by industry professionals. Awards are given based on criteria such as creativity, accuracy, and overall impact. The NSPA aims to celebrate and promote high-quality student journalism. Winners receive accolades and recognition for their achievements in the field of journalism.

title: GenCyber Summer Camp
subtitle: UNLV
raw_text: The UNLV GenCyber is a week-long cybersecurity summer camp designed for high school students. The program aims to educate students about proper and secure online behavior, foster good digital citizenship, and encourage interest in cybersecurity careers. Students will engage in various hands-on activities covering diverse cybersecurity topics and listen to insightful stories shared by cybersecurity experts.

title: OUHSC
subtitle: Spark Summer Program
raw_text: The Spark Summer Program offers high school students an opportunity to explore careers in healthcare and medicine through hands-on experiences and mentorship. Participants engage in interactive activities and gain insights into various health professions while developing skills essential for future success in the medical field.

title: Cancer Epidemiology and Genetics Internship
subtitle: NIH
raw_text: The Division of Cancer Epidemiology and Genetics (DCEG) offers a summer research internship for students interested in exploring careers in cancer epidemiology, biostatistics, and genetics. The program is open to high school, college, postbaccalaureate masters-level students, and graduate students, including medical and dental students. Successful applicants join the Division for at least eight weeks between May and September and work under the supervision of a Division researcher. This program is part of the NIH Summer Internship Program (SIP) in Biomedical Research.

title: UWM
subtitle: ACS Project SEED
raw_text: The ACS Project SEED program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in hands-on research experiences in chemistry. Students work alongside professional chemists and gain valuable skills and knowledge that can inspire future academic and career pursuits in the sciences.

title: The World Order — and Where It’s Heading
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: The subject of international relations is more relevant than ever. We are living through a time of disruption and promise. On one hand, technology offers more people a voice—on the other, populist movements threaten democracy. The world economy is strongly connected, yet threats like pandemics shut down supply chains and cause shortages. Industry is more productive, but causes environmental ills. How do these problems and potentials interact? What will your role be in the future? If you are interested in international relations, politics, law, economics or just curious about how our world works, this course is a must. Choose from our enrichment and college credit options, and discover this exciting subject today.

title: Learn How Investors Create Wealth
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: How do investors create wealth? What are the impacts of fintech and cryptocurrencies? What really happens to a stock once you buy it? This fascinating course navigates the complex world of finance by breaking down the basic mechanics of financial markets. You’ll learn how valuation models are used to determine a company’s value and how its value affects the price of its stock. You’ll apply what you learn to create an investment portfolio that meets your investment goals. If you see a future investing for individuals or for companies, this course is for you.

title: Global Youth Entrepreneurship Challenge

Participants work on creating and pitching entrepreneurial projects that address global challenges and demonstrate innovation. The competition provides a platform for students to gain feedback from experienced entrepreneurs and industry experts. It aims to nurture young entrepreneurs by offering opportunities for networking, learning, and showcasing their ventures. GYEC fosters an entrepreneurial mindset and supports students in pursuing business-related careers.

title: Mentor Assistance Program for High School Students

Participants solve problems individually and in teams, testing their mathematical abilities. The tournament aims to promote mathematical excellence and teamwork among students. Winners receive recognition and awards for their performance. The event supports the development of advanced mathematical skills and collaboration.

title: Upward Bound Math Science

raw_text: The TRIO Upward Bound Math – Science Program of the University of Pennsylvania aims to strengthen the educational, scientific and cultural foundations of highly motivated high school students from low-income and/or first-generation-to-college backgrounds with the goal of enhancing their ability to matriculate into competitive STEM college and university majors.

title: Ohio University
subtitle: J.C. Baker College Experience Summer Program

Participants engage in hands-on activities and gain insights into various business disciplines while developing valuable skills for their future academic and career pursuits.

title: National Security & Intelligence Academy
subtitle: Georgetown University HOYA Summer High School Sessions
raw_text:
The National Security & Intelligence Academy brings together unparalleled government and international relations resources from the Georgetown network to explore security and intelligence issues. You'll gain a deeper understanding of how policies enhance the security of Americans in the post-9/11 world, study how the United States prevents foreign adversaries from gaining access to national security information, and examine how intelligence information is collected, analyzed, and disseminated.

As a student in the National Security & Intelligence Academy, you'll spend your day immersed in a blend of classroom lectures, field trips, hands-on activities, and group discussions. Throughout the week, you'll have the opportunity to explore the following subject areas:

Homeland security
International politics
Cybersecurity
Drug trafficking
Arms proliferation
Border protection
Careers in national security and intelligence
National security and artificial intelligence
enhanced_description: The National Security & Intelligence Academy utilizes the Georgetown network’s extensive government and international relations resources to offer students a deep dive into the complexities of security and intelligence. Participants explore how post-9/11 policies protect American interests, study the prevention of foreign adversary access to sensitive information, and examine the full lifecycle of intelligence collection and analysis. The program’s immersive format combines classroom lectures and group discussions with field trips and hands-on activities to provide a practical understanding of the field. Students investigate a wide range of critical topics, including homeland security, international politics, cybersecurity, drug trafficking, arms proliferation, and border protection. Additionally, the curriculum addresses the impact of artificial intelligence on national security and highlights various career opportunities within the intelligence community.

title: Sibling Circles

raw_text: Sibling Circles is a drop-in workshop series focused on mental health and well-being. Through educational healing spaces, participants process life events, engage in open discussion and creative expression, and build skills to navigate the world in ways that uphold the importance of safety and uplift the power of collective care.

title: Summer Institute
subtitle: WEB Du Bois
raw_text: The Dubois Scholars Program supports high-achieving high school students from underrepresented backgrounds. To be eligible, applicants must have strong academic records, including high grades and standardized test scores. They should also demonstrate leadership and active involvement in extracurricular activities. Financial need is a key criterion, and the program values applicants who are committed to community service. A personal statement is required to showcase the applicant's goals and motivation for applying.

title: Simmons Research
subtitle: Stony Brook
raw_text: Established in 1984 as an outreach program for local high school students, the Simons Summer Research program now attracts applicants from all across the country to the Stony Brook campus: Simons Fellows are matched with Stony Brook faculty mentors, join a research group or team, and assume responsibility for a project. The Simons Fellows conclude their apprenticeship by producing a written research abstract and a research poster.

title: Summer Session

raw_text: The University of Virginia's Summer Session offers a wide range of courses and special programs, including the Summer Language Institute, UVA Advance for high school students, and the Morven Summer Institute. The summer term has multiple sessions running from May to August, with specific dates and holidays observed. Registration opens in late March for various student categories. The program aims to provide academic advancement and unique educational experiences.

title: International Young Researchers' Conference (IYRC)
subtitle: IYRC, Stanford University
raw_text:
rom November 22, 2025 to January 10, 2026, we invite you to join the IYRC STEM Winter Program, designed to provide you with a profound grasp of fundamental scientific concepts while keeping you up-to-date with the latest technological advancements.
​
Learn more about captivating subjects spanning Biology, Chemistry, Environmental Science, Computer Science, and Aerospace led by distinguished researchers and students from Stanford University, where you'll gain unique insights into the transformative impact of science and technology on our rapidly evolving world.
​
APPLICATIONS ARE CLOSED
KEY HIGHLIGHTS
STEM Learning: Deepen your knowledge in subjects such as Biology, Chemistry, Environmental Science, Computer Science, and Aerospace.
Virtual Asynchronous and Synchronous Sessions: Experience interactive virtual sessions as well as deepen your understanding of the subjects at your own pace.
Insightful Talks: Engage with enlightening talks by renowned faculty, students, and researchers at Stanford University.
​Research Skills: Learn essential techniques for conducting and writing a research paper.
Global Networking: Connect with brilliant students from around the world, fostering valuable relationships.
Office Hours: Over 50 hours of office hours with medical, dental, and undergraduate students.

Accepted students of the IYRC STEM Winter Program will be able to opt for the Adolescents Caring for COMmunity by Promoting Literacy on Insurance, Stroke, Health Education, Emergencies, and Dementia (ACComPLISHED) Community Health Worker (CHW) Program addition. This program is ideal for students interested in health or academia who wish to make a community impact. Participants will engage in clinical correlates, simulated patient encounters, and skill-building workshops led by physicians and allied health professionals from Columbia University and New York Presbyterian. The program features weekly Zoom sessions and monthly in-person meetings, personal mentorship from Columbia experts, and opportunities to implement a capstone community intervention. Students will educate five family or community members weekly, have access to extensive office hours, and present their projects at a symposium at Columbia VP&S.
enhanced_description: The IYRC STEM Winter Program offers students a comprehensive exploration of scientific concepts and technological advancements across fields including Biology, Chemistry, Environmental Science, Computer Science, and Aerospace. Participants engage in virtual asynchronous and synchronous sessions led by researchers and students from Stanford University, focusing on research paper techniques, global networking, and over 50 hours of dedicated office hours with medical, dental, and undergraduate mentors. Additionally, students can opt into the ACComPLISHED Community Health Worker program, which provides clinical correlates, simulated patient encounters, and mentorship from Columbia University and New York Presbyterian professionals to implement a capstone community health intervention. This supplemental program allows participants to educate community members on topics such as insurance, stroke, and health emergencies before presenting their projects at a concluding symposium.

title: HAS Astronomy
subtitle: NASA
raw_text: The High School Aerospace Scholars team is excited to launch our new astronomy course for educators to easily access NASA materials and events, as well as connect with other educators. There will be three modules available containing lessons for before, during, and after the eclipse to engage students in hands-on discovery learning that will pique their interests in the world of astronomy. Teachers can implement these lessons into their classroom instruction as they see fit. This astronomy course is primarily aimed at Texas educators working with grades 8-12 but is open to all U.S. educators. Some opportunities within the course may be limited to Texas residents only.

title: Duke University

title: International Relations Scholars Program
subtitle: Harvard University
raw_text:
About the Program

The Harvard University International Relations Scholars Program (HUIRSP) is a multi-day virtual conference for high school students who are interested in pursuing a career in foreign policy. This conference aims to reach students worldwide of diverse nationalities, socioeconomic classes, and lived experiences. HUIRSP provides participants with the unparalleled opportunity to explore pressing foreign policy subjects and engage in rigorous analytical assignments. Programming includes discussions with leading academics, policymakers, government officials, and regional experts. Students will gain skills in policy writing and cross-cultural leadership, and explore how to address global challenges from all sectors of international relations. There are two annual iterations of HUIRSP: the Summer Program (June of each year) and the Winter Intensive (January of each year). Students apply to HUIRSP on an individual basis.

The Policy Lab

Each iteration of HUIRSP offers participants the opportunity to participate in a Policy Lab. The Policy Lab offers a transformative experience for students, immersing them in a high-stakes simulation that mirrors the complexities of international policymaking. In this virtual lab, students are divided into teams, with each team representing different global actors, such as governments, international organizations (e.g., the United Nations), non-governmental organizations (NGOs), or multinational foundations (e.g., the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation). Teams will be placed in separate Zoom rooms, each tasked with addressing a pressing global issue—such as climate change, public health, or economic development—from their unique perspectives. As they develop policy solutions, real-world developments will be introduced that will force teams to reevaluate their strategies. For instance, a war might break out in one region, or an outbreak of a contagious disease may shift the global agenda. These events, along with the decisions made by other teams in different rooms, will have direct consequences on each group’s ability to move forward with their policies.

Throughout the process, teams will receive supervision, advice, and guidance from current Board Members of the Harvard Undergraduate Foreign Policy Initiative; after the conference, top policy solutions may be shared with professors at Harvard University.
enhanced_description: The Harvard University International Relations Scholars Program (HUIRSP) is a virtual conference designed for high school students worldwide who are interested in pursuing careers in foreign policy and international relations. Participants apply individually to join either the summer or winter iterations, where they engage in discussions with leading academics, government officials, and regional experts to develop skills in policy writing and cross-cultural leadership. A central component of the program is the Policy Lab, a high-stakes simulation where student teams represent various global actors—such as governments and international organizations—to address pressing issues like climate change or economic development. During this immersive experience, teams must adapt their strategies to evolving real-world developments and the actions of other groups while receiving guidance from board members of the Harvard Undergraduate Foreign Policy Initiative. Exceptional policy solutions developed during the program may even be shared with Harvard University professors following the conclusion of the conference.

title: Della Pietra HS Program
subtitle: Stony Brook
raw_text: Students will work in cooperative groups to explore various techniques plausible for high school level research. Students will be introduced to various model systems, such as E. coli, C. elegans, and D. melanogaster. Students will learn specific techniques that can be utilized with these organisms, such as bacterial transformations, gel electrophoresis, plasmid engineering, PCR analysis, DNA/RNA extraction, and RT-PCR analysis.

title: Nursing Academy
subtitle: Georgetown University HOYA Summer High School Sessions
raw_text:
This summer, spend one week immersed in the fast-paced, challenging, and rapidly evolving world of nursing. Our Nursing Academy offers an introduction to the nursing field, where you’ll have the opportunity to explore the fundamentals of the profession along with a variety of career paths and specializations, such as adult-gerontology, acute care, family practice, anesthesia, and women's health. You’ll also examine topics ranging from ethics and cultural competencies to biological, physical, and social sciences. Throughout the program, you’ll engage in faculty-led instruction and hands-on clinical experiences using a lifelike patient simulator at Georgetown’s O’Neill Family Foundation Clinical Simulation Center.

As a student in the Nursing Academy, you'll spend your day immersed in a blend of classroom lectures, field trips, hands-on activities, and group discussions. Throughout the course of the one-week program, you'll have the opportunity to explore the following subject areas:

Fundamentals of nursing
Healthcare settings
Biological science
Physical science
Social science
Ethics in healthcare
Cultural competency and healthcare
Clinical simulations
Career path in nursing specializations
enhanced_description: The Nursing Academy is a one-week immersive program designed to introduce students to the fundamentals of the nursing profession and its diverse career specializations, such as adult-gerontology, acute care, family practice, anesthesia, and women's health. Participants explore a wide range of subject areas, including healthcare ethics, cultural competency, and the biological, physical, and social sciences as they relate to medical practice. Learning is facilitated through a blend of faculty-led lectures, group discussions, and field trips, complemented by hands-on clinical experiences using lifelike patient simulators to prepare students for various healthcare settings.

title: Miami SAO
subtitle: Miami SAO High School Volunteer Internship Program
raw_text: This program offers high school students the chance to gain valuable experience in community service through volunteer work. Participants will engage in various projects that benefit the local community while developing essential skills and building their resumes.

title: Summer Math Program for Young Scholars

raw_text: The Summer Math Program for Young Scholars Program at NYU’s Center for Mathematical Talent is an intensive in-person 3-week long summer course for high school students, grades 9-11. The program provides a mathematically rich environment to students interested in math, and is designed to help them explore and navigate academic and professional careers in the mathematical sciences.

title: National Chemistry Olympiad
subtitle: ACS
raw_text: The American Chemical Society (ACS) Chemistry Olympiad is a national competition designed to challenge high school students in chemistry. It involves a series of exams and practical problems that test students' understanding of chemical principles and their problem-solving abilities. Participants who excel in the competition may advance to further rounds and potentially represent the United States in international chemistry events. The Olympiad aims to inspire students to pursue careers in chemistry and related fields. It provides recognition for outstanding achievements and promotes interest in the sciences.

title: Anime/Manga Session
subtitle: UTA
raw_text: Grades (9-12) - Campers learn how to creatively illustrate and produce their own works of fiction as they explore the depth of the “anime” art-style. Campers will learn about animation, artistic idiosyncrasies, and the many ways the Japanese culture and language has shaped this artistic genre. Campers will produce either an animated work, or comic, using this culturally explorative art style.

title: UCLA
subtitle: NeuroCamp Grades 9-12

Participants will engage in hands-on activities workshops and lectures that introduce them to the field of neuroscience. title: NJIT

raw_text: The NJIT Student Research Opportunities program offers undergraduate students a chance to engage in hands-on research projects under faculty mentorship. Participants can explore various fields within STEM while gaining valuable experience and skills. This program aims to foster innovation and collaboration in a supportive academic environment.

title: Cellular Construction Workshop
subtitle: UCSF
raw_text: The Cellular Construction Workshop (CCW) is a paid 10-day long summer program where high school students and teachers work together to learn about the field of cellular engineering. Students and teachers collaborate in teams to conduct experiments to observe how cells work, use robots and coding to copy how cells make decisions, and try to solve a real-world problem using what they’ve learned about cells and coding. No coding or robotics knowledge is necessary!

title: Global Youth Program - AI Leadership
subtitle: University of Pennsylvania Wharton
raw_text:
AI Leadership is an immersive program for students who want to explore the latest advancements in artificial intelligence and transformational technology. Held at Wharton San Francisco, students learn from Wharton faculty and industry experts while engaging in hands-on projects, site visits to top AI companies, and team-based problem solving. The program culminates in a final project that challenges students to apply AI tools to real-world business challenges—all while experiencing the heart of the tech industry in San Francisco. 

All participants who successfully complete the program will earn a Wharton Global Youth Certificate of Completion. 

By the end of the program students will be able to:

Identify and explain core AI concepts such as machine learning, natural language processing, and generative AI, and describe their applications in business contexts. 
Evaluate the impact of AI on different industries by analyzing real-world use cases discussed during lectures and site visits. 
Use beginner-level AI tools and platforms like ChatGPT to prototype or support the development of a solution to a real-world problem. 
Collaborate with a team to define a problem, research relevant AI applications, and design a creative solution supported by AI technologies. 
Create and deliver a final project presentation that clearly outlines the problem, proposed AI-powered solution, target users, and potential impact, using visuals and storytelling techniques. 
Engage with industry professionals during site visits and reflecting on how insights from these experiences can be applied to their own work. 
Demonstrate understanding of ethical considerations in AI, including data privacy, bias, and responsible innovation. 
Draw connections between San Francisco’s startup ecosystem and the emerging role of AI across industries.
enhanced_description: The AI Leadership program is an immersive experience designed for students to explore the latest advancements in artificial intelligence and transformational technology under the guidance of Wharton faculty and industry experts. Participants engage in hands-on projects, site visits to leading AI companies, and team-based problem solving to better understand core concepts like machine learning, natural language processing, and generative AI. Throughout the curriculum, students learn to use beginner-level AI tools for prototyping, evaluate the impact of technology across various industries, and address critical ethical considerations such as data privacy and algorithmic bias. The program culminates in a final project where teams design and present AI-powered solutions to real-world business challenges, and all successful participants earn a Wharton Global Youth Certificate of Completion.

title: Pre-Collegiate Summer Scholars Program
subtitle: Cornell

title: International Logic Olympiad, Senior
subtitle: International Logic Olympiad
raw_text:
The International Logic Olympiad is the leading logic competition hosted annually in partnership with Stanford University to promote and internationalize logic education.
Offering high school students worldwide a chance to showcase excellence in logic and problem-solving, The ILO culminates in an on-campus final round at Stanford University during the summer of 2025.

In our first year, we're proud to support:
3500+
Participants
92
Countries
2100+
Schools

The International Logic Olympiad started in 2024 as a partnership between Stanford University and Luminas, a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization.
Just like math and language, logic exists in the foundational fabric of society and is utilized perhaps even more so. However, logic is still severely underrepresented in modern education. Due to this gap, we started the ILO to highlight the importance of logical reasoning and problem-solving.
enhanced_description: The International Logic Olympiad (ILO) is a premier global competition hosted in partnership between Stanford University and Luminas, a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, to promote and internationalize logic education. Open to high school students worldwide, the activity provides a platform for participants to demonstrate excellence in logical reasoning and problem-solving while addressing the underrepresentation of logic in modern educational curricula. The competition structure includes a final round for top performers and has successfully engaged more than 3,500 participants from over 2,100 schools across 92 different countries.

title: Medical Academy
subtitle: Georgetown University HOYA Summer High School Sessions
raw_text:
The 1-Week Medical Academy introduces you to the field of medicine and gives you a glimpse into the Georgetown University Medical Center, which includes the nationally ranked School of Medicine and School of Nursing & Health Studies, in addition to the world-renowned Lombardi Cancer Center. You'll explore topics ranging from human anatomy, physiology, and radiology to surgery, cancer, biomedical ethics, and procurement of human tissues. You’ll participate in hands-on labs, including suturing, orthopedic casting, small mammal dissection, and use of a patient simulator. You will have the opportunity to interact directly with current medical students, Georgetown University School of Medicine faculty, and MedStar Georgetown University Hospital physicians to learn about the path to becoming a physician, discover ways to succeed in medical school, and explore a variety of medical specialties.

As a student in the 1-Week Medical Academy, you'll spend your day immersed in a blend of lectures, interactive experiences, and group discussions. Throughout the week, you'll have the opportunity to explore the following subject areas:

Medical gross anatomy
Cardiovascular physiology and pathology
Radiology
Surgery
Cancer
ICU medicine
Emergency medicine and trauma surgery
Internal medicine
Otolaryngology
Patient care
Biomedical ethics
enhanced_description: The 1-Week Medical Academy offers an immersive introduction to the medical field through the Georgetown University Medical Center’s various schools and the Lombardi Cancer Center. Students engage in a rigorous curriculum that blends lectures and group discussions with hands-on laboratory experiences, including suturing, orthopedic casting, small mammal dissection, and the use of patient simulators. The program covers a wide range of topics such as gross anatomy, cardiovascular physiology, radiology, trauma surgery, and biomedical ethics, while providing direct access to medical students, faculty, and hospital physicians. By participating in these interactive sessions, students explore numerous medical specialties and gain valuable insights into the educational path and professional skills required to succeed in medical school and become a physician.

title: Tisch Future Artists

raw_text: Explore your talents and accelerate your skills this spring in one of eight artistics tracks at the Tisch School of the Arts. title: Threading the Past + Present
subtitle: Emory
raw_text: Clothing is more than the fabrics we wear. It can communicate so much about us and can be used as a form of self-expression. Throughout the week, campers will explore the utility and visual power of clothing and accessories. Fiber artist Sara Perez will lead campers through the Carlos collections, considering what types of garments people wore in ancient Egypt, Greece and Rome, India, and more, and what it might tell us about them. Campers will design, sew, and construct garments and accessories based on our daily explorations.

title: AIME
subtitle: MAA
raw_text:
Skip to content
Mathematical Association of America

Search
LOGIN
MAA Invitational Competitions
Information Overview

Students who perform exceptionally well on the AMC 10 or AMC 12 are invited to continue participating in the MAA AMC series of examinations that culminate in the selection process for the USA International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO) team.
Invitational Competition Sequence

The first in this series is the American Invitational Mathematics Exam (AIME), followed by the USA Mathematical Olympiad and Junior Mathematical Olympiad (USAMO and USAJMO).

The top USAMO and USAJMO participants are invited to the Mathematical Olympiad Program (MOP) in the summer after the competition for mathematical development.

Based on testing at MOP, a select group of students is invited to participate in the Team Selection Tests (TSTs), a series of exams to determine the teams that will represent the USA at the International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO) and the European Girls’ Mathematical Olympiad (EGMO).

American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME)

The American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) is a challenging competition offered for those who excelled on the AMC 10 and/or AMC 12.

Description: The AIME is a 15-question, 3-hour examination, in which each answer is an integer number between 0 to 999. The questions on the AIME are much more difficult than those on the AMC 10 and AMC 12. Top-scoring participants on the AIME are invited to take the USAMO or USAJMO.

AIME I vs. AIME II: The AIME is given on a primary date (AIME I), and an alternate date (AIME II) to accommodate those unable to participate in the AIME I. Students may only take the AIME once; any student who takes both the AIME I and II will be disqualified.

AIME Competition Timeframe:

Administered between 1:30 pm ET and 5:30 pm ET on Competition Day.
AIME Administration Resources:

The AIME II Registration Form and the Change of Venue Form are located under “Competition Resources” on the dashboard of the AMC Platform. Only competition managers may fill out these forms.

AIME II Registration Form: Students who qualify for the AIME will automatically be registered to take the AIME I. Competition managers who cannot administer the AIME I or have students who cannot take it on that date must register for the AIME II. Complete the AIME II Registration Form by the deadline stated in the form.
AIME Change of Venue Form: Students who qualified for the AIME must take either the AIME I or AIME II at the institution where they took the AMC 10 and/or AMC 12. If the competition manager is unable to offer AIME I or II or a student absolutely cannot take the AIME at the same competition location, it is the competition manager’s responsibility to make arrangements with a different competition manager for their student and complete the Change of Venue Form by the deadline stated in the form.
Competition Managers who are administering both the AIME I and AIME II have the ability to switch students between the two competitions on the AMC platform.

USA Mathematical Olympiad and Junior Mathematical Olympiad (USAMO and USAJMO)

The United States of America Mathematical Olympiad (USAMO) and the United States of America Junior Mathematical Olympiad (USAJMO) are the national-level invitational competitions that serve as a key step in the International Mathematical Olympiad team selection process.

Description: The USAMO and USAJMO are six-question, two-day, 9-hour essay/proof examinations. The top-scoring AMC 12 participants (based on a combination of AMC 12 and AIME scores) are invited to take the USAMO. The top-scoring AMC 10 participants (based on a combination of AMC 10 and AIME score) are invited to take the USAJMO. 

The MAA AMC champions inclusivity within our program and competitions. As we work towards creating a mathematical community to empower students of all genders, we invite the top-scoring AMC girl-identifying students to our USAMO and USAJMO each year. These students are placed on an ambitious path to potentially qualify for MOP, EGMO, and ultimately the IMO.

USAMO and USAJMO Competition Timeframe:

Administered between 1 and 5:30 pm ET on each of two competition days.
USAMO and USAJMO Venues:

The USAMO/USAJMO will now be held only at select official testing sites. Qualifying students will be invited to register at a nearby site as soon as AIME scoring is complete.

Awarding: For the USAMO, the AMC awards Gold prizes to at least approximately 6%, Silver to at least approximately 12%, and Bronze to at least approximately 18% of competitors. For the USAJMO, we name winners and recognize approximately 20% of contestants. For both USAMO and USAJMO, each additional contestant with 14 points or more will receive an Honorable Mention distinction. Each year, the Student Selection Committee will decide the exact percentages and number of awards.

FAQs for the AIME and USAMO/USAJMO

enhanced_description: The MAA Invitational Competitions are a series of advanced examinations for students who excel on the AMC 10 or AMC 12, serving as the primary selection process for the teams representing the United States at the International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO) and the European Girls’ Mathematical Olympiad (EGMO). The sequence begins with the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), a three-hour, 15-question test requiring integer answers between 0 and 999, followed by the USA Mathematical Olympiad (USAMO) and Junior Mathematical Olympiad (USAJMO), which are nine-hour, two-day proof-based examinations. Qualification for these national-level events is determined by a combination of AMC and AIME scores, with the USAMO open to AMC 12 high-scorers and the USAJMO open to AMC 10 high-scorers, including a specific path for top-scoring girl-identifying students to empower gender diversity in mathematics. Top performers from these olympiads are invited to the Mathematical Olympiad Program (MOP) for intensive development, where Team Selection Tests (TSTs) are used to finalize the international competitive teams. Participants are eligible for various distinctions including Gold, Silver, and Bronze prizes, though they must adhere to strict registration protocols, such as only taking one version of the AIME and coordinating any necessary venue changes through their competition managers via the AMC platform.

title: Swarthmore College
subtitle: Summer Research Program
raw_text: This program offers undergraduate students the opportunity to engage in research under the guidance of faculty mentors. Students will work on projects that contribute to ongoing research in various STEM fields. Participants gain valuable experience and skills while exploring academic and career paths in science and engineering.

title: Summer Program for Verbally and Mathematically Precocious Youth
subtitle: Vampy
raw_text: A three-week residential camp held in June and July, VAMPY offers high-ability students who have completed grades 7–10 the chance to focus on one course during six class hours each weekday plus a nightly hour-long study hall. Classes are taught by highly motivated WKU faculty and high school teachers who are thrilled to have equally highly motivated students.

title: North Carolina State University (NCSU)
subtitle: Summer Textiles Exploration Program (STEP)
raw_text: This program offers high school students an immersive experience in textiles through hands-on activities and workshops. Participants will explore various aspects of textile design and production while gaining insights into the industry. It encourages creativity and innovation in the field of textiles.

title: Coding for Game Design
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: In 2024, we are offering one remote and two in-person sessions. Each session will be two weeks long. In each session, participants will learn about the principles of game design and be introduced to C# and Unity scripting, which they will use to create their own games! The program emphasizes team collaboration and close work with experienced game designers and developers. Students will work together and independently to create 2D/3D Unity games based on design principles and development techniques used by professionals at NYU.

title: Summer Session
subtitle: UCSC
raw_text: Our high school programs welcome students locally and globally to enroll in an actual UC Santa Cruz undergraduate university course. Students gain experience with the excitement and challenge of college-level academics while earning UC credits they can transfer to a future college or back to high school. Join our mailing list to be reminded of upcoming dates and deadlines.

title: Pre-College Scholars Program
subtitle: UMD
raw_text: The goal of the Clark School Pre-College Scholars Program is to recruit talented students to attend the A. James Clark School of Engineering at the University of Maryland.  The program recruits students in the 10th and 11th grade (rising juniors and seniors) who have an interest in and aptitude for mathematics, science and/or engineering.

title: PATHS-UP Young Scholar
subtitle: Rice
raw_text: The Digital Health Young Scholars Program is made possible by the Precise Advanced Technologies and Health Systems for Underserved Populations (PATHS-UP) and Expeditions in Computing. This summer program is a three-week program for current (2023-2024 school year) 10th and 11th Grade students which aims to introduce them to digital circuitry, computer science, physics, and engineering research at Rice University and its practical applications in the health care field.

title: Pre-College
subtitle: UMD
raw_text: The Upward Bound Program is a federally funded and state supported educational program that provides academic and counseling services to students in preparation for post-secondary education. The purpose of Upward Bound is to supplement our students secondary school experience by providing opportunities for academic, social, and emotional development in preparation for college. Our summer and academic year programs serve as a supplement to a student's high school experience by creating more opportunities for students to become college ready and build their academic and social skills.

title: Summer Science Academy
subtitle: Emory
raw_text: Summer Science Academy Day Program offers an exciting and engaging hands-on experience for passionate incoming 9th and 10th grade students with an interest in sciences: biology, health care, medicine, or related STEM fields. The 2024 Academy will take place in-person where you and your Academy mates will learn a variety of topics such as:

Aggie STEM Summer Camp Policies
What are Aggie STEM Overnight camps?
Aggie STEM Camps are one-week camps designed to encourage the exploration of STEM-focused project-based learning (PBL). Aggie STEM Summer camps are held at Texas A&M University in College Station. Camps are geared towards students entering 6th through 12th grade in the Fall of 2026. Aggie STEM campers are typically advanced students who reflect the core values of Texas A&M University and have a strong interest in STEM related fields. Registration is on a first-come basis.

New classes are offered every summer season for both High school and Junior high camps based on the availability of our STEM instructors. Each summer has a new camp theme, with new PBL (project-based learning) STEM classes campers are sure to enjoy.

Please note: The sample schedules and topics provided are for informational purposes only and are subject to change. Actual classes and content may vary.

9
Sample Junior-high schedule
View our sample Junior high schedule

9
Sample high-school schedule
View our sample High school schedule

What are Aggie STEM Elementary Day camps?
Aggie STEM Elementary Day Camps are Monday-Friday camps designed to encourage the exploration of STEM-focused project-based learning (PBL). Aggie STEM Summer camps are held at Texas A&M University in College Station. Camps are geared towards students entering 3rd through 5th grade in the Fall of 2026. Registration is on a first-come basis.

New classes are offered every summer season for Elementary students based on the availability of our STEM instructors. Each summer has a new camp theme, with new PBL (project-based learning) STEM classes campers are sure to enjoy.

*All 4 weeks of Day Camp will follow the same schedule and curriculum. 

Exploring scientific solutions to real world problems
Our camps are led by STEM professionals and A&M faculty. While Aggie STEM camp has a heavy focus on promoting STEM learning, it’s still a summer camp with plenty of fun activities to create lasting memories and connections.

Our camps explore a broad range of STEM content to include but not limited to:
9

9

Overnight Camp details
Aggie STEM Overnight Camps are a 6-day/6-night program at Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas for incoming 6-12th grade students. All camps provide food and lodging. A variety of meals and snacks are provided to support all dietary needs and restrictions. All campers will receive a private room with shared common areas and the option to select a roommate preference when registering. Tuition for middle grade camp is $1499 and tuition for high school camp is $1699. Registration fees and deposits are nonrefundable but are transferrable to other Aggie STEM sponsored camp weeks.

Packing List Link: https://u.tamu.edu/OvernightPackingList

Day Camp details
Aggie STEM Day Camps are a 5-day program at Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas for incoming 3rd-5th grade students. Day Camps provide snacks and a T-shirt, but campers are required to bring a packed lunch each day. Tuition for Day camps is $425 with a required $75 deposit. Registration fees and deposits are nonrefundable but are transferrable to other Aggie STEM sponsored camp weeks.
