enhanced_description: The Accelerated Learning Program (ALP) is a rigorous three-week precollege experience designed for high school students finishing grades 9 through 12 from across the United States and around the globe. Participants engage in 95 hours of instruction through a single, intensive non-credit course in subjects such as neuroscience, engineering, or international law, with the potential to coordinate high school credit upon completion. The program offers both residential and commuter options, featuring a daily schedule of morning and afternoon sessions followed by required study periods and social activities led by staff. This year, the program includes the Wisconsin International Precollege Academy as a specific academic track focused on international college readiness. Instruction is provided by subject-matter specialists and supported by teaching assistants in small, personalized classes. Admission is based on a rolling review of transcripts, essays, and English proficiency for international applicants—typically requiring a 3.2 GPA—with costs ranging from $2,850 to $5,100 plus a $100 application fee, though limited need-based scholarships are available.

title: Young Executive Scholars Hospitality and Tourism Program
subtitle: UNLV
raw_text: Modeled after the University of Nevada, Las Vegas’ International Gaming Institute (UNLV IGI) and University of Nevada Reno’s renowned Executive Development Program for industry professionals, the Young Executive Scholars Hospitality & Tourism Program (YES) is a rigorous summer course of applied learning, team collaboration, and a mentor-guided, case-study analysis of the global hospitality tourism industry. Each summer, under-resourced high school students discover the managerial and executive-level career opportunities available to them in the industry of their backyard, gain insight into the UNLV college experience, and develop new skills to excel in the classroom today and the workplace tomorrow.

title: Future Scholars
subtitle: Rutgers
raw_text: At Rutgers Future Scholars, we believe that access to higher education not only changes the lives of our students, but also has the power to change entire communities. Each year, the Rutgers Future Scholars program offers 215 first-generation, low-income, academically promising middle school students from New Brunswick, Piscataway, Newark, Camden and Rahway the opportunity for a college education. Click on a town to learn more about each program. In the summer before their 8th grade year, students become part of a unique pre-college culture of university programming, events, support, and mentoring that will continue through their high school years, and eventually college.

title: Design Media Arts
subtitle: UCLA
raw_text: The DMA Summer Institute curriculum is based on materials covered in the department’s undergraduate curriculum. Each class is taught by one instructor and one program assistant; class size is limited to a maximum of 20 students. Students explore a variety of media examining different practices and design methods applied to the domains of 2D image, net, 3D worldbuilding, and motion design. Broadly addressing a common theme, all four classes contribute to the creation of an integrated, multi-media exhibition at the end of the program.

title: Summer Challenge
subtitle: Boston University
raw_text: It’s called Summer Challenge because it pushes you in so many ways. You will explore your interests, discover new ones, test your academic boundaries, and immerse yourself in the college experience. Along the way, you will make new friends and get to know more about Boston University. Are you up to the challenge?

title: Preparatory Program
subtitle: Princeton
raw_text: PUPP is a rigorous academic and cultural enrichment program that supports high-achieving, low-income high school students. The multi-year, tuition-free program prepares participants for admission to and success in highly selective colleges.  It includes a 6-week summer program for 3 consecutive summers, year-round events including weekly meetings, cultural enrichment, college tours and test prep, and college application/financial aid help. Students receive various materials, including a Chromebook upon entry to the program.

title: Big Idea Competition
subtitle: Big Idea
raw_text:
As a young entrepreneur, what business would you start to make your world a better place to live? Think about problems you hear about in today’s news or problems that you personally experience. What business can you create to solve those problems? How can you use technology to solve those problems? Put your best business idea forward and compete for cash prizes and scholarships in the BIG Idea Competition – nearly $55,000 to be awarded! Learn more about the competition here. Part of the mission of the BIG Idea Competition is to spur creative thinking as part of the business building process. Think about your business as a way to solve a problem. How can your BIG Idea change the world or just make your corner of it a better place to live? Do you need help creating your big idea? If you do, the link below will help you start the brainstorming process. Judging the Wellness Category  (sponsored by Independent Health Solutions)
To enter this category, students’ business concept must promote wellness. Wellness is defined as a state of being in good physical and mental health.  Students must  check the Wellness box in the Entry form under the Business Name section to be submitted in this category.   The sponsor will choose the winner of the Wellness category from the top 10 highest scoring entries in the category.   The winning prize is $500 cash and a $500 scholarship to Northern State University.

Judging the Agriculture Innovation Category*  (sponsored by South Dakota Agriculture Foundation)
To enter this category, students’ business concept must promote agriculture by incorporating innovation, technology and/or leadership into agriculture or agriculture education. Students must check the agriculture innovation category box in the entry form under the business name section to be submitted into this category. The top 10 scoring entries will be submitted to the sponsor who will determine the winner of this category. The winning prize is $500 cash and a $500 scholarship to Northern State University. This category can only be won by a South Dakota student.

Judging the Hometown Business Category* (sponsored by South Dakota Retailers Association)
To enter this category, students’ business concept must promote small town business. The Hometown Business Category must be a brick-and-mortar retail, hospitality, grocery, or trade business. The business should also have an online presence but needs to have a physical storefront component, not online only. The category will also be judged based on if the business idea would be suitable in a community with a smaller population. Students must check the Hometown Business category box in the entry form under the business name section to be submitted into this category. The top 10 scoring entries will be submitted to a panel of retailers who will determine the winner of this category. The winning prize is $500 cash and a $500 scholarship to Northern State University. This category can only be won by a South Dakota student.

Judging the Makers Award Category* (sponsored by Blackout Industries)
To enter this category, students’ business concept must promote manufacturing. The Makers Award Category must be a business that creates and builds a physical product, which can include either a custom product built one at a time or a product that is made in larger quantities. Students must check the Makers Award category box in the entry form under the business name section to be submitted into this category. The top 10 scoring entries will be submitted to the sponsor who will determine the winner of this category. The winning prize is $500 cash and a $500 scholarship to Northern State University. This category can only be won by a South Dakota student.
enhanced_description: The BIG Idea Competition challenges young entrepreneurs to submit creative business concepts that solve modern problems using technology, with nearly $55,000 in total cash prizes and scholarships available to winners. Students can enter specialized categories such as Wellness for health-related ideas, Agriculture Innovation for tech-driven farming, Hometown Business for small-town brick-and-mortar retail, and the Makers Award for manufacturing physical products. To apply for these specific awards, participants must select the corresponding category on their entry form to be judged among the top ten scoring entries for a $500 cash prize and a $500 scholarship to Northern State University. While the competition encourages broad participation, the Agriculture Innovation, Hometown Business, and Makers Award categories are exclusively available to South Dakota students.

title: Summer Engineering Experience
subtitle: CMU
raw_text: The Summer Engineering Experience (SEE) is a week-long summer experience for rising 8th through 11th graders who are interested in math and science. SEE gives students hands-on experience in different forms of engineering. Session 1: The focus of this session is to expose the students to different engineering disciplines and the concept of design. In addition to educational presentations throughout the week, students will complete two projects primarily utilizing items readily available in their households. The first project is a structured assignment that will be completed by the entire group throughout the week. The second is a project that will be completed individually, working within smaller groups, that allows the students to be innovative and creative. Both projects teach the students problem-solving, critical thinking, and design concepts. Session 2: Biomedical Engineering is one of the more recent disciplines of engineering. Through academic presentations and interactive project work, students will learn about the intricacies and considerations that go into solving medical issues by applying engineering principles to biology and medicine, exploring interdisciplinary engineering concepts such as biomechanics, bioinstrumentation systems, circuit elements, stem cell and tissue engineering, robotics and 3D bioprinting.

title: Teen Med Camp
subtitle: UTA
raw_text: Grades (8-12) - For teens thinking about a career in medicine, this camp offers a valuable experience. Campers will study different body systems, learn how different medical specialties relate to each other, wellness techniques and nutrition, and how to test vital signs. At the end of the camp, campers will also earn CPR certification.

title: Climate Science at UNL
subtitle: YNS
raw_text: High schoolers (grades 9-12) can attend YNS summer camps -OR- apply to be a High School Researcher*. YNS High School Camps take place in Nebraska college laboratories with small groups and experiments for hands-on aspects of science with in-depth experiences. Each summer a few high school students are chosen for paid positions as High School Researchers: working with science teams at Nebraska campuses. These experiences are ideal for exposure to real-life STEM job experiences, and look great on your college applications.

title: Math Meet
subtitle: Purple Comet
raw_text: The Purple Comet Math Meet is an international math competition where students solve challenging problems individually and in teams. Participants compete in a timed environment, testing their mathematical skills. The competition aims to promote mathematical problem-solving and teamwork among students. Winners receive recognition and awards for their performance. The event supports the development of advanced mathematical skills and collaboration.

title: Tulane University
subtitle: Tulane Pre-College Architecture Program
raw_text: This pre-college program offers high school students an immersive experience in architecture through hands-on design projects and studio work. Students will explore the fundamentals of architecture and develop skills in critical thinking and creative problem-solving while engaging with faculty and peers in a collaborative environment.

title: Yale University
subtitle: Yale High School Internship Program
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to gain hands-on experience in various IT roles at Yale University. Students will work on real projects learn about technology and develop professional skills in a supportive environment. Interns will receive mentorship and guidance from experienced professionals.

title: Young Scholars Summer Research Experience (YS)
subtitle: Florida International University
raw_text: The Young Scholars Program at FIU offers high school students the opportunity to engage in research projects under the guidance of faculty mentors. Participants gain hands-on experience in various STEM fields while developing critical thinking and problem-solving skills essential for academic and professional success.

title: UTEP
subtitle: UTEP ExcITE Program
raw_text: The UTEP ExcITE Program offers high school students hands-on experience in engineering through interactive workshops and activities. Participants will explore various engineering disciplines and develop problem-solving skills while working on real-world projects. The program aims to inspire the next generation of engineers and innovators.

title: Davidson College
subtitle: Davidson Summer Promise Program
raw_text: The Davidson Summer Promise Program offers high school students a chance to engage in community service while developing leadership skills. Participants work on meaningful projects that benefit the local community and gain valuable experience in civic engagement and social responsibility.

title: Pre-College
subtitle: Harvard
raw_text: Harvard’s Pre-College Program for high school students is an intensive two-week summer program designed to give you a glimpse of college life. You will live on the Harvard campus during your two-week session while taking a college-level course with other Pre-College Program students.

title: USA BIOlympiad
subtitle: CEE
raw_text: The USA Biology Olympiad (USABO) is a national competition that tests high school students' knowledge and understanding of biology. Participants compete in written exams and practical lab tests to demonstrate their proficiency in biological sciences. The Olympiad aims to identify and support top young biologists and prepare them for international competitions. It provides an opportunity for students to showcase their biological knowledge and gain recognition in the field. Success in USABO can lead to further academic and career opportunities in biology.

title: Democracy Scholars
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: Democracy Scholars is a tuition-free program for New York City students entering their senior year of high school. For two weeks in July, students take discussion-based seminars taught by NYU faculty and build essential skills in critical thinking, college-level reading and writing.  In addition to engaging in daily classroom discussions, students will get an introduction to university life, attend field trips exploring the local community, gain real-world experience as student leaders, community activists and global citizens, and connect with other bold, intellectually curious students like them.

title: Duke Math Meet
subtitle: Duke
raw_text: The Duke Math Meet is an annual math competition for high school students hosted by Duke University. Participants engage in individual and team problem-solving events. The meet aims to foster mathematical skills and teamwork among students. Winners receive recognition and awards for their performance. The competition supports the development of advanced mathematical skills and collaboration.

title: OSU
subtitle: Arts and Sciences Summer Exploration Program
raw_text: This program offers high school students a chance to explore various disciplines within the arts and sciences through engaging activities and coursework. Students will experience life on a college campus while gaining valuable insights into academic and career pathways.

title: University of Kansas
subtitle: Summer Venture in Business
raw_text: This program offers high school students the chance to explore business concepts through hands-on activities and real-world experiences. Participants will engage in team projects and develop skills in entrepreneurship marketing and finance while gaining insight into college life and the business world.

title: World Wildlife Day Youth Art Contest
subtitle: UN
raw_text: The World Wildlife Day Youth Art Contest invites high school students to create and submit artwork that celebrates wildlife and conservation. The contest aims to raise awareness about the importance of protecting endangered species and their habitats. Participants' artworks are evaluated based on creativity and relevance to wildlife conservation themes. The competition provides an opportunity for students to express their passion for wildlife through art. Winners receive recognition and prizes for their contributions to promoting environmental awareness.

title: Fab Lab: 3D Printing
subtitle: UTA
raw_text: Grades (9-12) - Unleash your inner artist when you create a sculpture using 3-D modeling software and a 3-D printer. Campers will learn about 3-D printing, constructing functional and sturdy creations from multiple materials, and using 3-D rendering software as they construct their own design.

title: Begin Your Medical Research Journey
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: Every vaccine, drug, and treatment used in medicine is the result of evidence-based research. For a cancer therapy to succeed, medical researchers have to ask a question. Will it work? In this course you will learn the process researchers use to formulate, conduct, and evaluate the evidence they gather. You will be tasked with developing your own study using professional methods. For any high schooler thinking about a future in STEM, medical research, pharmaceuticals or medical school, this course is for you.

title: Global Youth Program - Essentials of Leadership
subtitle: University of Pennsylvania Wharton
raw_text:
Essentials of Leadership prepares talented high school students to become leaders in the global economy. Through a curriculum of rigorous coursework and activities, students will build skills in emotional intelligence, problem-solving, interpersonal communication, and effective teamwork and collaboration.

This program blends leadership theory with practice, including two immersive business simulations, case studies, and a final industry leadership project.

Key themes and topics include: 

Developing Self-Awareness
Exploring leadership styles and personal strengths 
The Johari Window and emotional intelligence 
Building self-confidence and resilience as a leader 
Leadership Characteristics and Principles 
Situational leadership and adapting to context 
Identifying the traits of effective leaders 
Teamwork and Collaboration 
Stages of team development 
Characteristics of high-performing teams 
Leading and contributing in group projects 
Negotiation and Conflict Resolution 
Strategies for group negotiation 
Managing disagreements and pressure effectively 
Strategic Planning and Decision-Making 
Setting SMART goals and creating actionable plans 
Analyzing industries and competitive landscapes 
Case studies in ethical decision-making 
Business Simulations 
OPEQ Negotiation Simulation: competing and cooperating in groups 
Wildfire Simulation: crisis management and decision-making under pressure
Communication and Presentation Skills 
Crafting persuasive arguments and leadership messages 
Leading with clarity and confidence 
Presenting team projects to peers and instructors
By the end of the program, students will have practiced leadership in multiple contexts—negotiating, leading teams, making ethical decisions, and presenting ideas. They will leave with a deeper understanding of who they are as leaders and how to apply their skills in school, community, and future careers.
enhanced_description: Essentials of Leadership is a comprehensive program designed for talented high school students that focuses on preparing them for leadership roles in the global economy through a blend of theory and practical application. The curriculum features rigorous coursework, case studies, and a final industry leadership project, alongside immersive business simulations like the OPEQ Negotiation and the Wildfire crisis management exercise. Students explore key themes such as self-awareness, emotional intelligence, situational leadership, and strategic planning while developing essential skills in negotiation, conflict resolution, and ethical decision-making. By practicing teamwork and presentation skills, participants gain the confidence to lead effectively in various contexts, ultimately preparing them to apply these leadership principles to their schools, communities, and future professional careers.

title: UCR
subtitle: UCR RISE
raw_text: The UCR RISE program offers high school students a unique opportunity to engage in research and gain hands-on experience in STEM fields. Participants will work closely with faculty mentors develop critical thinking skills and enhance their understanding of scientific inquiry through immersive learning experiences.

title: UMKC
subtitle: High School Scholars Program
raw_text: The High School Scholars Program at UMKC offers high school students the opportunity to take college courses earn college credit and explore academic interests. Students can engage with faculty and experience college life while enhancing their educational journey through this enriching program.

title: UConn
subtitle: Pre-College Academic Enrichment Program
raw_text: This program offers high school students an opportunity to explore health careers through hands-on activities and academic enrichment. Students will engage in interactive sessions with healthcare professionals and participate in workshops designed to enhance their understanding of various medical fields.

title: Colorado School of Mines
subtitle: Summer Multicultural Engineering Training
raw_text: This program is designed for high school students from diverse backgrounds interested in engineering. Participants will engage in hands-on activities and workshops that promote engineering concepts and skills. The program aims to inspire and prepare students for future studies in engineering fields.

title: Dune Neuroscience Experience
subtitle: Duke
raw_text: DUNE engages local high school students in full-time summer research in cutting-edge neuroscience labs at Duke University. Our students gain hands-on research experience, participate in professional development activities, and receive a stipend. We encourage students from diverse backgrounds to apply, including students without prior research experience.

title: Summer Academy for Math & Science
subtitle: Carnegie Mellon University
raw_text:
For over twenty-five years, the Summer Academy for Math and Science (SAMS) program has engaged students in a rigorous curriculum taught by faculty and staff who are deeply committed to student success. Led by the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion, SAMS allows students to develop a deeper understanding of STEM via traditional classroom instruction, through hands-on projects, and sustained engagement with world-renowned faculty and skilled staff mentors. In addition to their academic experiences, students also have the opportunity to collaborate and develop meaningful relationships with peers from across the country.

Through SAMS and other outreach initiatives, the university:
Develops a diverse and supportive community of STEM Scholars interested in attending top-tier universities.
Strengthens students’ commitment to pursuing STEM-related disciplines.
Broadens students understanding and access to opportunities made available through study in STEM.
Equips students with the knowledge, skills, and confidence to be successful STEM scholars.
Curriculum 
The Summer Academy for Math and Science will consist of 3 parts:
PART 1: Part one of the SAMS program occurs prior to the start of the residential program. This is a required virtual Jumpstart for participants, focusing on skill-building that is needed for the in-person program. We will be connecting virtually for portions of both June 15 & June 16, 2026, however students will not be needed for full days. 
PART 2: Part two of the SAMS program is a 6-week, in-person, Pre-College program. SAMS Scholars will be in courses and meetings for full days during the time they are here. The academic portion of the program will conclude with the research symposium on the final Friday of the program.  Scholars are responsible for their travel to and from Pittsburgh. 
Academic Experience
SAMS Research Symposium
SAMS students at orientation
Testimonials
I learned so much during my SAMS experience, and I feel like it will really help me move forward as an educated scholar. ~Participant, SAMS 2025
I really enjoyed learning new things with a supportive environment and amazing group of people. ~Participant, SAMS 2025
I really enjoyed the community at SAMS. Although it is cliche to say, I really felt like I met people who I really connected with and felt supported by. I think I will forever remember the people here at SAMS as the first time I have felt like I was in a true community of people who had the same passion and support for others. ~Participant, SAMS 2025
I liked connecting with so many different people and seeing the paths that people took to get where they are and how unique and diverse their experiences were. ~Participant, SAMS 2025
Hear more from our students and families here.
SAMS students on outing
PART 3: Part three of the SAMS program involves Sustaining Connections & Engagement Experiences.These connections will be ongoing and virtual.
Students will have the opportunity to participate in on-going virtual enrichment sessions, such as FAFSA, college prep, budgeting, and info sessions on additional development opportunities. Families and caregivers will be invited to attend relevant sessions.
Students will interact with current Carnegie Mellon community members to explore STEM majors and opportunities at CMU.
SAMS is a fully funded, merit-based program. There is no cost for scholars to participate beyond their travel to and from Pittsburgh, PA. We expect all SAMS Scholars to participate fully for the duration of the program. We understand that students may be applying to multiple summer opportunities, however if selected for SAMS, scholars will not be permitted to participate in any other programs (virtual or in person) if program dates conflict.
enhanced_description: The Summer Academy for Math and Science (SAMS) is a fully funded, merit-based program led by the Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion that provides students with a rigorous STEM curriculum through classroom instruction, hands-on projects, and mentorship from world-renowned faculty. The program structure consists of three parts: a required virtual jumpstart focused on skill-building, a six-week in-person academic experience culminating in a research symposium, and a final phase of ongoing virtual enrichment sessions covering topics such as college preparation, financial aid, and budgeting. Participants join a diverse community of scholars to strengthen their commitment to STEM disciplines and gain the necessary skills to succeed at top-tier universities. While there is no cost for scholars to participate, the program requires full engagement for its duration, and students are not permitted to participate in other conflicting activities during the program period.

title: Youth Leadership Program
subtitle: AAU
raw_text: The Asian Americans United Summer Program is a six-week leadership program for high school youth and a four-week summer camp program for children (grades 2-5). A week and a half of intensive training prepares youth staff to run the summer program for children and includes team-building, leadership development, discussion of identity and history, and training on delivering the summer curriculum. The youth staff, under the supervision of the Program Director, run the Summer Program for children for four weeks. The summer camp runs Mondays through Thursdays. High school youth staff provide instruction on an alternating basis, scheduled either on Monday/Tuesday or Wednesday/Thursday, and all youth staff come together Fridays for a full training day with workshops, speakers, and time for youth staff to work on their own curriculum.

title: California State University Sacramento (CSUS)
subtitle: Summer Youth Academies
raw_text: The Summer Youth Academies at CSUS offer engaging educational experiences for students in grades 6-12. Participants can explore various subjects including STEM and the arts while developing new skills and making friends. The program is designed to inspire and empower young learners through hands-on activities.

title: Neubauer Phoenix Scholars
subtitle: UChicago
raw_text: From creating the first controlled, self-sustaining nuclear reaction to discovering the mathematical theory of black holes, the University of Chicago has long been a pioneer in groundbreaking STEM research. Our students and professors are fearless and creative problem solvers, who engage in interdisciplinary thinking, and who value diverse perspectives. Diversity is a fundamental driver of innovation and progress in STEM fields. By uniting diverse students and faculty for more than a century, UChicago has fostered one of the most unique—and decorated—intellectual communities in the world. The Neubauer Phoenix STEM Summer Program offers the opportunity for outstanding students of all backgrounds who value diversity of thought and experience with an interest in STEM-related areas to be exposed to UChicago’s distinctive approach and abundant research and academic opportunities in STEM fields.

title: LSU
subtitle: Architecture Design Workshop
raw_text: This workshop invites high school students to explore architecture and design through hands-on activities and collaborative projects. Participants will engage with faculty and students while developing their creative skills and understanding of the design process. The program culminates in a presentation of their work.

title: 1-Week Medical Academy
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text:
Hoya Summer High School Information Session Webinar
Wednesday, Nov. 19, 4–5 p.m. ET

This information session will review our three programs: Non-Credit Academies, College Prep, and Summer College. We want to ensure that our prospective students are confident in their choice while planning their summer at Georgetown. We will provide an overview of each program and its respective application processes.The 1-Week Medical Academy introduces you to the field of medicine and gives you a glimpse into the Georgetown University Medical Center, which includes the nationally ranked School of Medicine and School of Nursing & Health Studies, in addition to the world-renowned Lombardi Cancer Center. You'll explore topics ranging from human anatomy, physiology, and radiology to surgery, cancer, biomedical ethics, and procurement of human tissues. You’ll participate in hands-on labs, including suturing, orthopedic casting, small mammal dissection, and use of a patient simulator. You will have the opportunity to interact directly with current medical students, Georgetown University School of Medicine faculty, and MedStar Georgetown University Hospital physicians to learn about the path to becoming a physician, discover ways to succeed in medical school, and explore a variety of medical specialties.Program Format & Subject Areas
As a student in the 1-Week Medical Academy, you'll spend your day immersed in a blend of lectures, interactive experiences, and group discussions. Throughout the week, you'll have the opportunity to explore the following subject areas:

Medical gross anatomy
Cardiovascular physiology and pathology
Radiology
Surgery
Cancer
ICU medicine
Emergency medicine and trauma surgery
Internal medicine
Otolaryngology
Patient care
Biomedical ethics
enhanced_description: Georgetown University offers several summer programs for high school students, including Non-Credit Academies, College Prep, and Summer College, each featuring its own specific application process. The 1-Week Medical Academy introduces participants to the field of medicine through a blend of lectures, group discussions, and hands-on labs involving suturing, orthopedic casting, small mammal dissection, and the use of patient simulators. Students explore a wide range of subject areas such as medical gross anatomy, cardiovascular physiology, radiology, surgery, emergency medicine, and biomedical ethics while gaining exposure to the university's medical center and the Lombardi Cancer Center. Participants also have the opportunity to interact directly with medical students, faculty, and hospital physicians to discuss the path to becoming a doctor and explore various medical specialties.

title: Global Youth Program - Pre-baccalaureate Program
subtitle: University of Pennsylvania Wharton
raw_text:
The Wharton Pre-baccalaureate Program is an academically intensive opportunity for exceptional high school juniors and seniors to enroll in credit-bearing courses that span the breadth of Wharton’s business curriculum. Through a mix of live and independent coursework, engaging real-world activities, and robust university resources, students will experience a world-class education recognized globally for intellectual leadership and innovation.
Logo of Wharton Pre-Baccalaureate Program featuring an open book with an emblem on it, encircled by program name text.
Program Highlights
Earn college credits from any time zone with flexible online courses
Learn directly from Wharton instructors through weekly live class meetings
Explore business topics not available at the high school level
Gain insight into the college academic experience
Access university learning resources and academic advising
Forge friendships and network with diverse peers from around the globe
Prepare for the challenges of highly selective colleges
Accrue additional credits by enrolling again
Pre-baccalaureate courses are selected from across Wharton’s academic departments and are designed to instill a deep understanding of how business works. Courses are offered at the introductory level and convey the rigor and relevance of a Wharton undergraduate education.

Each course varies in specifics, though all courses include live, weekly class meetings offered on a synchronous basis. During live classes, students will participate in instructor-led lectures and course discussions. Additionally, live meetings may include business simulations, case studies, group projects, or individual assignments. Courses also incorporate some level of asynchronous content, which may include pre-recorded faculty lectures, readings, or assignments.

SMALL CLASS ENVIRONMENT

Courses are made up entirely of high school students in the Pre-baccalaureate Program. All courses are taught by Wharton instructors and class sizes are small to facilitate student engagement and foster dynamic conversations.

UNDERGRADUATE-LEVEL ASSESSMENT

Pre-baccalaureate students are graded on attendance and course participation, quality of assignments, and formal assessments such as quizzes, midterms, and final papers or exams. Attendance at live class meetings is mandatory, as is the completion of all assigned coursework.

Each student is initially registered to receive a traditional letter grade (A–F) for coursework. Upon consultation with an academic advisor, and in accordance with academic policies and deadlines, students may change to a Pass/Fail grading status if deemed necessary.

COLLEGE CREDITS

Upon successful completion of the program and all included therein, Pre-baccalaureate students will generate official University of Pennsylvania/Wharton transcripts outlining courses completed, grades earned, and college credits received, which are transferable to most universities and colleges.

Each Wharton Pre-baccalaureate course awards 0.5 University of Pennsylvania course units, which is equivalent to 2 college credits at most post-secondary institutions. Students may enroll in a maximum of two courses per session, and may continue to enroll in courses and earn credits in subsequent sessions until they graduate from high school, as long as they maintain good academic standing.

ACADEMIC SUPPORT

To assist in academic studies, Pre-baccalaureate students are granted access to university learning resources, including research catalogs, library services, instructor office hours, and academic advising.

Every student is assigned an academic advisor upon admission. This individual will serve as the student’s primary program contact and will assist students in navigating university resources, adhering to academic policies and deadlines, and identifying suitable courses. All students will receive an introductory email from their advisor prior to the start of the program and will be invited to attend an introductory advising session, as well as new student orientation, via video conference. Students can feel free to meet with their advisors as often as needed.
enhanced_description: The Wharton Pre-baccalaureate Program provides high school juniors and seniors with the opportunity to earn college credits by enrolling in introductory business courses taught by Wharton instructors. These online courses combine mandatory weekly synchronous meetings with asynchronous content, featuring small class sizes designed to foster engagement through lectures, business simulations, and group projects. Students can earn 0.5 University of Pennsylvania course units per course—equivalent to two college credits—which are documented on an official transcript and transferable to most post-secondary institutions. Academic performance is evaluated through participation, assignments, and formal exams, with students receiving additional support through assigned academic advisors and access to university resources such as library services and research catalogs.

title: Youth Science Camp
subtitle: NYSCamp
raw_text: Hosted in Monongahela National Forest in West Virginia since 1963, the National Youth Science Camp (NYSCamp) is a residential science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics (STEAM) program designed to honor and challenge some of the nation’s rising leaders and provide them with opportunities to engage with STEAM professionals and participate in exciting outdoor activities. Typically, two delegates are selected to attend camp from each state and the District of Columbia. In partnership with the U.S. State Department, we also host international delegates. Past countries represented include Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Germany, Japan, Mexico, and Trinidad and Tobago. Housing, meals, transportation, and supplies are provided to participants at no cost.

title: Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory
subtitle: Lamont Summer High School Opportunities
raw_text: This summer program offers high school students the chance to engage in hands-on research at the Hudson River Field Station. Participants will work alongside scientists and gain valuable experience in environmental science and ecology through fieldwork and laboratory activities.

title: Trapped Ions and Photonics Research
subtitle: UMass
raw_text: Our competitive Research Intensives program places high-achieving high school students in professional working labs alongside distinguished faculty, graduate and undergraduate students. The UMass⁺ Ion lab microfabricates chips in the UMass cleanrooms for trapped ion quantum computing. We then trap ions on our chips and study their performance as qubits by measuring their qubit gate fidelity towards building a scalable quantum computer.

title: Summer Sessions
subtitle: UCB
raw_text: Berkeley Summer Sessions is open to a wide variety of students including UC Berkeley degree-seeking students, students from other UC campuses, visiting students from around the U.S. and the world as well as the general public.

title: IAS Computes
subtitle: Stony Brook
raw_text: The Institute for Advanced Computational Science at Stony Brook University is offering a 10-day ONLINE programming workshop for high school students who will be juniors or seniors in the fall of 2020. Students must be 15 years old or older by the time of the camp. This hands-on camp introduces students to the programming skills and software/computer technologies that drive advances in science, industry, business and society. Starting with no assumed prior knowledge of programming, the camp introduces programming using the Python language and emphasizes development of algorithmic thinking and problem solving. From faculty and graduate students, participants will learn about using big-data analytics and high-performance computing to solve problems in science and engineering, and will then participate in team projects motivated by these same research challenges. By the end of the camp, students will have sufficient programming skills and awareness of the field to pursue further independent study and to inform future choices for education and careers. Ideally students will use their own laptops (Macs, PCs or Linux are acceptable; a few are available for loan) so they can continue to use the camp's open-source software programming environment and tools.

title: SCUBA Summer Coding
subtitle: UChicago
raw_text: This 6-week summer program combines design thinking, analytical problem solving, and mentorship with Python programming for a well-rounded interdisciplinary experience.  Incoming students need not arrive with any of the above skills to apply or be considered for the program. We are looking for students with diverse lived experiences, backgrounds, and interests. We are looking for students who are excited to learn something new and use their creativity and innovative spirit to create something meaningful.

title: Global Youth Program - Financial Decision Making
subtitle: University of Pennsylvania Wharton
raw_text:
High school students face daily financial choices. From deciding between a $6 cup of Starbucks coffee or saving for a new pair of Air Jordans, to contemplating whether to invest in an ad-free YouTube subscription, the decisions they make can impact their financial well-being. They must also begin to understand the more sophisticated financial landscape to empower them to grow and manage their wealth throughout their lifetime. Uninformed decisions can often lead to financial setbacks.

By delving into the basics of economics and fundamental financial principles, students will develop a robust understanding of financial concepts and navigate the complexities of the financial world confidently. They will engage with real-world datasets and practical examples, building their analytical skills and decision-making abilities.

Financial Decision Making uses a curriculum developed by Wharton Professor David Musto who is an expert in capital markets and strategic equity finance. Over the course of the program, students will build a strong foundation in personal and corporate finance while developing analytical skills to make smarter financial decisions. Students will learn and practice using Excel throughout the program.

Key themes include: 

Personal Finance Foundations 
Budgeting, saving, and spending trade-offs
Understanding credit, debt, and interest rates
Building good financial habits and avoiding common pitfalls 
Introduction to Financial Markets
What are stocks, bonds, and mutual funds?
How markets function and why they matter 
Risk vs. return: making informed investment choices 
Money, Banking, and the Economy 
The role of banks and central banks 
How monetary policy impacts borrowing, spending, and investing
Understanding inflation, interest rates, and economic cycles
Decision-Making with Data
Using real-world financial datasets to analyze trends 
Applying basic quantitative tools to evaluate options 
Case studies on how data informs investment strategies 
Wealth Building and Management
The power of compound interest and long-term investing 
Diversification: spreading risk across assets 
Planning for major life goals (college, career, retirement)
Financial Ethics and Responsibility
Understanding trade-offs between profit and social impact
The role of finance in addressing global challenges 
Ethical dilemmas in personal and corporate finance 
By the end of the program, students will not only understand financial concepts, but also be able to analyze real situations, weigh options, and communicate financial decisions effectively—skills that will serve them for life.
enhanced_description: The Financial Decision Making program for high school students utilizes a curriculum developed by Wharton Professor David Musto to help participants build a strong foundation in both personal and corporate finance. Throughout the course, students develop critical analytical skills and practical decision-making abilities by engaging with real-world datasets and learning to use Excel for quantitative analysis. The comprehensive curriculum covers essential themes such as budgeting, credit, and debt, while also exploring the mechanics of financial markets, the role of central banks, and strategies for long-term wealth management through diversification and compound interest. By examining financial ethics and various case studies, participants learn to analyze complex situations and communicate financial decisions effectively, preparing them to navigate the financial landscape with confidence.

title: Summer Research Scholars Program
subtitle: Lillehei Heart Institute
raw_text: With the assistance of a grant from the AHA, the Lillehei Heart Institute offers annual summer research scholarships in basic science research related to cardiovascular disease. These highly competitive, prestigious scholarships are designed to expose highly qualified students to several disciplines within cardiovascular disease research and its clinical applications. Each scholar will be supported by a research scholarship. The major focus will be intensive basic or clinical research as each scholar will be assigned a laboratory and a faculty mentor. In addition, scholars will be introduced to clinical, industrial, and academic medicine through a variety of field trips, seminars and hands on experiences. Weekly seminars by faculty and industry leaders will be given to offer the scholar a window into career opportunities in cardiovascular science and medicine. The goal of these scholarships is to encourage medical and scientific careers in Cardiovascular Medicine.

title: Secondary School
subtitle: Harvard
raw_text: Harvard Summer School’s Secondary School Program (SSP) is a 4- or 7-week academic program for motivated high school students ready to excel in academically rigorous college courses for college credit.

title: College-Bound STEM Academy
subtitle: PSU
raw_text: Penn State Abington and KleinLife have partnered to provide a STEM-based high school enrichment program for KleinLife families and neighborhood high school students. This collaborative effort aims to enhance educational opportunities and outcomes for high school students in the Northeast Philadelphia community.

title: Wharton Global High School Investment Competition
subtitle: University of Pennsylvania Wharton
raw_text:
The Wharton Global High School Investment Competition is a free, experiential investment challenge for high school students (9th to 12th grade) and teachers. Students work in teams of four to six, guided by a teacher as their advisor, and have access to an online stock market simulator. Together, they learn about strategy-building, teamwork, communication, risk, diversification, company and industry analysis, and many other aspects of investing.

Teams examine a short case study featuring a potential client (a real Wharton graduate working in business) and are tasked with collaborating to meet that client’s long-term investment goals as they try to win his or her business. Equipped with the Wharton Investment Simulator (WInS), which allows them to buy and sell stocks and ETFs, over the course of 10 weeks students develop an investment strategy, analyze industries and companies, and build a portfolio using $500,000 in virtual cash. Winners are selected on the strength and articulation of their team strategies, not on the growth of their portfolios, which is a key differentiator between this investment challenge and others. During the competition each team submits two deliverables.

Final reports are reviewed by a team of judges, who select 50 semifinalist teams. Those teams are invited to present their strategies to a panel of expert judges at the virtual Semifinals. The top 10 teams from the Semifinals move on to the Global Finale at Wharton in Philadelphia.
enhanced_description: The Wharton Global High School Investment Competition is a free, experiential challenge designed for students in grades 9 through 12 and their teacher advisors. Working in teams of four to six, participants use the Wharton Investment Simulator to manage a $500,000 virtual portfolio of stocks and ETFs while developing a strategy to meet the long-term goals of a specific case-study client. Over a 10-week period, students focus on industry analysis, risk management, and teamwork to produce two required deliverables. Unlike many other challenges, winners are selected based on the strength and articulation of their investment strategies rather than portfolio growth. The competition progresses through a review process where 50 semifinalist teams are chosen to present their strategies, ultimately leading to a global finale for the top 10 teams.

title: ICaRE Summer Science
subtitle: OldWestBury
raw_text: The Summer Science Program offered by the ICaRE (Institute of Cancer Research and Education) at SUNY Old Westbury provides High School students with an opportunity to learn molecular biology of cancer, cell biology, cancer immunology, biochemistry, neuroscience and microbiology under the mentorship of Faculty. Students will learn how laboratory science can be translated to improved human health and will engage in investigative experiences. Our program gives students the opportunity to: 1. Understand the process of the scientific method 2. Apply knowledge to a real world problem and gain research skills 3. Learn key laboratory methodologies 4. Learn critical reading of peer-reviewed literature on an unknown topic. 5. Gain experience presenting scientific work through writing and oral presentation 6. Have fun learning about the science!

title: University of Delaware
subtitle: College Readiness Scholars Institute
raw_text: The College Readiness Scholars Institute is designed for high school students to enhance their academic skills and prepare for college. Participants engage in interactive workshops and activities that focus on college readiness including study skills time management and effective communication to ensure a successful transition to higher education.

title: Pre-Collegiate
subtitle: Stanford
raw_text: Stanford Pre-Collegiate Studies advances the education of intellectually passionate pre-college students. We offer a variety of programs designed to meet the needs of students everywhere.

title: UH
subtitle: Summer Discovery
raw_text: This program offers high school students an opportunity to explore architecture through hands-on projects and studio work. Participants will engage in design challenges and learn about the architectural process from experienced faculty. The program aims to inspire creativity and critical thinking in aspiring architects.

title: Clinical Anatomy
subtitle: Stanford CASP
raw_text: The Clinical Anatomy Summer Program (CASP) at Stanford University is for high school students considering careers in medical and health-related fields, such as medicine, surgery, dentistry, EMT/paramedics, nursing, biomedical engineering, occupational therapy, physical therapy, sports medicine, and medical education.  This in-person, week-long course will introduce students to the anatomy of the human body. Students will attend lectures given by Stanford Medicine faculty, engage in hands-on anatomy lab activities, observe surgical demonstrations, and attend workshops with Stanford physicians. Further information on CASP curriculum can be found here.

title: Art Museum Summer Academy
subtitle: Princeton
raw_text: Join us for a three-week program designed to provide high school students from Trenton Central and Ewing High Schools with the opportunity to learn about careers in art museums and the visual arts while working with mentors, artists, and professionals from Princeton University and the surrounding region. Students will explore themes related to identity, power, and social justice through close engagement with original works of art. The program will culminate in a capstone project providing students the opportunity to create a work of art, poem, musical piece, or other creative expression, which will be exhibited or shared during a closing celebration.

title: Summer Session
subtitle: UNC
raw_text: he University of North Carolina (UNC) offers summer programs for high school students to explore academic interests and gain college experience. Programs include pre-college courses, academic enrichment, leadership development, and career exploration. Students can earn college credit, develop new skills, and engage in hands-on learning. Each program has specific application requirements and deadlines. For more details, visit the UNC Summer Programs website.

title: Brown University
subtitle: Brown Experiential Education Barcelona
raw_text: This program offers high school students the chance to explore Barcelona while engaging in experiential learning. Participants will immerse themselves in the local culture and history while developing critical thinking and problem-solving skills through hands-on projects and activities in a vibrant city setting.

title: Essay Competition
subtitle: Immerse Education
raw_text: The Immerse Education Essay Competition gives students aged 13–18 the chance to submit an essay on a question that sparks their interest. Each year, we refresh our list of questions to encourage students to explore their favourite subjects in greater depth. With more than twenty options available in our Essay Competition Guide, there’s plenty to choose from. Ten winners will receive a full scholarship to study with us at a world-leading university of their choice, and outstanding runners-up will also be awarded partial scholarships.
enhanced_description: The Immerse Education Essay Competition provides students aged 13 to 18 with the opportunity to explore their favorite subjects in depth by submitting an essay based on a variety of academic prompts. Participants can choose from over twenty different subject options listed in the official Essay Competition Guide, which is updated annually to include fresh questions that spark intellectual curiosity. Successful entrants have the chance to win prestigious prizes, including ten full scholarships to study at a world-leading university for top winners and partial scholarships for outstanding runners-up.

title: GENIUS Olympiad
subtitle: Genius
raw_text: The Genius Olympiad is an international competition that encourages high school students to develop innovative projects addressing global challenges. Participants work on projects related to environmental sustainability, social issues, and scientific advancements. The competition provides opportunities for students to present their ideas and solutions on a global stage. Genius Olympiad aims to inspire and support young innovators in making a positive impact on the world. Winners receive recognition and prizes for their contributions to solving global problems.

title: RITMS Research Program
subtitle: Rutgers
raw_text: The RITM Summer Research Program at Rutgers University provides high school students with the opportunity to engage in biomedical research. Participants work on research projects in labs under the guidance of experienced scientists and researchers. The program includes hands-on lab work, seminars, and presentations, offering students practical experience in scientific research. It aims to inspire interest in biomedical sciences and prepare students for future academic and career pursuits. The RITM program provides a comprehensive introduction to research in a professional setting.

title: Aspiring Scholars Directed Research Program (ASDRP)
subtitle: Aspiring Scholars Directed Research Program (ASDRP)
raw_text:
The Aspiring Scholars Directed Research Program (ASDRP) is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit research & development (R&D) institution that provides opportunities for high school students throughout the Bay Area, especially those who are underrepresented in STEM or who are socioeconomically disadvantaged, to conduct high-level novel scientific research. As the premier precollegiate research establishment in the Bay Area, ASDRP is committed to both producing state-of-the-art research year round, and serving the diverse community in which we are located.
Students participate in research projects across various subjects in STEM, including chemistry, biology, computational modeling, computer science, and much more. Students publish and present their work as well in venues within and outside of ASDRP. Research in ASDRP is supervised by highly skilled scientists  and engineers on the research faculty, who are clustered under one of three departments - Biological/Human/Life Sciences, Chemistry/Biochemistry/Physics, or Computer Science & Engineering. Click on the Research tab above to learn more about each department. We function much like any other research establishment in industry or in academia: we pursue challenging and novel research questions, we make discoveries, and we publish papers and present work at conferences.  But there's one catch - the science is in the hands of high school students. 
ASDRP provides students with research mentors and over $4M worth of research equipment in our research laboratory (for more information, please see our Facilities page). Students are matched with research mentors who have experience in academia or industry in their particular field; together, they design a research project. These projects are not science experiments in which the results are known a priori, but rather are original research projects that expand current scientific knowledge. Students execute research projects, learn scientific reading and writing skills, write research papers on their results, undergo mock peer-review, publish their research papers in the ASDRP Communications online journal, and give poster presentations at the end-of-summer expo. Students additionally publish and present their work in peer-reviewed journals and conferences. We follow up with students from ASDRP to help place them into university research laboratories and industry internships in subsequent summers. The inaugural cohort of ASDRP started in summer 2018.
​
We invite you to read more about our facilities and program model throughout this website. You can access student research papers on the Journal page, peruse the various projects and disciplines in which students conduct research, learn more about our facilities, and more.
 
ASDRP is a translatable model for increasing interest in, and exposure to, novel scientific research among high school students, especially those who are underrepresented in STEM. ASDRP is a production of Olive Children Foundation, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization in Fremont, CA.
​
enhanced_description: The Aspiring Scholars Directed Research Program (ASDRP) is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit research and development institution that provides high school students, particularly those underrepresented in STEM, with opportunities to conduct high-level novel scientific research. Participants are matched with experienced research mentors from academia and industry to design and execute original projects across disciplines such as biology, chemistry, physics, and computer science. Utilizing over $4M in advanced laboratory equipment, students develop scientific reading and writing skills, undergo mock peer-reviews, and publish their findings in the ASDRP Communications journal or external peer-reviewed publications. The program also supports students in securing university research placements and industry internships by providing hands-on experience in presenting work at conferences and professional expos.

title: Ewgis Program
subtitle: GiS
raw_text: Embark on a scientific quest, diving deep into the realms of ground-breaking research. Unleash your curiosity, work side by side with seasoned mentors, and contribute to the ever-expanding universe of knowledge. OR Become a STEM trailblazer by choosing the project-oriented path. Tackle real-world challenges in your local community, apply your STEM skills creatively, and make a tangible impact where it matters most.

title: Arizona Cancer Center
subtitle: High School Students and Teachers Program
raw_text: This program offers high school students and teachers the opportunity to engage in hands-on cancer research experiences. Participants will work alongside researchers gain insights into cancer biology and treatment. It aims to inspire future careers in science and medicine through direct exposure to research.

title: Pre-college Online Program - Business
subtitle: Northwestern University
raw_text:
In this course, you’ll explore the fundamentals of business strategy, marketing, sales, operations, and more. Through real-world examples and expert insights, you’ll learn how companies develop products, reach their customers, and deliver value efficiently. You’ll apply your learning in a final project where you analyze a well-known company and propose a new product or service idea aligned with its goals and market. Whether you're curious about business or considering it as a future path, this course will give you a practical foundation to build on.


APPLY TO BUSINESS
PROGRAM DATES

Choose the course length that works for you: 2-week and 4-week sessions
ELIGIBILITY

For students ages 13 and up
INDIVIDUAL COURSE FEES

$1,895
From Idea to Execution

DISCOVER THE FOUNDATION OF BUSINESS

Ascertain what business is, how companies are structured, how businesses maintain success, and the skills required to become a dynamic business leader across all verticals.
DETERMINE WHAT TO SELL—AND HOW

Understand the fundamental concepts of product development and product management. Review how product ideas are developed and managed all the way to launch.
DRIVING SUCCESS THROUGH STRATEGY

Review the fundamental elements of business strategy and learn how they drive successful businesses. Enhance your strategic and analytical lens to address real-world strategic problems.
GO INSIDE MARKETING & SALES

Once you’ve decided what consumers want, how do you ensure a strong product-market fit and alignment with your overall business strategy? Discover how to effectively sell products to customers.
UNDERSTAND BUSINESS OPERATIONS AND ITS MOVING PIECES 

Discover the critical role that operations and supply chain management play. Explore the functions that they fulfill, and how products are sourced, procured, manufactured, and distributed.
COURSE CONCLUSION & FINAL CAPSTONE PROJECT

Step into the role of a business strategist, crafting a presentation that analyzes a real company's product. Unpack its strengths, weaknesses, target audience, and marketing mix to pitch your strategic vision.
Northwestern pre-college online student
How You Will Benefit

Ascertain what business is, how companies are structured, how businesses maintain success.
Understand the fundamental concepts of product development and product management. 
Identify how businesses market and sell products according to their larger business strategy.
Complete a Final Capstone Project to demonstrate what you’ve learned.
Earn a Certificate of Completion from Northwestern University.
enhanced_description: This Northwestern University pre-college online course, titled "From Idea to Execution," is designed for students ages 13 and up who are interested in exploring the foundations of business strategy, marketing, and operations. Participants examine how companies are structured, how products are developed and managed from launch to distribution, and how supply chain management and sales strategies drive organizational success. Throughout the program, students apply expert insights to real-world problems, culminating in a final capstone project where they analyze a well-known company and pitch a strategic vision for a new product or service. Available in both two-week and four-week session lengths for a fee of $1,895, the course concludes with a Certificate of Completion to recognize the student's practical understanding of business leadership across various verticals.

title: UCSB
subtitle: Academic Affairs Student Internship Program
raw_text: The Academic Affairs Student Internship Program at UCSB offers students hands-on experience in academic administration and policy development. Interns will work closely with faculty and staff on various projects enhancing their understanding of university operations and academic affairs.

title: Engineering, Math and Science Camp
subtitle: UPENN
raw_text: Penn GEMS is a week-long day camp targeting middle school students in 7th, 8th, and 9th grade that focuses on bioengineering, nanotechnology, materials science, graphics and computing. The Penn GEMS Summer Camp is dedicated to providing hands-on activities to engage middle school students in applied science, technology and engineering.

title: UTEP
subtitle: Project ACE
raw_text: Project ACE is a summer program designed for high school students interested in the arts and humanities. Participants engage in interactive workshops and activities that foster creativity and critical thinking skills while exploring various artistic disciplines.

title: UCA Cheer Camp
subtitle: UTA
raw_text: The University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) offers a variety of summer camps for high school students through its Youth Program. These camps cover a range of subjects, including science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), as well as arts and leadership. Participants engage in hands-on activities, workshops, and projects designed to enhance their skills and knowledge in their chosen fields. The programs aim to provide enriching educational experiences and help students explore potential career paths. UTA's summer camps offer opportunities for academic growth and personal development in a supportive environment.

title: Foreign Policy Academy
subtitle: Georgetown University HOYA Summer High School Sessions
raw_text:
Combining lectures, talks by policymakers, visits to a number of foreign Embassies, crisis simulations, and group discussions, Georgetown's Foreign Policy Academy introduces you to the many components that inform and create U.S. foreign policy. Throughout your time in the program, you'll develop your critical thinking and interpretive skills while examining key international crises and world leaders' responses and policy choices in a global arena. You'll also analyze the factors that affect the decision-making process and the theories and methods used to formulate and implement policies.

By the time you complete the program, you'll have a deeper understanding of American foreign and defense policy, the complexities of terrorism threats, the influence of non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and think tanks, strategies for aid and democracy-building, and the underpinnings of foreign commerce and trade policies.

As a student in the Foreign Policy Academy, you'll spend your time engaged in a combination of class sessions, field trips, hands-on workshops, group discussions, and extracurricular activities. Throughout the program, you'll have the opportunity to explore the following subject areas:

Theoretical frameworks of foreign policy formulation
State and USAID Policy
Think tanks and NGO Influence
Second-track diplomacy
Counter-intelligence and terrorism
World conflicts
International political economy and trade policy
Religion and foreign policy
Careers in foreign policy
enhanced_description: Georgetown's Foreign Policy Academy provides an immersive introduction to the formulation and implementation of U.S. foreign policy through a blend of lectures, policymaker talks, and embassy visits. Participants engage in crisis simulations, hands-on workshops, and group discussions designed to sharpen critical thinking and interpretive skills while analyzing the decision-making processes of world leaders during international crises. The comprehensive curriculum covers a broad range of critical subjects, including theoretical frameworks, defense policy, counter-intelligence, and the influence of NGOs and think tanks on global affairs. Students also explore international political economy, second-track diplomacy, and strategies for democracy-building, ultimately gaining valuable insight into diverse career paths within the field of foreign policy.

title: Leadership Project
subtitle: Sadie Nash
raw_text: Summer Institute is an award-winning 6-week summer program where participants explore their own leadership skills and build a strong community with other Nashers…because at Sadie Nash we believe that all young women and gender-expansive youth are leaders NOW!

title: Summer STEM Program
subtitle: Amherst
raw_text: The STEM Incubator is a cohort-based summer research program specifically developed at Amherst College in 2019 to educate and mentor first-generation or low-income students without previous STEM research experience.

title: Pre-College
subtitle: Barnard
raw_text: Experience Summer in New York City at Barnard. With distinct programs to choose from, ranging from entrepreneurship to STEM, you have the unique opportunity to explore an area of interest on a deeper level through both in-class discussions and city exploration. As part of the learning experience at Barnard, you will get a taste of both college life and the city that never sleeps!

title: Biotechnology Intern
subtitle: IALR
raw_text: The Institute for Advanced Learning and Research (IALR) offers an annual summer internship program to provide meaningful on-the-job training. The internship program provides real-world leadership development experiences in diverse career fields such as research and data analysis, public relations, human resources, AgTech research, coding and robotics, information technology and more. Candidates for IALR internships must be: a high school graduate with plans to attend college in fall of 2024; an undergraduate or graduate level college student; OR a recent college graduate, within the last 12 months.

title: Blum Center at UCI
subtitle: Summer Scholars Program
raw_text: The Summer Scholars Program at the Blum Center provides high school students with an opportunity to engage in research related to social issues. Participants will work alongside faculty mentors develop critical thinking skills and gain hands-on experience in addressing real-world challenges.

title: TRIO Pre-College
subtitle: UCR
raw_text: UC Riverside's TRIO Pre-College programs motivate, encourage and equip low-income and potential first-generation college students as they enroll in, persist at, and graduate from a postsecondary institution. Available to students of select Riverside and San Bernardino County high schools, TRIO program participants receive free services including academic tutoring, mentorship, financial guidance, application assistance and fun enrichment activities that improve educational access and retention.

title: High School Law Institute
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: Explore topics and build foundational knowledge about the U.S. legal system at NYU! The New York University High School Law Institute (HSLI) is a student-run organization that serves talented and motivated high school students throughout New York City. HSLI is a free program that offers courses in constitutional law, criminal law, and speech and debate. Classes are conducted on Saturdays, from 10 AM - 1 PM throughout the academic year. Courses are taught by teams of current NYU Law and undergraduate students who are trained and supported by NYU Law faculty. Students participate in discussion-based classes and complete assignments that are tailored to their interests. At HSLI, students are encouraged to think critically, advocate well, and work collaboratively; they are also taught to evaluate arguments based on analytical rigor and strength of evidence.

title: UAB
subtitle: UAB Summer Scholars Institute
raw_text: The UAB Summer Scholars Institute offers high school students an immersive experience in STEM fields through hands-on learning and mentorship. Participants engage in various activities designed to enhance their understanding of scientific principles and explore potential career paths in health and research.

title: Software Engineering Internship
subtitle: Think Neuro
raw_text:
The ThinkNeuro Software Engineering Internship Experience (SEIE) is a fully remote, project-based engineering program for ambitious high school and undergraduate students. Interns learn essential software engineering skills including Git version control, collaborative development workflows, portfolio creation, and real-world software project execution.

The SEIE curriculum is designed with guidance from engineers at Apple, Uber, Meta, NASA, and GitHub, ensuring alignment with modern industry standards and internship expectations.
Students complete the program with:

A hosted personal portfolio website
A GitHub profile showcasing professional-quality commits and repositories
Completion of a real team-based software engineering project
A certificate recognizing internship - level engineering training
A final demo-day video presentation and polished project README
Hands-on experience using Git, GitHub Issues, Projects, and Pull Requests - mirroring real internship workflows
Workshops are developed by engineers from top institutions, while office hours and team support are provided by ThinkNeuro instructors and project managers who guide students through portfolio building, debugging, and completing all project deliverables.
What you will learn
Git & Engineering Foundations

Git basics: clone, commit, push, pull
Branching, merging, and conflict resolution
Using GitHub Issues, Projects, and Pull Requests
VS Code workflows used by industry engineers
Personal Portfolio Website

Clone and customize open-source templates
Build your own personal site 
Deploy using GitHub Pages
Optimize your resume and GitHub profile
 Internship-Style Team Project

3-5 person teams
Weekly standups and progress tracking
Collaborative development using Git
Final demo day with real feedback
enhanced_description: The ThinkNeuro Software Engineering Internship Experience (SEIE) is a fully remote, project-based program designed for ambitious high school and undergraduate students to master industry-standard software engineering workflows. Developed with guidance from engineers at top institutions like Apple, Meta, and NASA, the curriculum covers essential technical skills including Git version control, VS Code workflows, and collaborative development using GitHub Issues and Pull Requests. Participants work in teams of three to five to complete a real-world software project, supported by weekly standups, workshops, and office hours led by ThinkNeuro instructors and project managers. By the end of the program, students produce a professional portfolio featuring a hosted personal website, a robust GitHub profile, and a final demo-day video presentation, all while earning a certificate recognizing their internship-level training.

title: Summer Academy
subtitle: Vanderbilt
raw_text: SA students take accelerated courses with instructors drawn from the wealth of talented scholars here at Vanderbilt University and from within the Nashville community. VSA courses are designed to be accelerated to meet the needs of gifted and high-ability students. With up to six hours a day devoted to academic learning, this program provides for a satisfying level of focus and depth. Because courses are accelerated, we ask applicants to submit eligibility materials to determine if an accelerated course would be a good academic fit for the student.

title: Summer Medical Career Program
subtitle: LAPS
raw_text: The Los Angeles Pediatric Society established the Eve and Gene Black Summer Medical Career Program in 1969 and is proud to celebrate its 55th year in 2024. The purpose of the program is to encourage high school students to choose careers in the health professions. This program is best described as a medical mentor program. Participants will attend daily online sessions with presentations/interactive sessions from a variety of general pediatricians, specialists, including surgeons, nurses, pharmacists, dietitians, infectious disease, ophthalmologists, radiologists, child life, and  therapists, (i.e., physical, speech, occupational, or cognitive).

Academic Connections

Expand and cultivate your academic skills as a motivated and independent individual preparing for college.

PROGRAM OVERVIEW
Academic Connections Summer 2026 Information will become available January 2026. 

Managed by the Division of Extended Studies, UC San Diego Academic Connections is committed to providing a pre-college summer experience that is academically and socially enriching to high-achieving, college-bound high school students motivated to explore the offerings of UC San Diego – a top five, internationally ranked public institution. The program aims to help young people engage with the future by exposing them to some of the most exciting fields of research and study. Participants will work with committed and enthusiastic instructors to examine the world around them as inquisitive academic scholars. 

 

We would love to keep in touch! Sign up for our Academic Connections Summer 2026 Contact Form to be updated about program information for Summer 2026 by visiting the link here: Academic Connections Summer 2026 Contact Form.
