enhanced_description: The Actuarial Science Camp at Lebanon Valley College is a week-long intensive program designed for rising high school seniors to explore the actuarial profession through interaction with industry experts and exposure to relevant software. This long-standing program emphasizes a blend of mathematical coursework, programming, and communication skills, providing students with an authentic look at the field through practical experience and peer presentations. Prospective attendees must complete an application form and provide a one-page letter of recommendation from a high school math teacher emailed directly to the program director. By leveraging extensive industry connections and alumni insights, the camp helps students determine their interest in actuarial careers while building foundational professional skills.

title: Yale University
subtitle: Summer Enrichment Research Experience
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in clinical research at Yale. Participants will work closely with faculty mentors develop research skills and gain hands-on experience in the medical field. The program aims to inspire future careers in medicine and research.

title: Summer Session
subtitle: UMaine
raw_text: The University of Maine's Early College summer program allows high school students to earn college credits by taking courses during the summer. It offers a range of classes both in-person and online, providing students with an opportunity to explore academic interests and get a head start on their college education. The program is designed to be flexible to accommodate different schedules and interests. Students can benefit from the experience of college-level coursework while still in high school. For specific course details and registration information, students should visit the Early College summer courses page.

title: Pre-college Online Program - Business of Sports
subtitle: Northwestern University
raw_text:
Ready to discover the business moves that drive championship teams to success? In this course, you’ll learn how professional sports teams operate behind the scenes, from player evaluation and scouting to front office decision-making. Uncover how data analytics and technology are transforming talent development and game strategies; explore revenue generation, sponsorship deals, and market expansion. Understand the full spectrum of how sports organizations thrive, and create your own strategy for a new expansion team.


APPLY TO BUSINESS OF SPORTS
PROGRAM DATES

Choose the course length that works for you: 2-week and 4-week sessions
ELIGIBILITY

For students ages 13 and up
INDIVIDUAL COURSE FEES

$1,895
Discover the Business Behind Sports

INSIDE THE FRONT OFFICE: TEAMS AND TACTICS

Explore the split between business and sports operations, and learn how data-driven strategies shape modern front office decision-making and team success.
SCOUTING AND ANALYTICS: BUILDING A WINNING ROSTER

Master player evaluation techniques, analyze scouting tools, and understand how data and technology drive recruitment and roster decisions across pro sports.
REVENUE PLAYBOOK: MAXIMIZING IN-STADIUM EXPERIENCE

Discover how teams generate revenue through ticket sales, concessions, and corporate sponsorships, while learning how fan engagement drives business success.
THE FUTURE OF WOMEN'S SPORTS LEAGUES

Explore the growth and challenges of women’s professional sports, focusing on revenue, investment opportunities, and strategies for expanding fan bases and media coverage.
EXPANSION AND OWNERSHIP: NEW TEAMS, BIG DECISIONS

Learn the fundamentals of sports ownership and team expansion, examining key factors like market share, league health, and long-term team profitability.
BUILD YOUR DREAM TEAM

Apply course concepts to create your own expansion franchise. From scouting to business operations, design a winning strategy for your team’s success.
Northwestern pre-college online student
How You Will Benefit

Gain insight into how professional sports teams operate through real-world examples and expert guest speakers.
Understand the latest industry trends and innovations shaping the sports industry.
Sharpen your analytical skills and master the use of data and technology in decision-making processes for scouting, player development, and front office strategies.
Explore the diverse career opportunities within sports organizations, including business operations, sports science, and analytics, opening doors to various career paths in sports.
Complete a Final Capstone Project to demonstrate what you’ve learned.
Earn a Certificate of Completion from Northwestern University.
enhanced_description: The Business of Sports is a pre-college program designed for students ages 13 and up that explores the internal operations of professional sports organizations, including front office decision-making, scouting, and player evaluation. Participants delve into how data analytics and technology drive talent development while also examining revenue streams such as sponsorship deals, ticket sales, and the growth of women’s professional leagues. Available in two-week or four-week sessions for a fee of $1,895, the course features expert guest speakers and culminates in a final capstone project where students design their own expansion franchise strategy. Upon finishing the curriculum, students earn a Certificate of Completion from Northwestern University and gain a comprehensive understanding of career paths in sports science, analytics, and business operations.

title: Visiting Owls
subtitle: Rice
raw_text: The Visiting Owls program at Rice University offers a variety of summer courses for high school and undergraduate students, allowing them to experience college-level academics. The program includes both in-person and online course options, providing flexibility for participants. High school students can take courses for college credit, and there are opportunities to engage with Rice University's faculty and resources. International students are eligible to apply for the Visiting Owls program. For detailed information on course offerings, application procedures, and eligibility criteria, visiting the Rice University Visiting Owls program webpage is recommended.

title: Summer Internship
subtitle: Cincinnati Org
raw_text: The High School Summer Internship Program at Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center is an eight-week program in which graduating high school seniors work 20 hours per week with a mentor in one of multiple pediatric specialties. This internship is a paid, part-time position for Cincinnati-area graduating high school seniors only. The program is very competitive, offering an exciting opportunity for highly motivated students interested in pursuing higher education (MD, PhD, or MD / PhD) to learn more about careers in Biomedical Sciences.

title: The Knowledge Society
subtitle: TKS
raw_text: TKS is a 10-month accelerator program from September 2024 to June 2025. During the program, students attend weekly 3-hour sessions with their cohort. Each cohort has ~40 students and a full-time Program Director and Associate Director that are dedicated to coaching and guiding students. During the week, students can earn access to special events like guest speakers, workshops, and conferences. We also host socials and community events for the students to make friends with others from around the world and locally.

title: Summer Academics
subtitle: Molloy
raw_text: Through these unique and exciting program opportunities, you'll participate in interactive discussions, hear from guest speakers, and engage in hands-on activities with our faculty and student ambassadors...all while earning 1 college credit. Enjoy socializing and networking with your fellow classmates during fun-filled campus events.

title: Summer Actor Training
subtitle: AADA
raw_text: The Academy’s Conservatory for Young Actors (ACYA) is a four-week summer intensive in Los Angeles for students ages 12-16. The program is taught by the same professional and encouraging instructors who oversee The Academy’s world-renowned two-year Full-Time Conservatory Program. ACYA’s mission is to provide a solid foundation for young actors who desire to strengthen their skills and develop new techniques to excel at the craft of acting. Through experiential classes and field trips, students are introduced to the concepts and practices that contribute to the work of a professional actor.

title: Space Physics Camp
subtitle: UTAUS
raw_text: The Summer Research Program at the University of Texas at Austin's College of Natural Sciences offers high school students the opportunity to engage in hands-on scientific research. Participants work closely with faculty mentors and gain practical experience in various scientific disciplines, including biology, chemistry, physics, and more. The program aims to provide students with exposure to cutting-edge research techniques and foster their interest in pursuing careers in science and engineering.

title: Communications Intern
subtitle: IALR
raw_text: The Institute for Advanced Learning and Research (IALR) offers an annual summer internship program to provide meaningful on-the-job training. The internship program provides real-world leadership development experiences in diverse career fields such as research and data analysis, public relations, human resources, AgTech research, coding and robotics, information technology and more. Candidates for IALR internships must be: a high school graduate with plans to attend college in fall of 2024; an undergraduate or graduate level college student; OR a recent college graduate, within the last 12 months.

title: NC State University
subtitle: Online Research Program for High School Students
raw_text: This online research program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in scientific research under the guidance of faculty mentors. Participants will develop research skills and gain experience in a collaborative virtual environment while exploring various STEM fields.

title: Learn What It Takes To Lead
subtitle: Georgetown
raw_text: Leadership is a vital skill that comes in many forms, even while you’re in high school. Do you want to be the leader of a team or club? What do you think your leadership style is? In this course, you’ll identify various leadership styles, explore the circumstances that call for each, practice effective leadership tools, and uncover ways to motivate others using your unique strengths. Learn to navigate challenges and hear from renowned leaders in the fields of politics, finance, research, medicine, and more.

title: BEAM Residential
subtitle: UCI x GATI
raw_text:
University-Level STEM Research & Innovation
At the heart of Southern California’s growing centers of tech, UCI x GATI Programs offer an enriching experience for gifted high school students to pursue their passion and interests in the ever-expanding fields of Biology,  Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, and Medicine (BEAM). Students learn from UC Irvine faculty and researchers through structured sessions designed to introduce them to current topics in STEM. With a diverse and multidisciplinary set of research labs, students will be immersed in fields including, but not limited to: 
 
Mechanical / Chemical Engineering
Aerospace Engineering
Anatomy 
Neurology 
Physics
Microbiology
 
In addition to developments and growth in research at the university level, students will participate in the innovative side of research. Students will be able to connect the dots and see the research process holistically by further developing:
 
Skills in collaborative group settings
Communication skills
Critical thinking skill
Entrepreneurship / Innovation


01/
High-Impact Learning Experience
Experience rich resources and facilities at UC Irvine, a leading research university in the U.S. 
Intensive schedule at BEAM allows fellows to be immersed in research and innovation experiences. 
02/
Lab Experience
Gain hands-on experience in advanced research methodologies. Under the guidance of experienced mentors and faculty, learn the fundamental techniques and process essential for cutting-edge bioengineering, and medical research. Present your research lab outcomes to panels of experts at the end of the program.
03/
Innovation
Extend your learning and ideas to innovative solutions. Go beyond lab research process and find how science and technology is impacting the real world.
04/
High-Touch Mentorship
Get matched with UC Irvine faculty-led research teams, work with ANTrepreneur (entrepreneurship) mentors, and mingle with the Visioneers who serve as invaluable role models, bridging the gap between classroom knowledge and real-world application.
enhanced_description: The UCI x GATI Programs provide gifted high school students with an intensive, university-level immersion into the fields of Biology, Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, and Medicine (BEAM). Participants engage in hands-on research across diverse disciplines, including aerospace, mechanical, and chemical engineering, as well as anatomy, neurology, physics, and microbiology. Guided by a network of faculty mentors, researchers, and entrepreneurship experts, students master advanced methodologies and fundamental techniques essential for cutting-edge bioengineering and medical research. The curriculum balances technical lab work with the development of collaborative, communication, and critical thinking skills, encouraging students to translate their scientific findings into innovative real-world solutions. This high-impact experience culminates in a formal presentation where fellows share their research outcomes with a panel of experts, effectively bridging the gap between academic knowledge and professional application.

title: Yale Young Global Scholars (YYGS)
subtitle: Yale University
raw_text:
Yale Young Global Scholars (YYGS) is an academic enrichment program for outstanding high school students from around the world. Each summer, students from over 150 countries (including all 50 U.S. states) participate in one interdisciplinary, two-week session at Yale’s historic campus. Immerse yourself in a global learning community at Yale University.\

Innovations in Science & Technology
Snapshot:
Innovations in Science & Technology (IST) is designed for students who are interested in learning about diverse topics in the STEM fields and applying scientific principles to real-world applications. Students explore a wide variety of scientific fields such as physics, molecular biology, chemistry, biochemistry, astronomy, engineering, neuroscience, immunology, psychology, and earth science. Students also are exposed to interdisciplinary applications across the many scientific fields ranging from the nanoscopic to the astronomical in scale.

Participants are challenged to examine the world as scientists as they gain exposure to a wide array of biological, physical and applied sciences topics. The session builds students’ critical thinking and analytical skills, while simultaneously stressing the importance of collaboration and teamwork, thereby training students to become more impactful scientists.

Politics of Law & Economics (PLE)
Snapshot:
Politics of Law & Economics (PLE) is a session aimed at students with an interest in understanding diverse economic theories, the values and practices of government, and legal frameworks in historical and comparative perspectives. Students learn key ideas in topics such as public policy, human rights, market regulation, governance structures, international policy, and conflict and cooperation across borders.

The session builds students’ critical thinking and analytical skills, enabling them to examine social systems and present-day issues through the lenses of economic, legal, and political theory. During PLE, students draw extensively on interdisciplinary approaches to build their expertise and increase their exposure to a wide array of topics within the session theme, preparing them to be more informed and engaged global citizens.

Solving Global Challenges (SGC)
Snapshot:
Solving Global Challenges (SGC) is designed to equip students with innovative and cross-disciplinary strategies to address the most pressing global issues of the 21st century. Guided by the United Nations’ 17 Sustainable Development Goals (link is external), the program covers a broad range of critical topics, including global health, gender equality, poverty alleviation, to environmental sustainability. SGC provides students with the tools to translate technical knowledge into effective solutions. By integrating diverse academic disciplines from STEM, social sciences, to the humanities, students develop and refine their skills in critical analysis, problem-solving, and creativity as they work towards sustainable solutions to the complex issues that will shape our future.
enhanced_description: Yale Young Global Scholars (YYGS) is an interdisciplinary academic enrichment program designed for high-achieving high school students from over 150 countries and all 50 U.S. states. Participants engage in two-week sessions that emphasize critical thinking, analytical skills, and collaborative teamwork within a global learning community. The program offers three distinct tracks: Innovations in Science & Technology, which focuses on diverse STEM fields and real-world scientific applications; Politics of Law & Economics, which examines economic theories, legal frameworks, and governance; and Solving Global Challenges, which utilizes the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals to address issues like environmental sustainability and global health through a cross-disciplinary lens. By integrating fields ranging from the humanities to the physical sciences, the program prepares students to become more impactful scientists, engaged global citizens, and innovative problem-solvers.

The primary objective is to recognize the unique characteristics of each community, fostering a deeper understanding and respect for our differences and appreciation for the commonalities that bind us together.

Priority for in-person and virtual courses goes to students from the state of Maryland. APL STEM Academy courses aim to provide an accessible, inclusive, and supportive space to learn. All learners, no matter what their gender, ethnicity, or socio-economic status, can be successful in STEM Academy courses. title: Precollege Online Program - Regenerative Medicine
subtitle: Dartmouth University
raw_text:
Dive into the groundbreaking field of regenerative medicine, where science meets innovation to repair and regenerate the human body. This course takes you through the core principles of tissue engineering, stem cell technology, and organ regeneration in modern medicine. Explore how cutting-edge tools like 3D bioprinting and biomaterials are shaping the future of healthcare. With interactive lessons and real-world case studies, you’ll gain a deep understanding of the science revolutionizing medicine today.

APPLY TO REGENERATIVE MEDICINE
PROGRAM DATES

Multi-length sessions available throughout the year
ELIGIBILITY

For students ages 13 and up
INDIVIDUAL COURSE FEES

$1,895
The Transformative World of Regenerative Medicine

THE BUILDING BLOCKS OF HEALING

Explore the core principles of regenerative medicine, like how cells form tissues and can be used to repair cellular damage.
POWERFUL CELLS, LIMITLESS POTENTIAL

Discover how stem cells and cellular therapies are revolutionizing healthcare, from tissue repair to ethical debates about their use in modern medicine.
ENGINEERING TISSUES, REDEFINING POSSIBILITIES

Dive into the science of tissue engineering, uncovering scaffold design, biomaterials, and bioactive molecules that enable regeneration and healing.
FROM LAB TO LIFE: ORGAN REGENERATION

Unravel the complexities of organ regeneration with technologies like 3D bioprinting, decellularization, and bioreactors, offering potential solutions to organ shortages and medical challenges.
BEYOND HEALTHCARE: EXPANDING REGENERATIVE FRONTIERS

Explore regenerative medicine's impact on biotechnology, personalized medicine, and beyond, including space medicine, cosmetic applications, and animal care innovations.
REGENERATION REIMAGINED: THE BIG PICTURE

Discover how regenerative medicine transforms healthcare while envisioning its future impact on science, technology, and society.
Student taking Dartmouth's precollege online regenerative medicine program
How You Will Benefit

Stay ahead by learning about the latest advancements in modern medicine like biotechnology, precision medicine, and space-related regenerative innovations.
Understand how regenerative medicine addresses critical challenges like organ shortages, tissue repair, and disease treatment through case studies and practical examples.
Master techniques and technologies used in regenerative medicine to analyze challenges like vascularization and tissue integration, preparing for real-world scientific problem-solving.
Acquire foundational knowledge in medicine, engineering, and biology that supports careers in healthcare, biotechnology, and other medical- or science-driven fields.
Complete a Final Capstone Project to demonstrate what you’ve learned.
Earn a Certificate of Completion from Dartmouth.
enhanced_description: Dartmouth’s pre-college online program in regenerative medicine offers students ages 13 and up an in-depth exploration of how science and innovation are used to repair and regenerate the human body. Participants delve into core principles such as tissue engineering, stem cell technology, and organ regeneration while examining cutting-edge tools like 3D bioprinting, biomaterials, and bioreactors. The curriculum covers a broad range of applications, from addressing organ shortages and vascularization challenges to exploring frontiers in space medicine and personalized healthcare. For a course fee of $1,895, students engage in interactive lessons and real-world case studies, ultimately completing a final capstone project to earn a Certificate of Completion.

title: Junior Doctors of Tomorrow Summer Program
subtitle: Florida International University
raw_text:
Join our Junior Doctors of Tomorrow (JDOT) Program for an immersive journey into the world of medicine. This week-long summer enrichment program offers high school students the opportunity to explore a career in health care.

Featuring hands-on clinical workshops, interactive learning sessions, and mentorship from experienced medical professionals, JDOT equips students with the knowledge, skills, and attributes needed to succeed in medicine. The program is limited to 30 students per session.

This program is made possible through the generous support of the Haitian-American Chamber of Commerce of Florida, Health Foundation of South Florida, and Primary Medical Care Center.

Please note that participants are responsible for arranging their own transportation to and from campus.

Application Requirements

500-word essay (prompt provided in application)
Letter of recommendation from teacher (preferably math or science) or guidance counselor who can verify student is in good academic standing with no history of disciplinary issues
High school transcript with most current grades and GPA
**Please note that incomplete applications will not be reviewed.
enhanced_description: The Junior Doctors of Tomorrow (JDOT) Program is a week-long summer enrichment opportunity designed for high school students to explore careers in medicine through hands-on clinical workshops, interactive learning sessions, and mentorship from experienced medical professionals. Supported by the Haitian-American Chamber of Commerce of Florida, the Health Foundation of South Florida, and the Primary Medical Care Center, the program is limited to 30 students per session and requires participants to arrange their own transportation. To apply, interested students must submit a 500-word essay, a high school transcript with current GPA, and a letter of recommendation from a teacher or counselor verifying good academic and disciplinary standing. Please note that only complete applications will be reviewed for this immersive experience aimed at equipping future healthcare leaders with necessary knowledge and skills.

title: Global Youth Program - Strategy and International Management
subtitle: University of Pennsylvania Wharton
raw_text:
Featuring interactive lectures by Wharton faculty, as well as guest speakers from the UK, this two-week program acquaints students with core concepts of management and international business. In addition, the course invites students to apply strategy and international management frameworks to relevant, contemporary business problems.   

Throughout the program, students will be asked to prepare university-level business cases that introduce a company’s management challenges and invite students to propose solutions.  

Case analysis is a key component of job selection processes for many elite companies, as well as an important method of instruction and assessment in most business schools around the world. Participants will gain a sense of how to approach case analysis and how to learn about general business theories by dissecting specific real-world cases.  

Wharton Strategy and International Management students will:  

Dive into real-world cases to understand how industries and firms compete, grow, and adapt in a global business environment.
Apply proven strategy and international management frameworks to tackle contemporary challenges faced by companies expanding across borders.
Work closely with peers in teams to solve strategy problems, engage in simulations, and practice the decision-making skills used by business leaders.
Compete in a capstone case competition, presenting your team’s strategy to a panel of expert judges and receiving feedback on your analysis and recommendations.
Learn directly from Wharton faculty, alumni, and UK-based professionals, who share insights into international business strategy and management careers.
Immerse yourself in Cambridge’s culture and business community, gaining a unique perspective on how history, culture, and location influence global business.
enhanced_description: The Wharton Strategy and International Management program is a two-week course that introduces students to core concepts of management and international business through interactive lectures led by Wharton faculty, alumni, and guest speakers. Participants dive into real-world case studies to understand how firms compete and grow globally, applying proven strategy frameworks to tackle contemporary challenges faced by companies expanding across borders. Throughout the experience, students work in teams to engage in simulations, practice executive decision-making, and prepare university-level business cases that mirror the instruction and assessment methods used in elite business schools. The program culminates in a capstone case competition where student teams present their strategic recommendations to a panel of expert judges to receive professional feedback on their analysis.

title: Forensic Investigation Academy
subtitle: Georgetown University HOYA Summer High School Sessions
raw_text:
In Georgetown's Forensic Science Academy, you'll gain a firsthand look at the world of forensic science from professionals in the field—including investigators, detectives, crime scene technicians, and pathologists. Topics covered will include crime scene diagramming, evidence collection, criminal investigative process, and video forensic analysis, to the ethical dimensions of issues faced by today’s criminal investigative professionals. Various exercises, class interaction, case studies, lectures, discussions, mock crime scene creation, and examination have been developed to provide exposure to Criminal Forensic investigation. Test your critical thinking skills by identifying and interpreting the evidence as you explore the application of science and medicine in law enforcement.

s a student in the Forensic Investigation Academy, you'll spend your day immersed in a blend of classroom lectures, field trips, hands-on activities, and group discussions. Throughout the course of the week, you'll have the opportunity to explore the following subject areas:

Crime scene analysis
Types of evidence important to criminal investigations
Criminal evidence collection
Diagramming crime scenes
Deductive reasoning in criminal investigation
Actual criminal case study
Interviewing and interrogation techniques
Ballistic forensics
Fingerprinting
Testifying in court as a forensic expert and/or detective
Blood spatter analysis
Geographic profiling
Medical examinations
Gang member investigations
Terrorism investigations
enhanced_description: Georgetown’s Forensic Science Academy offers students a comprehensive introduction to the field through direct interaction with professionals such as investigators, detectives, crime scene technicians, and pathologists. Participants engage in a dynamic learning environment that blends classroom lectures and group discussions with hands-on activities, field trips, and the creation and examination of mock crime scenes. The curriculum covers a wide array of specialized topics, including crime scene diagramming, evidence collection, ballistic forensics, fingerprinting, blood spatter analysis, and medical examinations. Students also explore complex subjects like geographic profiling, gang and terrorism investigations, and the ethical dimensions of criminal justice while practicing interviewing techniques and learning to testify as expert witnesses. By analyzing actual case studies and applying deductive reasoning, students test their critical thinking skills and explore the vital intersection of science, medicine, and law enforcement.

subtitle: NYU

 Student smiling in a lab coat and goggles
The Applied Research Innovations in Science and Engineering (ARISE) program at the NYU Tandon School of Engineering offers unparalleled opportunities for high school students to conduct real-world scientific research at a variety of NYU STEM labs. 
Under the guidance of NYU Faculty and graduate researchers, students gain valuable first-hand experience working in a lab and making practical, substantive contributions to the lab’s research objectives in exciting STEM fields, like Biomedical Engineering, Civil and Urban Engineering, Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, and more. 
Students will also receive training in presentation and public speaking skills, in collaboration with ARISE’s partners at Irondale Ensemble Project, and present their research findings at the program’s concluding colloquium to NYU faculty and graduate students, their peer ARISE participants, other academic experts, family members and friends.
ARISE is a 10-week program that takes place during the summer with four weeks of remote after school workshops in June and six weeks of in-person labs starting July 1. It is open to New York City high school students in the 10th or 11th grade. ARISE is offered as a tuition-free program through the support of the Pinkerton Foundation, with additional funding from the Depository Trust and Clearing Corporation (DTCC), and in partnership with the New York City Science Research Mentoring Consortium.
How to Apply
ARISE is intended to provide an advanced STEM research opportunity to New York City students lacking access to high quality STEM education experiences. 
Eligible applicants to ARISE will be New York City high school students currently enrolled in the 10th or 11th grade with strong academic records and demonstrated interest in STEM subjects. Students from groups historically excluded from STEM disciplines and careers are strongly encouraged to apply.
Spaces in the ARISE program are limited and admissions is selective. The application for ARISE is a multi-step process, which includes submission of the online application, a group interview, and lab tours to determine applicants’ placement in one of 32-40 labs. 
Areas of Study
Life Sciences
Life Sciences / Engineering
Computer and Data Science/Engineering
Engineering and Materials Chemistry
Engineering
Student Life
Students will spend six weeks conducting research at one of 32-40 STEM labs at New York University, reporting to their lab assignment Monday-Friday from 9 AM - 4 PM. 
During their lab placement, students will be directed in their research tasks by graduate researchers and faculty, developing technical skills and building a strong foundation for understanding the principles and best practices of conducting research in STEM. 
Students will also participate in workshops designed to improve their public speaking and leadership skills, and be able to take advantage of on-campus events and activities organized for NYU’s summer high school students.

enhanced_description: The Applied Research In Science and Engineering (ARISE) program is a selective, tuition-free summer research initiative for high school sophomores and juniors who demonstrate a strong interest in STEM subjects. Participants engage in a ten-week experience that combines remote workshops with intensive lab research, working alongside faculty and graduate mentors in diverse fields such as biomedical engineering, computer science, and materials chemistry. Beyond technical skill development, the program provides specialized training in public speaking and leadership through a partnership with the Irondale Ensemble Project, culminating in a research colloquium where students present their findings to academic experts and peers. This non-credit opportunity, which prioritizes students from groups historically excluded from STEM disciplines, involves a multi-step application process including interviews and lab tours to determine placement in one of several dozen research labs.

raw_text: The Ross Program is a 6-week intensive summer experience designed to encourage motivated pre-college students to explore mathematics. title: Branding & Marketing Program
subtitle: UVA
raw_text: s it worth spending $6 million on a 30 second Super Bowl ad? What makes you pick one thing over another in the store? How do companies communicate through distinct design choices? In this course, you will learn basic marketing principles and branding strategies. You will analyze the ways in which real companies market their products or services, and they will think deeply about brand equity and product promotion. You will learn how marketing strategies have changed and how the rise of social media has influenced branding and marketing.

title: Space Astronomy Program
subtitle: STSCI
raw_text: Each summer, the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) employs about a dozen highly motivated college students for the Space Astronomy Summer Program (SASP) to work individually with STScI researchers and staff on projects that include data reduction and interpretation, software development, software engineering, instrument calibration and support, scientific writing, and public outreach. STScI is a premier astronomical research institution, and our scientific staff of astronomers, scientists, analysts, and engineers is at the forefront of some of the most exciting astronomy going on today, including the study of our own solar system, the structure of the Milky Way, the composition of near and distant galaxies, and dark energy. Our competitive program is primarily open to upper-division undergraduates with a strong interest in space-based astronomy, engineering, or public outreach (other candidates may be considered on an individual basis). In addition to hands-on projects, students are matched with a mentor and attend a variety of lectures. Students receive a stipend, housing assistance, and travel reimbursement.

title: Stanford Program for Inspiring the Next Generation of Women in Physics (SPINWIP)
subtitle: Stanford University
raw_text:
The Stanford Program for Inspiring the Next Generation of Women in Physics (SPINWIP) is a virtual summer outreach program hosted by the Stanford Physics Department and the Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology, designed to get high-school girls excited about physics. This 3-week program is free to participants and is held through online video meetings.  First-generation students and students from underrepresented backgrounds in physics are particularly encouraged to apply. No prior knowledge of physics or coding is needed.

Students will learn about cutting-edge research in physics in fields such as quantum physics, quantum computing, astrophysics, and cosmology. They will also learn to code in Python and apply their coding skills to physics-based projects. Students will attend lectures by Stanford professors and researchers, will work in small groups led by Stanford undergraduates, and will attend college planning and career development workshops. Students will have the opportunity to form mentorship relationships with Stanford students and professors.
enhanced_description: The Stanford Program for Inspiring the Next Generation of Women in Physics (SPINWIP) is a free, three-week virtual outreach program hosted by the Stanford Physics Department and the Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology designed to engage high-school girls in the field of physics. The program specifically encourages applications from first-generation students and those from underrepresented backgrounds, requiring no prior knowledge of physics or computer programming to participate. Participants explore cutting-edge research in areas such as quantum computing and cosmology while learning to code in Python for physics-based projects. Through a combination of lectures from Stanford professors, small-group sessions led by undergraduates, and professional development workshops, students gain valuable career insights and form lasting mentorship connections within the Stanford community.

title: Engineering Virtual Summer Program
subtitle: UMD
raw_text: Join us for an exciting virtual summer experience at the A. James Clark School of Engineering! During the week, you will have an opportunity to explore the interdisciplinary principles of engineering while learning more about the eight engineering departments within the Clark School! You will participate in a variety of activities including lectures, discussions, interactive instruction and an individual and team design project. Within the network of support provided by the instructors, program advisors, and peers, you will have the opportunity to build self-confidence in applying your math, science and engineering skills.

title: PRISM High School Program
subtitle: Northwestern
raw_text: Promoting Inner-City Youth in Science and Medicine (PRISM) encourages high school students in Chicago to explore science and medicine career opportunities through mentor-guided, interactive educational activities. Started by Northwestern University Medical Scientist Training Program (MSTP) students and maintained through our collaboration with the Northwestern Science Club and the Pedersen-McCormick Boys & Girls Club, the PRISM curriculum integrates science and medicine learning and provides students with mentorship on the many paths in science and medicine that they can pursue after high school. Students also have opportunities to participate in field trips to labs and hospitals.

title: UMBC
subtitle: Summer Enrichment Academy
raw_text: The Summer Enrichment Academy at UMBC offers high school students an opportunity to explore various subjects through engaging courses. Students can enhance their skills and knowledge while experiencing college life in a supportive environment.

title: Bug Camp
subtitle: UMD
raw_text: Insects are the most abundant animals on earth! Not only are these creepy-crawlies everywhere, they provide many necessary benefits to humans and human society. Through a variety of hands-on activities and interactive field trips, Bug Camp: Insects. Science & Society will teach kids how amazing and valuable bugs truly are. Campers will gain experience with science in the field and the lab, and will come away with an understanding of the important relationship between humans and insects.

title: Pre-College
subtitle: JHU
raw_text: The Summer Programs at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies (SAIS) offer high school students a chance to explore international relations and global affairs. The programs include intensive courses and seminars on topics such as international economics, global security, and diplomacy. Participants engage in lectures, discussions, and practical exercises designed to enhance their understanding of global issues and develop critical thinking skills. The programs aim to provide a deeper insight into international studies and inspire students interested in careers in diplomacy, international development, and related fields. Overall, these summer programs offer a rigorous academic experience and exposure to the world of global affairs.

title: ARISE UWCCC Summer High School Cancer Research
subtitle: UW Madison
raw_text: Our goal is to enrich the education of 6-12 grade students from diverse backgrounds underrepresented in biomedical fields. By providing year-round science education, a diverse array of cancer focused activities to bolster skills, and community experiences, we can improve student potential to thrive in advanced degree science programs and engage in cancer health related careers.
enhanced_description: This initiative aims to support 6th through 12th-grade students from underrepresented backgrounds by providing consistent, year-round access to biomedical science education. Through a curriculum focused on specialized cancer research activities and community-building, the program strengthens the technical and academic skills necessary for success in higher education. Ultimately, it seeks to empower these students to excel in advanced degree programs and pursue leadership roles in cancer-related health careers.

title: Internship Program
subtitle: Oak Ridge NGSI
raw_text: The Next Generation STEM Internship Program (NGSI) affords rising juniors and seniors from high schools or accredited home school programs in Anderson, Blount, Knox, Loudon and Roane counties the opportunity to participate in STEM or STEM-related projects with researchers at ORNL.

title: Youth Environmental Advocacy Fellowship
subtitle: HNP Canada
raw_text:
Project Mission
Our mission is to empower youth to become advocates for environmental issues. We aim to provide participants the tools, knowledge, and platform needed to foster environmental leadership, empathy, and the possibility of successful, impactful change.
Project Description
This fellowship is a transformative program that equips students with the knowledge and skills to make a tangible impact in the lives of Canadians and other citizens within their own communities. Participants will explore the efficacies of the actions that current governments and organizations have taken for the climate crisis. In the end, participants will condense what they have learned into a report on the significance of civic involvement in environmental activism.
Project Impact
The program seeks to create lasting impact by raising awareness regarding climate catalysts, and equipping youth with the knowledge and tools to drive positive environmental change in t
enhanced_description: This fellowship is a transformative program designed to empower youth and students to become effective advocates for environmental issues through leadership development and civic engagement. Participants will analyze the efficacy of current government and organizational responses to the climate crisis while gaining the tools and knowledge necessary to drive tangible change within their local communities and across Canada. To conclude the experience, students will synthesize their learning into a formal report that examines the significance of civic involvement in environmental activism and addresses the impact of various climate catalysts.

title: Forensic Science Camp
subtitle: UVA
raw_text: In this course, we’ll uncover the secrets behind solving mysteries and crimes using forensic science. Get ready to learn how to examine crime scenes, collect evidence, and employ techniques like DNA analysis and fingerprinting! We’ll explore the history of forensic science, figure out how scientists crack cases, and even discuss the ethical side of things. Ever wondered how detectives use science to catch the bad guys? Join us to find out! Get ready for an exciting adventure into the world of forensic science, where you’ll become a crime-solving pro.

title: The Science Internship Program (SIP)
subtitle: UC Santa Cruz
raw_text: The Science Internship Program provides motivated, advanced students with a unique opportunity to work and learn at a premier research institution. SIP is a summer-long (9 week) research internship program for high school students in STEAM fields. UCSC faculty, graduate students, and post-doctoral researchers provide one-on-one mentoring of these high-school interns. The research projects are real in that they are not made up just for the high-school students; instead students are inserted into existing research projects here at UCSC.

title: TRIO Upward Bound
subtitle: UND
raw_text: Upward Bound offers students 20 weeks of individualized tutoring and instruction in core subjects during the school year. Weekly instruction occurs in after-school academic enrichment sessions on the Notre Dame campus. Sessions are organized based on grade level and individual academic needs. These sessions also utilize project-based learning to capture students’ interests—applying classroom knowledge to interesting and relevant, real-world problems. Students receive academic advising and participate in weekly workshops, which combine to supply them with the skills and information needed to prepare for, apply to, and succeed in college—including effective study skills, SAT and ACT preparation, the college admissions process, as well as financial literacy and student financial aid.

title: International Academic Competitions
subtitle: IAC
raw_text: International Academic Competitions (iAC) organizes a variety of academic competitions for high school students, focusing on intellectual development and academic excellence. Competitions include quiz bowls, academic decathlons, and specialized contests across various subjects. iAC aims to challenge students’ knowledge and problem-solving skills while fostering teamwork and collaboration. Participants have the opportunity to compete at national and international levels, showcasing their academic abilities. The organization provides a platform for students to excel and gain recognition in their areas of expertise.

title: NECHR Mentee Program
subtitle: Northeast Centre for High School Research

title: Leadership Seminars
subtitle: UND
raw_text: Leadership Seminars is a competitive, 10-day program on Notre Dame's campus for academically talented students who show impressive leadership within their communities. Approximately 100 students are admitted to Leadership Seminars each year, and students could be eligible to receive one transferable college credit upon completion of the program. Tuition, housing, and meals for students admitted to Leadership Seminars will be paid for by the University.

title: Pre-College Flute
subtitle: UIUC
raw_text: The Pre-College Flute Program at the University of Illinois offers advanced training for high school flutists. It includes private lessons, masterclasses, and performance opportunities to enhance students' technical skills and musicality. Participants receive individualized instruction from experienced faculty and engage in ensemble work to develop their collaborative skills. The program aims to prepare students for college-level music studies and professional performance. It is designed for dedicated young flutists seeking to advance their abilities and pursue a career in music.

title: Summer Stem
subtitle: USNA
raw_text: Summer STEM at the Naval Academy is a vibrant week of problem solving, exploratory learning, critical thinking, and team building for rising 9th-11th graders interested in a future in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math.

title: Missouri S&T
subtitle: Summer Camp
raw_text: This summer camp is designed for high school students interested in nuclear science and engineering. Participants will engage in hands-on activities and experiments while learning about the principles of nuclear energy. The program fosters teamwork and problem-solving skills in a fun and educational environment.

title: UTSA
subtitle: Klesse Pre-College Program
raw_text: The Klesse Pre-College Program at UTSA offers high school students an opportunity to engage in hands-on STEM activities and research experiences. Participants will work closely with faculty and graduate students to explore various scientific fields and gain valuable skills in a collaborative environment.

title: High School Programming
subtitle: Lewis & Clark
raw_text: The Bates Center for Entrepreneurship & Leadership at Lewis & Clark College is hosting its 2nd annual high school program, the Circular Innovation Challenge. It is open to all high school students, including international students, and will take place in-person July 13th - 19th, 2024, at the beautiful Lewis & Clark College campus!

title: Student Research Internships
subtitle: Scripps
raw_text: The Scripps Research Translational Institute (SRTI) promotes cutting-edge translational research, focused on personalized health care through the genomic, proteomic and metabolomic correlates of health and disease. We additionally seek to advance personalized medicine through research incorporating mobile health (mHealth) monitoring of individuals’ symptoms and physiology.

title: Conrad Challenge
subtitle: Conrad
raw_text: The Conrad Challenge is an innovation and entrepreneurship competition for high school students to develop and pitch solutions to global challenges. Participants create business plans and prototypes that address issues in various fields such as technology, health, and environment. The challenge provides mentorship and resources to support students in developing their ideas. It aims to inspire young innovators and entrepreneurs by offering a platform for showcasing their projects. Winners receive recognition and support for further development of their innovations.

title: Math and Science Scholars
subtitle: UMich
raw_text: Welcome to the Michigan Math and Science Scholars (MMSS) home page, a program designed to introduce high school students to current developments and research in the sciences and to encourage the next generation of researchers to develop and retain a love of mathematics and science.

title: UMKC
subtitle: Career U
raw_text: Career U is a unique program designed to help students gain essential career readiness skills. Participants will engage in workshops networking opportunities and hands-on experiences that prepare them for the workforce. The program aims to enhance professional development and connect students with potential employers.

title: Summer STEM Camp
subtitle: UNLV
raw_text: The UNLV STEM Institute is excited to announce its STEM Summer Camp program for the summer of 2024. Students will have the opportunity to attend the STEM Institute from July 1 – 29, 2024 (Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays (except 7/4), and Fridays, a total of 16 meetings). The morning session will be held from 9:30 – 11:45 AM. The afternoon session will be held from 1:00 – 3:15 PM.

title: Toxicology Camp
subtitle: Oregon State
raw_text: What is toxicology? It is the study of how chemicals and substances affect people, animals, and the earth! In this camp, students will explore what it means for a chemical or substance to be "toxic" or "safe." We'll also learn about ways to protect humans and the environment from toxins. Our student scientists will get to conduct their own toxicology experiments and analyze their data. Activities will reflect real-world challenges that scientists in toxicology and environmental chemistry face. We will go into “the field” to sample the environment, test chemical effects in daphnia, and explore molecular mechanisms in glowing zebrafish.
enhanced_description: What is toxicology? It is the study of how chemicals and substances affect people, animals, and the earth! In this camp, students will explore what it means for a chemical or substance to be "toxic" or "safe." We'll also learn about ways to protect humans and the environment from toxins. Our student scientists will get to conduct their own toxicology experiments and analyze their data. Activities will reflect real-world challenges that scientists in toxicology and environmental chemistry face. We will go into “the field” to sample the environment, test chemical effects in daphnia, and explore molecular mechanisms in glowing zebrafish.

title: Summer Academic Program
subtitle: Columbia
raw_text: Columbia Engineering's Summer High School Academic Program for Engineers (SHAPE) is a pre-college program for rising sophomores, juniors, seniors, and recent high school graduates. SHAPE is geared toward students with a curiosity for STEM: science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Each 3-week session (July 8 - July 26, 2024; July 29 - Aug 16, 2024) offers college-level, project-based courses in engineering taught by a diverse group of faculty at Columbia University

title: Scientific Enrichment Month
subtitle: Columbia University
raw_text:
The Scientific Enrichment Month (SEM) program, brought to you by YES in THE HEIGHTS at the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center (HICCC), is a free virtual program for high school students held in the summer (undergraduates and middle schoolers welcome if interested). This month-long program takes place in July and focuses on cancer education, scientific enrichment, and professional development.  

Students who participate listen and engage in a variety of lectures on topics like how to develop a hypothesis, what is cancer research, cancer health inequities, and public health. Students also join sessions on professional development with topics like resume writing, personal statements, interviewing skills, and public speaking. 

In addition, students can join public health working groups focused on peer-to-peer education for community service hours. Working groups culminate in student presentations which are open to the student’s families and their community. Examples of past public health working groups include:

Human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination (led by past SEM participants)
Skin cancer prevention (led by Community Outreach Engagement Office)
Tobacco use prevention (led by Community Outreach Engagament Office)
Nutrition and physical activity (led by Community Outreach Engagement Office)
Cancer genetics and genetic counseling (led by Huntsman Cancer Institute)
Lastly, those who participate in a specified number of sessions across the month have the opportunity of being granted an HICCC Certificate.

Past topics

A sample of the sessions held in past Scientific Enrichment Month programming includes:  

An introduction to cancer research, including panel discussions with professionals in the field 
Cancer health equity and environmental equity in your community 
Cancer prevention and risk reduction through behavior changes 
Insights from researchers in the field of oncology 
Professional development such as lectures on how to write a personal statement and how to submit a strong college application (parents invited) 
Hands-on, student-led activities
enhanced_description: The Scientific Enrichment Month (SEM) program, hosted by YES in THE HEIGHTS at the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center (HICCC), is a free virtual initiative primarily for high school students, though undergraduates and middle schoolers are also welcome to participate. This month-long program focuses on cancer education, scientific enrichment, and professional development through lectures covering topics such as hypothesis development, cancer health inequities, and public health research. Participants also engage in professional development sessions focused on resume writing, personal statements, interviewing skills, and public speaking to prepare for future academic and career pursuits. Additionally, students can join public health working groups on topics like HPV vaccination and skin cancer prevention, which allow them to earn community service hours and deliver final presentations to their families and community. Those who attend a specified number of sessions throughout the month are eligible to receive an official HICCC Certificate of completion.

title: Mathematics Camp
subtitle: Stanford SUMaC
raw_text:
Spend the Summer with Peers Who Share a Passion for Mathematics

SUMaC leads participants on a journey in advanced mathematics through lectures, guided research, and group problem solving. In an environment centered on mathematics, participants explore current lines of mathematical research, the historical development of important areas of mathematics, and applications across scientific disciplines.
Advanced Mathematics
Explore mathematics beyond the scope of what is typically taught in the classroom. SUMaC is for students who have an exceptional interest in mathematics, and who are prepared to study abstract algebra and number theory or algebraic topology.
Academic Enrichment
SUMaC courses are not for credit or grade—they are designed for pure mathematical enrichment.
Intensive Exploration
SUMaC focuses on mathematics that is motivated independently of ties to other sciences; nonetheless, important applications are introduced and pursued along the way.
College-Level Workload
Similar to what they would experience in a college course, participants can expect a heavy and engaging workload of assignments to complete outside of the live class meeting times.

Admissions is competitive. We receive many more qualified applicants for this small program than the space we have available. The residential program will serve 40 students and the online program will serve 64 students. SUMaC students are selected based on their grades in math courses, their teacher recommendation, their passion for mathematics as demonstrated in their essays and other parts of the application, their prior engagement with math both inside and outside class, and their performance on the SUMaC admission exam. 

Using the factors described above to determine the best fit, the Admissions Committee will place each admitted student in either the Program I course or Program II course. Most applicants accepted to Program II are very familiar with the material covered in Program I through prior participation in SUMaC or other study.

The admission exam is a collection of challenging proof-based math problems for applicants to work on at home over an extended period before the application deadline. If you are not familiar with the type of problems on the admissions exam, we invite you to consider applying to our Stanford Pre-Collegiate Summer Institutes math courses: Number Theory or Discrete Mathematics. These courses will take place online. Stanford Pre-Collegiate Summer Institutes requires a different application from SUMaC, but you can use the same account to begin and submit your application. The deadline to apply for Stanford Pre-Collegiate Summer Institutes courses is March 13, 2026.

In addition to the online application form, a complete application includes: 

Academic Records
We require unofficial transcripts for each school or academic program from which you earned grades (such as letter or numerical grades) from Fall 2023 through Fall 2025. If you have multiple grade reports from one school, combine them into a single file for upload. Homeschooled applicants should submit a document similar to a transcript with their coursework from the years listed above. Homeschooled students should also submit transcripts from any graded courses they took with a school or program during this period. 
 
Teacher Recommendation
We require one online recommendation form from a math teacher.
 
Optional Video Essay
The video essay is an opportunity to share more about your interest in our program. You can consider it a conversation between you and our Admissions Committee. If you attend a school in which the primary language of instruction is a language other than English, we strongly encourage you to complete the video essay.
 
$65 Application Fee
You may submit the $65 application fee online using a credit card. See instructions for payment at the end of the Online Application. Fee waivers can be provided if qualifications are met. To request a fee waiver, complete the application fee waiver form linked in the admissions application.
enhanced_description: SUMaC is an intensive summer program for students with an exceptional interest in advanced mathematics, offering a college-level workload focused on abstract algebra, number theory, and algebraic topology through lectures, guided research, and group problem solving. Designed for pure mathematical enrichment rather than credit, the program features two distinct tracks—Program I and Program II—and serves a limited number of participants across both residential and online formats. Admission is highly competitive and determined by an evaluation of academic records from recent years, a math teacher recommendation, and a challenging proof-based admission exam completed at home. Prospective students must also submit an online application, which includes an optional video essay and a $65 fee, with fee waivers available for those who qualify.

title: Journal of Emerging Investigators
subtitle: Journal of Emerging Investigators
raw_text:
The Journal of Emerging Investigators is a science journal and mentorship program publishing research by middle and high school scientists.

Through the scientific review process, JEI connects middle-school and high-school students with PhD candidates and advanced investigators who work in university research laboratories. By publishing with JEI, student-authors will learn the scientific method, practice communicating their science, and be recognized as young emerging scientists.

These pages will guide you through the entire process, from initial submission all the way to publication. Take some time to review all of the steps before submitting, and feel free to come back throughout the process as you move through the different stages.

Requirements For JEI Submissions

In order for your submission to pass pre-review and enter the scientific review process, it must meet the following requirements:

The person submitting the manuscript must be an adult mentor as outlined in our author eligibility requirements.
The manuscript must be submitted using our manuscript template, following the instructions in the document correctly.
If the study involves human subjects or vertebrate animals, documentation of regulatory approval must be included in the submission.
The manuscript must appropriately cite any outside sources of information, data, or software according to our reference formatting guidelines.

A teacher, mentor, or Principal Investigator of a lab must submit on behalf of the student authors. In no instances should a student submit his/her own manuscript.
enhanced_description: The Journal of Emerging Investigators (JEI) serves as a science journal and mentorship program that publishes original research authored by middle and high school students. By engaging in a formal scientific review process, participants collaborate with PhD candidates and advanced university investigators to refine their understanding of the scientific method and enhance their professional communication skills. All submissions must be managed by an adult mentor, teacher, or principal investigator rather than the student, and manuscripts are required to follow a specific template while including proper citations. Furthermore, any research involving human subjects or vertebrate animals must be accompanied by documentation of regulatory approval to be eligible for publication.

title: GSU
subtitle: Summer Institute
raw_text: The Summer Institute at Georgia State University offers international students an immersive experience in American culture and academics. Participants engage in various courses and activities designed to enhance their English language skills while exploring the vibrant city of Atlanta. This program fosters cultural exchange and personal growth.

All while they build connections with peers from around the world and learn from Duke faculty and PhD students as well as industry experts.

title: SPUN Debate Program
subtitle: NSS
raw_text: The spUN Debate Program forms teams of international students who learn about current laws and concerns in space development and expansion.  It then gives them the opportunity to debate the ramifications of emerging policy in space industries and space utilization.

title: National Youth Science Camp

raw_text: The National Youth Science Camp (NYSCamp) is a prestigious residential STEM program for recent high school graduates. It offers lectures, hands-on activities, and outdoor adventures to foster a deep understanding of STEM topics. The camp is fully funded, covering all expenses including travel, meals, and accommodation. Participants engage with STEM professionals and network with peers from across the nation. The program aims to develop future leaders in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.

title: Nash U
subtitle: Sadie Nash
raw_text: Nash U is a year-long program designed to support seniors through the college application process. With intensive one-on-one advising and peer support, this is an opportunity to determine what plans are best for YOU after high school.

title: Young Investigators

raw_text: At the Stanford Doerr School of Sustainability, high school scholars spend the summer working in research groups and laboratories on the main Stanford campus. Since 2004, over 300 high school students have worked in our research labs and learned about the process of science first hand. We offer several different options, with different areas of focus and time commitments.

title: Georgia Tech

raw_text: This program offers high school students the chance to engage in STEM-related research at Georgia Tech. Participants will work alongside faculty and graduate students gaining hands-on experience in a collaborative environment. The program aims to inspire future careers in science and technology.

title: Summer SAIL

raw_text: FREE weeklong Day-Only and Overnight/Residential programs for rising high school freshman through rising seniors, hosted on the University of Oregon Eugene campus, where high school students learn about various subjects from distinguished University of Oregon faculty members through fun social and interactive activities.

title: CATALYST Academy
subtitle: Cornell
raw_text: CATALYST Academy is a branch of the Cornell Engineering High School Outreach Program. It is a one-week residential program for rising high school juniors and seniors who desire to learn about engineering in the context of an authentic college experience. It is designed to develop literacy around engineering as a major course of study, showcase career and graduate school pathways in engineering, and demystify the college admissions process. Scholars spend a week on the Cornell campus, living in dormitories, and networking with current Cornell Engineering students, faculty, and fellow participants from across the country. Participants attend daily classes in one area of study led by a Cornell Engineering faculty member. They work cooperatively under the supervision of faculty, graduate students, and undergraduate students to execute and present a research project. Scholars also participate in nine field sessions across our engineering majors, as well as a field session focused on the admissions process.

title: Business and Technology Programs
subtitle: UCD
raw_text: Our online Business and Technology Programs for high school students are engaging, interactive and impactful. College-bound students can explore technology careers in cybersecurity and data analytics and are perfect for those interested in computer science or other STEM programs. Both our online Cyber Sleuth Immersion Program and online Introduction to Data Analytics Immersion Program are made up of two courses, giving you a robust experience. Through online project-based learning and role playing, you will immerse yourself in realistic scenarios that develop essential career skills such as teamwork, critical thinking, problem solving and communication.

title: Mark Cuban Foundation AI Bootcamp
subtitle: PSU
raw_text: The Mark Cuban Foundation AI Bootcamp is an opportunity for high school students to immerse themselves in artificial intelligence and machine learning. No prior experience with coding is required for participation. With AI being a relevant topic on many news sources, students will learn what artificial intelligence is and is not, where they already interact with AI in their own lives, and the ethical implications of AI systems including, but not limited to, TikTok recommendations, smart home assistants, facial recognition, and self-driving cars. Participants will also learn how Large Language Models like ChatGPT are changing life as we know it by answering questions, telling original stories, and even writing computer code.

raw_text: The UMass Dartmouth STEAM Academy offers high school students a chance to explore science technology engineering arts and mathematics through hands-on activities and projects. Students who are interested in STEM fields and would like to experience “real-time” applications of STEM in a research-focused work world conducting research and technology development should apply.

title: University of Minnesota

title: Summer Session

raw_text: Each summer William & Mary offers about 180 courses in summer sessions through the main campus and through the Washington Center. The delivery mode is noted in the course description. title: Forensic Science Camp
subtitle: PSU

title: Human Exploration Rover Challenge

Winners receive recognition for their engineering achievements and contributions to space exploration. The competition supports hands-on learning and innovation in planetary science and engineering.

title: William & Mary
subtitle: Pre-College Programs
raw_text: William & Mary’s pre-college programs offer high school students unique opportunities to explore various academic fields and gain insight into college life through engaging activities with faculty and peers in a collaborative environment.

title: Future Generations of Women Leaders
subtitle: KPMG
raw_text: The KPMG Future Leaders Program is a charitable initiative designed to increase the diversity pipeline of women in business and STEM fields. Funded by the proceeds from the KPMG Women’s PGA Championship and KPMG Women’s Leadership Summit, the KPMG Future Leaders Program annually awards 22 deserving female high school seniors the opportunity to enhance their personal growth throughout their college experience with annual scholarships, ongoing development and support, mentorship and an introduction to golf. Since the program's inception in 2016, more than $5.3 million in scholarships have been awarded to 166 KPMG Future Leaders.

title: Global Youth Program - Sports Business Academy
subtitle: University of Pennsylvania Wharton
raw_text:
Sponsored by the Wharton Sports Analytics and Business Initiative (WSABI), the Wharton Sports Business Academy (WSBA) takes students inside the business of sports, exploring how the industry is structured, monetized, and evolving. Delivered online, the program combines faculty lectures, case discussions, current events, guest speakers, and a capstone project, giving students an authentic Wharton-style introduction to one of the most exciting global industries. 

Key themes and topics include: 

Foundations of Sports Business 
Why study sports as a business discipline 
The history of sports business and its evolution 
Industry overview: leagues, teams, and associations 
The Business of Sports Properties 
Revenue generation models in professional and college sports 
Franchise ownership, valuation, and governance 
Unions, player compensation, and collective bargaining 
Revenue sharing and competitive balance across leagues 
Fans, Media, and Marketing 
Understanding today’s fan and shifting consumer behavior 
Media strategies and the future of live sports on TV and streaming 
Marketing, sponsorships, and licensing as key revenue streams 
Special Topics in Sports Business 
The rise of emerging leagues and niche sports 
The economic and ethical implications of sports gambling 
Deep dives into golf, tennis, motorsports, and college sports as unique case studies 
Capstone Project: Emerging League Analysis 
Teams research an emerging professional sports league 
Conduct a SWOT analysis to evaluate strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats Develop a strategy recommendation and present findings in a final group presentation 
By the end of WSBA, students will understand not just how the sports industry works, but also how to analyze its opportunities, navigate its challenges, and apply business thinking to one of the world’s most dynamic fields.
enhanced_description: Sponsored by the Wharton Sports Analytics and Business Initiative (WSABI), the Wharton Sports Business Academy (WSBA) provides students with an authentic introduction to the structure, monetization, and evolution of the global sports industry. The program utilizes faculty lectures, case discussions, and guest speakers to explore foundational topics such as league governance, franchise valuation, and revenue generation models in both professional and collegiate sports. Participants examine the shifting landscape of media strategies, fan engagement, and marketing sponsorships, alongside specialized subjects like the rise of niche leagues and the economic impact of sports gambling. The experience culminates in a capstone project where student teams conduct a SWOT analysis on an emerging professional league and present strategic recommendations, ensuring they can apply rigorous business thinking to navigate the challenges of this dynamic field.

title: UML Liftoff
subtitle: UMass
raw_text: Rising high school juniors and seniors also have the option to participate in our signature 6-week program. Students can complete up to two courses during this program. In addition, students are supported with weekly faculty roundtable discussions, student success coaching, tutoring, and regular check-ins on course progress by first year professional advisors.

title: Biomechanics at UNO
subtitle: YNS
raw_text: High schoolers (grades 9-12) can attend YNS summer camps -OR- apply to be a High School Researcher*. YNS High School Camps take place in Nebraska college laboratories with small groups and experiments for hands-on aspects of science with in-depth experiences. title: American Rocketry Challenge
