raw_text: The American Rocketry Challenge (TARC) is a national competition where high school students design, build, and launch model rockets. Participants compete to achieve specific flight objectives, such as altitude and duration. The challenge aims to foster interest in aerospace engineering and provide hands-on experience with rocketry. Winners receive awards and the opportunity to advance to international competitions. The competition supports STEM education and encourages innovation in aerospace technology.

title: Summer Child Health Internship
subtitle: Children's Hospital
raw_text: The Department of Pediatrics at the University of Colorado School of Medicine and the Colorado Child Health Research Institute at Children's Hospital Colorado host a summer research program for high school seniors over the age of 18, college students, graduate students and first-year medical students. Students will work in the lab with members of the Department of Pediatrics faculty at Children's Hospital Colorado and the University of Colorado on the Anschutz Medical Campus.

title: Belin-Blank Research Center
subtitle: UIowa
raw_text: you are an advanced high school student in grades 10-11, this highly selective and intensive summer research program may be for you. SSTP offers you rare access to opportunities that help realize your academic and professional goals. You will conduct research under the mentorship of world-class faculty from a research-intensive university. Participate in classes and events that will stretch you as a researcher and scholar. Explore your interests, enhance your academic skills, and make meaningful friendships with intellectual peers.

title: Precollege Academic Campus Experience (PACE)
subtitle: UW Madison
raw_text: The PACE program gives students finishing grades 5–8 an opportunity to explore their current interests and passions with like-minded peers in a college setting. Students will spend one week taking an enrichment course designed specifically for advanced middle-school learners. Students may choose to take a class in the first session, in the second session, or participate in both sessions. Scholarships are available.

title: WoodWorks
subtitle: UHouston
raw_text: Architecture combines practical considerations of function and sustainability with a poetics of form and meaning. Although architecture may take years to master, those who study it in college have usually harbored an intense curiosity since at least their early teens. Daily slide-illustrated lectures on architectural history from the ancient to modern and an introductory studio, with accompanying field trips, will give you a broader, deeper understanding of the subject and also the opportunity to develop a portfolio for use in applying to schools of architecture should you eventually wish to do so.

title: Livestock Science Camp
subtitle: NCSU
raw_text: The NC State Livestock Science Camp is designed for high school students aged 15-18. During the camp, youth will engage with NC State students, faculty, and staff to explore animal science and learn more about the livestock and agricultural industries and related careers. No previous livestock species experience is necessary.

title: Scholars Program
subtitle: Project Scientist
raw_text: Project Scientist’s Scholars program is an interactive after-school program for girls* ages 13-18 to build confidence, ignite curiosity and empower their science, technology, engineering, arts and math (STEAM) career dreams. Scholars meet once a week for 90 minutes for 12 to 16 weeks.

title: Summer Camp
subtitle: NYFA
raw_text: During NYFA’s year-round programs, teens and kids can pursue their interests in the film, media, and performing arts. Through projects, exercises, games, and activities, students develop new skills in filmmaking, acting for film, screenwriting, broadcast journalism, photography, musical theatre, game design or 3D animation. In these programs, students learn what it means to be a visual and (or) performing artist and storyteller while forming lasting friendships, creating their own unique content, and establishing their unique artistic voice.

title: Building Leadership Strategies Summer Academy
subtitle: Rutgers
raw_text: During this one-week intensive program, you will engage in a series of integrated lectures and public speaking workshops, and activities. Through this program, you will identify your personal leadership strengths and style, enhance critical thinking skills, and hone in on communication skills.

title: Research Immersion
subtitle: UCSD
raw_text: RIMSE stands for Research Immersion in Materials Science and Engineering. Sponsored by the U.S. National Science Foundation as part of the UC San Diego Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC), the RIMSE Summer Schools are immersive, hands-on courses meant to prepare trainees to work in Materials Science and Materials Engineering research laboratories.  They generally run for 8 to 10-weeks each summer on the UC San Diego campus. The UC San Diego MRSEC currently runs four RIMSE schools. Focused on materials science research in topics of interest to the UC San Diego MRSEC, each of the four RIMSE Summer Schools are run by MRSEC faculty who serve as senior mentors and/or instructors. Each RIMSE begins with an intensive training in theory, techniques and laboratory methods, and includes  a capstone “Discovery Project”—an independent research project implemented by the trainee in a small team and under the mentorship of a current UC San Diego MRSEC researcher.

title: UMKC
subtitle: Gencyber Camps
raw_text: Gencyber Camps offer high school students an opportunity to learn about cybersecurity through hands-on activities and interactive sessions. Participants will engage in team-based challenges and gain insights into the field of cybersecurity while developing critical skills needed for future careers in technology.

title: Bridge Undergraduate Science Jr. Program
subtitle: USC
raw_text: The BUGS Jr Program runs concurrently each summer with a parallel program for undergraduates, Bridge Undergraduate Science Program, known as BUGS for short. Students in the BUGS Jr Program pair with a USC Faculty Member and the members of their laboratory, often graduate students or postdoctoral fellows, to perform hands-on research in state-of-the-art research labs at USC. Students also benefit from weekly BUGS Jr Program activities, including campus tours, journal clubs, career symposia, technical panels and Bridge-sponsored peer community-building activities such as research seminars and multi-disciplinary social mixers.

title: GU
subtitle: Georgetown University High School Summer Internship Program
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to gain hands-on experience in various fields while working alongside professionals. Interns will engage in meaningful projects develop skills and gain insights into potential career paths.

title: Summer College Immersion Program
subtitle: UCLA
raw_text: The UCLA Summer College Immersion Program (SCIP) offers exceptional high school students the opportunity to experience a comprehensive introduction to college life while studying alongside UCLA undergraduates. Designed to emulate the undergraduate experience, SCIP provides students access to a broad range of UCLA’s academic expertise and resources through lectures, workshops, and seminars, as well as UCLA coursework. SCIP’s co-curricular components are specifically curated to empower students to gain balance and thrive as they embark on their college journey.

title: JSEP
subtitle: Dartmouth
raw_text: The one-week 2024 Remote JSEP program will take place in late July or August 2024.  Exact dates will be determined and posted here soon. Students are expected to attend the full week of the program, which consists of daily meetings on zoom and independent work completed at home. Daily synchronous meetings on zoom will last no more than 4 hours and we will arrange meeting times to accommodate time zones of U.S. students as best as possible. Students will also have some pre-assignments to complete in advance of the remote program.  The 2024 field program will take place late June into July 2024. We typically travel to Greenland around the 25th of June and return 2-3 weeks later. We should have tentative dates for the program by the fall, which will be posted here when available. We won't know the exact dates until spring when flight schedules are finalized. Students who participate in the field program are also expected to participate in components of the remote program to offer their experiences and insights from being in Greenland.

title: Medical Program
subtitle: UHawaii
raw_text: The program involves learning through various methods, including gross anatomy lab demonstrations, clinical skills labs, computerized manikin simulations, and standardized patient interactions. Students will gain knowledge about the epidemiology, signs, symptoms, pathophysiology, diagnosis, and treatment of common illnesses in Hawai`i. They will also develop basic clinical skills like measuring vital signs and using stethoscopes to listen to heart and lung sounds. Additionally, students will practice interviewing and counseling patients. This hands-on approach aims to provide comprehensive training in medical skills and patient care.

title: Bioengineering Research
subtitle: UCSD
raw_text: The UC San Diego Department of Bioengineering and UC San Diego Extended Studies are pleased to offer courses to high school students who are excelling in scholarship and would like to explore Bioengineering. The course offerings are based on fun, experiential, remote, at-home, hands-on lab activities.

title: Computer & Data Science Camp
subtitle: Lebanon Valley
raw_text: LVC's Computer and Data Science Summer Camp introduces high school juniors and seniors to programming and data science. The week-long camp includes hands-on projects, teamwork, and problem-solving activities. Participants learn fundamental concepts in computer science and data analysis. The program also features guest speakers and site visits to tech companies. It aims to equip students with skills and knowledge for future studies and careers in technology and data science.

title: Biomedical Engineering Innovation
subtitle: JHU
raw_text: During the JHU three-credit course, you will model biological systems and design experiments to test those models and use engineering principles to solve biological, physiological, and/or medical design problems. Note that this is a mostly asynchronous course with pre-recorded lectures; optional, real-time study sessions; and no set class times.

title: Howling With Cals
subtitle: NCSU
raw_text: The Howling with CALS Camp is a 5-day residential camp (June 9 -13, 2024) for a small group of rising high-school freshmen from rural North Carolina counties or underrepresented communities to reside on North Carolina State University’s campus to learn more about opportunities within agriculture and life sciences. From meeting our dairy cows and having a taste of howling cow ice cream to propagating weird and wonderful plants, this week promises a lot of fun discovery. We are seeking students who are interested in learning more about agriculture and life sciences disciplines, have a passion for making a difference, and understanding the science behind these fields, and participating in hands-on learning.

title: Summer Academy
subtitle: ESAP
raw_text: The Engineering Summer Academy at Penn (ESAP) welcomes highly motivated and talented students to explore Engineering at the college level.  The Academy’s intensive, three-week programs combine sophisticated theory with hands-on practical experience in cutting-edge technologies. Work with leading faculty while earning college credit, live on Penn’s historic campus, and connect with new friends from around the world.

title: Summer Research Immersion
subtitle: Binghamton
raw_text: SRI is a research-intensive, structured and mentored experience. It consists of two, four-credit courses (eight credits in total) over 10 weeks in the summer between summer sessions I and III. Participation in the program is a full-time (40 hr/wk) commitment. SRI program for 2024 will run from May 28th - August 2nd.

title: Medical and Health Programs
subtitle: UCD
raw_text: Get a taste of what various careers in health and medicine are like with these unique, online courses. Designed to give high school students an immersive, engaging and robust learning experience, these courses help students build teamwork, communication, critical thinking and problem-solving skills. Through an interactive, simulation-based format, you will gain realistic practice by playing the role of a medical or health professional and completing the tasks assigned.

title: Teen Wellness Summit
subtitle: UCSF
raw_text: Join 150 high school students to gain knowledge, learn new skills, reduce stigma around mental health, get helpful resources, and have FUN! FREE educational event open to all SF Unified School District 9th-12th grade student Raffle, goodie bags, free catered lunch from SF Kebab. Presentations from UCSF researchers, faculty, and other local experts on teen mental health. Exciting workshops such as Supporting Friends, Nature Connection, LGBT Mental Health, Expressive Arts, and many more! Organized by teens for teens!

title: Clinical Neuroscience Immersion Experience (CNI-X)
subtitle: Stanford University
raw_text:
The Clinical Neuroscience Immersion Experience (CNI-X) at Stanford University is an intensive summer program that generally follows a student’s sophomore, junior, or senior year of high school. Students attend a two-week (10-day) session which provides introductory exposure to fascinating topics in neuroscience, psychiatry and psychology plus an opportunity to complete a collaborative capstone project.

During each session, students from across California, the country, and the world are exposed to the breadth of research found in the Stanford Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences. Through interactive seminars with Stanford faculty and researchers, students learn about principles of neuroscience, clinical neuropsychiatry, neuroscience research, psychiatric epidemiology, behavioral and social sciences, and more. CNI-X also covers topics important to young people, including professional and career opportunities in medicine and science, plus self-care strategies in the transition to adulthood. 

In addition to participating in interactive lectures, students in each session will spend guided time working in small teams to develop innovative, novel solutions to social issues related to psychiatry, psychology, or neuroscience. These ideas and solutions will then be presented at a final capstone session in front of an audience of classmates, families, and the program’s faculty and staff.

CNI-X is a fast-paced, intense, challenging, creative, and bonding experience for students. Previous students have come from very diverse academic backgrounds, and have a wide range of career aspirations, including law, sociology, medicine, psychology, engineering, business, fine arts, and more.
enhanced_description: The Clinical Neuroscience Immersion Experience (CNI-X) is an intensive ten-day program designed for high school students who have completed their sophomore, junior, or senior years. Participants engage in interactive seminars led by faculty and researchers from the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, covering diverse topics such as clinical neuropsychiatry, psychiatric epidemiology, and behavioral sciences. In addition to academic lectures, the curriculum explores professional career paths in medicine and science while providing practical self-care strategies for the transition to adulthood. A core component of the experience is a collaborative capstone project where students work in small teams to develop and present innovative solutions to social issues related to neuroscience and psychology. This fast-paced and challenging program attracts students from a wide variety of academic backgrounds, including those interested in law, medicine, engineering, and the fine arts.

title: The Columbia Junior Science Journal
subtitle: Columbia University
raw_text:
The Columbia Junior Science Journal (CJSJ) is a high school research journal seeking original research papers and review articles. We provide high school students with a platform to publish manuscripts in the fields of natural sciences, physical sciences, engineering, and social sciences. Selected CJSJ authors demonstrate the ability to communicate research projects to the general public and scientific community. CJSJ promotes the development of young researchers versed in technical and communication skills, which are facets encoded into the DNA of Columbia University.

Background

CJSJ began as a spin-off journal of the Columbia Undergraduate Science Journal (CUSJ), an open-access, professional-level science journal that is committed to publishing manuscripts of the highest scholarship stemming from significant scientific research and outstanding scientific analysis. Papers published in CUSJ undergo a peer review process by the journal’s editorial review board. Established in 2005, CUSJ publishes its journal annually, resulting in 17 volumes as of Spring 2024. In Fall 2015, CUSJ leadership elected to bring a similar opportunity to high school students by establishing CJSJ. CJSJ has published 9 volumes as of Spring 2024. CJSJ continues to set the bar higher with each volume. This growth is driven by research of the highest quality from our authors and the dedication of our editorial board.
enhanced_description: The Columbia Junior Science Journal (CJSJ) serves as a professional-level platform for high school students to publish original research papers and review articles in the fields of natural sciences, physical sciences, engineering, and social sciences. Originally established as a spin-off of the Columbia Undergraduate Science Journal, this publication focuses on developing young researchers who possess strong technical skills and the ability to communicate scientific findings to both the general public and the broader scientific community. Selected authors demonstrate high-quality scholarship and outstanding scientific analysis, contributing to a growing body of work that currently spans nine volumes and is managed by a dedicated editorial board.

title: Captured in Clay
subtitle: Emory
raw_text: Have you ever stopped to look at a work of art and wondered about the person depicted in it? Led by ceramicist Savannah O'Leary, campers will use the works in the Carlos Museum as a starting point to think about what a portrait can be. Campers will create individual portrait vessels and as well as a collaborative piece using traditional hand-building methods like pinch pots, coiling, and slabs.

title: SRMP
subtitle: American Museum
raw_text: The Science Research Mentoring Program (SRMP) at the American Museum of Natural History is an opportunity for New York City high school students to conduct one year (August–June) of scientific research with Museum scientists.

title: Neuroscience Program
subtitle: Rockefeller
raw_text: The Summer Neuroscience Program (SNP) is a two-week course for NYC public high schoolers led by Rockefeller graduate students. Participants take a look at ongoing neuroscience research in an effort to understand how the brain works and how it relates to our daily life. We aim to introduce students to modern neuroscience, while empowering them to explore in their own unique ways the mysteries that remain.

title: Tufts University
subtitle: Teachers and High School Students Program (TAHSS)
raw_text: This program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in hands-on learning experiences in medicine and health care. Participants will explore various topics and gain insights into the medical field through interactive sessions and mentorship from professionals.

title: University of North Texas
subtitle: UNT AI Summer Research Program
raw_text: The UNT AI Summer Research Program offers high school students the opportunity to engage in hands-on research projects in artificial intelligence. Participants will work closely with faculty mentors and gain valuable experience in the field while developing their skills and knowledge in a collaborative environment.

title: Summer Research Program
subtitle: Fermilab QuarkNet
raw_text: QuarkNet offers summer research opportunities in science and technology for students who have demonstrated a strong interest in and aptitude for science and mathematics. Students work with scientists for seven weeks on projects related to the Fermilab research program.

title: Solve For Tomorrow
subtitle: Samsung
raw_text: Samsung's Solve for Tomorrow competition encourages high school students to develop innovative solutions to address community issues using STEM principles. Participants work on projects that tackle real-world problems and present their solutions to judges. The competition aims to foster creativity and problem-solving skills among students. Winners receive prizes and recognition for their contributions to STEM and community improvement. The contest supports the development of future leaders in technology and innovation.

title: CURE Internship
subtitle: UCSF
raw_text: The CURE Internship is a paid opportunity for high school juniors underrepresented in health careers to spend two months at UCSF supporting various types of research with the primary objectives of: Immersing promising high school juniors in career opportunities across the spectrum of research, including basic, clinical, behavioral, and population sciences; Providing positive training and support for participating students so they will declare a major aligned with biomedical research and seriously consider research as a career option. The CURE program provides high school students with an exceptional scientific, health and medical environment to further their career interests, as well as college application preparation and academic and professional development.

title: Emergent Quantum Materials and Technologies
subtitle: YNS
raw_text: High schoolers (grades 9-12) can attend YNS summer camps -OR- apply to be a High School Researcher*. YNS High School Camps take place in Nebraska college laboratories with small groups and experiments for hands-on aspects of science with in-depth experiences. Each summer a few high school students are chosen for paid positions as High School Researchers: working with science teams at Nebraska campuses. These experiences are ideal for exposure to real-life STEM job experiences, and look great on your college applications.

title: The Emerson Prize
subtitle: The Concord Review
raw_text: We need the best history papers we can find, and we welcome a chance to consider your best work. Essays are accepted on a "rolling admissions” basis and are eligible for the next four issues of the journal. Deadlines to be considered for specific issues are August 1 (Winter), November 1 (Spring), February 1 (Summer) and May 1 (Fall). We are frequently asked what types of papers we look for and are most likely to publish. There is no set criteria for this, but here are a few suggestions: 1) Having an interesting and informative topic that readers will learn something from. 2) Writing in an engaging and clear manner that will make your paper easy and enjoyable to read and 3) Having a substantial bibliography showing that you have done abundant research and using many of these sources in your paper through your endnotes. Even if your work does not get immediately published (we only publish around 5% of essays we receive), we always suggest to students who are applying to college in the near future that they include on their college application that they submitted a paper to The Concord Review (include the title and the length of the paper) and that it is still being considered for publication. We have been around since 1987 so many college admissions officers are familiar with our work, and realize that any student submitting a paper to TCR is serious about their academic work and would do well in college.

title: SVRA Research and Data Analysis Intern
subtitle: IALR
raw_text: The Institute for Advanced Learning and Research (IALR) offers an annual summer internship program to provide meaningful on-the-job training. The internship program provides real-world leadership development experiences in diverse career fields such as research and data analysis, public relations, human resources, AgTech research, coding and robotics, information technology and more. Candidates for IALR internships must be: a high school graduate with plans to attend college in fall of 2024; an undergraduate or graduate level college student; OR a recent college graduate, within the last 12 months.

title: Research Scholars Program
subtitle: SanfordHealth
raw_text: This unique 10-week research internship offers a total-immersion experience in real-time laboratory research at Sanford for motivated high school students with an aptitude for biomedical sciences. Work alongside scientists as part of the research team, connect with peers through in-house scientific interest groups, and present your work as a scientific poster at the Sanford Research Symposium. PROMISE Scholars earn 3 undergraduate elective-credits at the University of South Dakota (BIOC192) and are awarded a $2,500 scholarship.

title: Utah Entrepreneur Challenge
subtitle: Lassonde
raw_text: The Lassonde Entrepreneur Institute's High School Entrepreneurial Competition invites students to develop and pitch innovative business ideas. Participants work on creating viable business plans and receive feedback from experienced entrepreneurs and industry professionals. The competition aims to foster entrepreneurship and provide students with opportunities to showcase their ideas and skills. It offers mentorship, resources, and potential investment to support student ventures. The competition promotes creativity and business acumen among high school students.

title: Shadow Program
subtitle: Stanford IFSS
raw_text: Hosted each summer, the focus of the Inspiring Future Scientists Through Shadowing (IFSS) program is to provide rising high school juniors and seniors who are at least 16 years of age by the start of the program (no exceptions can be made to the age cut-off) with the opportunity to learn more about cutting-edge chemical research. Throughout the two-week program, participants will observe and converse with a number of different graduate students in the chemistry department. There are many different types of research, therefore shadowing a couple of different researchers will allow you the chance to learn broadly about a wide array of scientific topics and techniques.

title: Mercer University
subtitle: Pharmacy Scholars Summer Program
raw_text: This summer program offers high school students an opportunity to explore the field of pharmacy through hands-on experiences and educational sessions. Participants will engage with faculty and current pharmacy students while learning about the profession and the admissions process for pharmacy school.

title: MedAcademy
subtitle: UCI
raw_text: UCI MedAcademy is a five-day experience designed to introduce high school students to medical careers and broaden students’ understanding of the healthcare field. UCI MedAcademy is open to high school students (including 2023 graduates) ages 15-19. Participants must be at least 15 years of age by the first day of the session they plan to attend.

title: Pre-Collegiate University-Level Online Math & Physics
subtitle: Stanford University
raw_text:

 Mathematics ULO
Mathematics
We offer nine advanced, rigorous mathematics courses. These courses were originally designed to match the Stanford Mathematics Department's curriculum. All mathematics courses require prerequisites to help ensure student success.
Prerequisites

The flowchart below outlines what course(s) students should begin with. In order to enroll in a course, students must satisfy the given prerequisites or the equivalent.

ulo-prereq
Courses

Multivariable Differential Calculus (XM521)

Differential calculus for functions of two or more variables. Topics: vectors and vector-valued functions in 2-space and 3-space, tangent and normal vectors, curvature, functions of two or more variables, partial derivatives and differentiability, directional derivatives and gradients, maxima and minima, optimization using Lagrange multipliers.

Prerequisites: Calculus AB, BC (or Calc I, II) or equivalent.
Required text: Calculus: A New Horizon, 6th edition (or later).

Multivariable Integral Calculus (XM522)

Integral calculus for functions of two or more variables. Topics: double and triple integrals, change of variables and the Jacobian, vector fields, line integrals, independence of path and the fundamental theorem of line integrals, Green's theorem, divergence theorem, and Stokes' theorem.

Prerequisites: Multivariable Differential Calculus or equivalent.
Required text: Calculus: A New Horizon, 6th edition (or later).

Linear Algebra (XM511)

An introductory course in Linear Algebra. Topics: matrices, linear equations, vector spaces, bases, coordinates, linear transformations, eigenvectors, eigenvalues, and diagonalization.

Prerequisites: Calculus AB, BC or equivalent.
Required text: Linear Algebra, Bronson.

Modern Algebra (XM609)*

Theory of abstract algebra, with particular emphasis on applications involving symmetry. Topics: groups, quotient groups, symmetry groups in three dimensions, Pólya-Burnside method, rings and fields, polynomial and Euclidean rings, quotient rings, field extensions, and geometrical constructions.

Prerequisites: Multivariable Calculus, Linear Algebra or equivalent.
Required text: Modern Algebra and Applications, Gilbert.

*Only offered in Fall and Spring terms

Real Analysis (XM615)

Theory of functions of a real variable. Topics: sequences, series, limits, continuity, uniform continuity, sequences and series of functions, uniform convergence, differentiation.

Prerequisites: Calculus, Linear Algebra or equivalent. [Proof-writing experience is desirable.]
Required text: Elementary Analysis: The Theory of Calculus, K. Ross.

Complex Analysis (XM606)*

Theory of differentiation and integration of complex functions. Topics: algebra of complex numbers, complex functions, multi-valued functions, exponentials, logarithms, analyticity, integrals, power series, Laurent series, residues, isolated singularities, poles and zeros.

Prerequisites: Calculus, Real Analysis, Linear Algebra or equivalent.
Required text: Complex Variables and Applications, Brown and Churchill.

*Only offered in Fall and Spring terms

Differential Equations (XM531)

Basic techniques and methods for solving ordinary differential equations. Topics: linear, separable, and exact equations, existence and uniqueness theorems, difference equations, basic theory of higher order equations, variation of parameters, undetermined coefficients, series solutions, Laplace transform, systems of equations.

Prerequisites: Multivariable Differential Calculus, Linear Algebra or equivalent.
Required text: Elementary Differential Equations, Boyce and DiPrima, 6th edition (or later).

Partial Differential Equations (XM631)*

Theory of differential equations involving functions of more than one variable. Topics: first order equations, classification of second order equations, initial-boundary value problems for heat equation, wave and related equations, separation of variables, eigenvalue problems, Fourier series, existence and uniqueness questions.

Prerequisites: Multivariable Calculus, Linear Algebra, Differential Equations, Real Analysis, Complex Analysis or equivalent.
Required text: Partial Differential Equations, An Introduction, W. Strauss.

*Only offered in Fall and Spring terms

Number Theory (XM452)

Introduction to number theory and its applications. Topics: Euclid's algorithm, divisibility, prime numbers, congruence of numbers, theorems of Fermat, Euler, Wilson, Lagrange's theorem; residues of power, quadratic residues; magic squares; continued fractions; Diophantine equations; quadratic fields and quadratic integers.

Prerequisites: Precalculus or equivalent. [Proof-writing experience, participation in math competitions are desirable.]
Required text: An Introduction to Number Theory, Stark.

 Physics ulo
Physics
We offer four advanced physics courses that were originally designed to match the Stanford Physics curriculum. These courses have mandatory prerequisites both in physics as well as mathematics. These prerequisites help ensure student success.
Prerequisites

The flowchart below outlines what course(s) students should begin with. In order to enroll in a course, students must satisfy the given prerequisites or the equivalent.

 Physics Course Map
Courses

Light and Heat (XP645)

An introduction to optics and thermodynamics. Topics: temperature, properties of matter, introduction to the kinetic theory of matter, light and electromagnetic waves, reflection and refraction of light, lens systems, interference and diffraction.

Prerequisites: AP Physics C: Electricity and Magnetism, AP Calculus AB, BC, or equivalent.
Required text: Physics; For Scientists and Engineers. P. Tipler, 5th, 6th or Fundamentals of Physics, Halliday, Resnick, 7th or later.

Modern Physics (XP670)

An introduction to the two pillars of modern physics. Special relativity and an introduction to general relativity, experimental basis of quantum theory, quantization of light, Hilbert space structure of qubits, multiparticle states, entangled states, incompatible observables, Bell inequalities, introduction to quantum information and quantum computing, Schrödinger equation.

Prerequisites: Light and Heat and Multivariable Differential Calculus, and Linear Algebra as corequisite.
Required text: Spacetime Physics, J. Wheeler, E. Taylor, 2nd; Quantum Mechanics, L. Susskind; Six Quantum Pieces, V. Scarani.

Intermediate Mechanics I (XP710)*

Intermediate Mechanics covers much of what is generally covered in an upper division university mechanics course. The course is a sophisticated treatment of the mechanics of particles and systems. Tensors, vector calculus, Newtonian laws of mechanics and gravitation, oscillations, Green's functions, calculus of variations, Lagrangian mechanics, orbits, and physics in rotating frames of reference.

Prerequisites: Modern Physics & Differential Equations.
Required text: Classical Dynamics; Of Particles and Systems, S. Thornton, J. Marion, 4th or later.

*Only offered in Fall and Spring terms

Intermediate Mechanics II (XP711)*

Intermediate Mechanics covers much of what is generally covered in an upper division university mechanics course. The course is a sophisticated treatment of the mechanics of particles and systems. Rigid body dynamics, oscillating systems, Hamilton's principle for continuous systems, waves, general wave equation, and fluid dynamics.

Prerequisites: Intermediate Mechanics I.
Required text: Classical Dynamics; Of Particles and Systems, S. Thornton, J. Marion, 4th or later.

*Only offered in Fall and Spring terms

enhanced_description: Stanford Pre-Collegiate Studies offers University Level Online (ULO) courses in advanced mathematics and physics, featuring a curriculum originally designed to match Stanford University’s own academic standards. The mathematics track includes nine rigorous options such as Multivariable Calculus, Linear Algebra, Real Analysis, and Number Theory, while the physics track consists of four advanced courses including Light and Heat, Modern Physics, and Intermediate Mechanics. To ensure student success, all participants must satisfy specific prerequisites and obtain required textbooks, with some specialized courses available exclusively during the fall and spring terms. Interested students can apply for the program through the official portal and may also seek financial aid to support their enrollment in these high-level academic offerings.

title: High School Internship
subtitle: CLA
raw_text: Looking to explore the world of business, professional services, or accounting and gain hands-on experience with real projects and clients? Discover your passions and pave the way for your future career with CLA’s high school internship program. Designed for students aged 16 to 18, this summer internship provides the opportunity to develop new skills, understand your strengths, and get paid for your hard work. Internship opportunities are available in select locations nationwide starting in June.

title: AMC 8
subtitle: MAA
raw_text:
AMC 8

The AMC 8 is a great way to introduce younger students to mathematical problem-solving beyond the standard school curriculum. Students who enjoy the AMC 8 may want to continue with the AMC 10 and AMC 12 in later years.

Description: The AMC 8 is a 25-question, 40-minute competition designed for students in grade 8 and below. The competition focuses on middle school mathematics topics, including counting and probability, estimation, proportional reasoning, elementary geometry (including the Pythagorean Theorem), spatial visualization, and interpreting graphs and tables. Some of the later questions may touch on beginning algebra topics, such as linear or quadratic functions and coordinate geometry.

For: Middle school students in grades 8 and below, with a maximum age of under 15.5 years on the day of the competition.

When: Annually in January over the course of a week. Students may only take the AMC 8 once each year.
enhanced_description: The AMC 8 is a mathematical competition designed for students in grade 8 and below who are under 15.5 years of age, serving as an introduction to problem-solving beyond the standard school curriculum. This 25-question, 40-minute assessment allows participants to compete once annually and acts as a foundation for those interested in pursuing the AMC 10 and AMC 12 in later years. The competition covers a broad range of middle school mathematics, including counting and probability, estimation, proportional reasoning, elementary geometry, spatial visualization, and the interpretation of graphs and tables. More challenging questions may also incorporate beginning algebra topics such as linear or quadratic functions and coordinate geometry.

title: Georgia Tech
subtitle: IPAT Research Program
raw_text: The IPAT Research Program offers undergraduate students the opportunity to engage in research projects related to the intersection of technology and society. Participants will work closely with faculty mentors and gain valuable research experience while contributing to innovative projects that address real-world challenges.

title: UCSF
subtitle: BAY Area Youth Science (BAYS)
raw_text: BAYS is a summer science program for high school students interested in exploring the field of biomedical science. Participants engage in hands-on research projects and learn from leading scientists. The program aims to inspire future careers in science and medicine through immersive experiences and mentorship.

title: Global Youth Program - Moneyball: Training Camp
subtitle: University of Pennsylvania Wharton
raw_text:
Wharton Moneyball Training Camp is a one-week, online program broadly introducing students to statistics through a sports lens. Hosted by the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and the Wharton Sports Analytics and Business Initiative (WSABI), the Wharton Moneyball Training Camp welcomes talented students intrigued by statistics. Students applying to this program should have strong math skills and an interest in sports. 

The summer experience serves as an entrée into the sports statistics world as it is not heavily focused on computing but rather the fundamental principles of sports statistics. By the end of the program, students will better understand sports analyses in articles they may read, and will create their own sports analysis project, which may be featured in the Wharton Sports Analytics Journal. Wharton Professor Adi Wyner and guest faculty in conjunction with PhD students teach the program. 

Key themes and topics: 

Fundamentals of Statistics: data wisdom, histograms, box plots, quantiles, contingency tables, confounding factors, and the Empirical Rule. 
Regression and Relationships: scatter plots, correlation, regression lines, and avoiding the regression fallacy. 
Probability and Decision-Making: probability basics using examples from sports and betting. 
Students finish with hands-on experience using statistics and R programming to analyze sports data and communicate results effectively. 

Following the completion of the Moneyball Academy: Training Camp, many students go on to attend a future session of the three-week Moneyball Academy for a deeper dive into sports analytics.
enhanced_description: The Wharton Moneyball Training Camp is a one-week online program hosted by the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and the Wharton Sports Analytics and Business Initiative (WSABI) that introduces students to statistics through a sports lens. Designed for talented students with strong math skills and a passion for sports, the curriculum focuses on fundamental principles such as data wisdom, regression, and probability basics while providing hands-on experience with R programming to analyze sports data. Led by Professor Adi Wyner alongside guest faculty and PhD students, the program culminates in a sports analysis project that may be featured in the Wharton Sports Analytics Journal, often serving as a foundational experience for those planning to attend the more intensive three-week Moneyball Academy.

title: CAMINOS: Your Journey to College
subtitle: NCSU
raw_text: CAMINOS: Your Journey to College is a pre-college program for rising high school juniors and seniors that focuses on three key components: exposure to the college academic environment, preparation for the college application and financial aid process and establishment of a strong sense of community through peer engagement and near-peer mentorship. Participating in one of our pre-college programs is a year-long commitment. Beginning with the week-long on-campus summer component, students will continue to engage with program staff, peers and campus partners through a series of on-campus and virtual events throughout the year. While the programming and cultural exploration is geared towards students who identify as Hispanic or Latino, all students are welcome to apply.

title: High School Camp
subtitle: UNL
raw_text: The college offers an exciting, interactive summer high school camp: the Career Explorations in Architecture, Interior Design and Landscape Architecture Workshop. This camp offers a unique experience to investigate issues surrounding design, learn more about the design professions and what it's like to be a college student.

title: Berkeley Math Tournament
subtitle: UC Berkeley
raw_text: The Berkeley Math Tournament is a high school math competition hosted by the University of California, Berkeley. Participants solve challenging math problems individually and in teams. The tournament aims to enhance mathematical problem-solving skills and promote collaboration. Winners receive recognition and awards for their achievements. The event supports the development of advanced mathematical abilities and teamwork.

Academic Immersion (AIM)
A 3-week program
Here’s your chance to do a deep dive into a subject that fascinates you. Picture this: three stimulating weeks on campus engaging in intensive study, with classmates who feel just as passionate about a single academic topic as you do. If you’re entering your junior or senior year of high school, we invite you to apply.

NOW ACCEPTING APPLICATIONS

2026 AIM courses
Introduction to Experimental Psychology
Two students working on a laptop in a classroom - Introduction to Experimental PsychologyAIM: Introduction to Experimental Psychology combines classroom work in the psychological sciences with the experience of conducting research. You will learn to design and carry out your own research experiments under the supervision of Boston University instructors.

Introduction to Medicine
AIM: Introduction to Medicine is a premedical program that combines classroom work in the sciences with experiential learning activities that include simulations, lab work, and explorations of different medical fields.

Creative Writing
AIM: Creative Writing gives you the opportunity to develop your writer’s voice in a supportive, inspiring environment. You will learn formal techniques in multiple genres from seasoned instructors and participate in workshops that build confidence and sharpen skills. You will hear published authors discuss their craft, engage in free-write exercises, and visit important cultural centers around Boston. This exciting course is offered in partnership with BU’s renowned Creative Writing Program.

Business
A student in a Business class at Boston Univiersity's Summer TermAIM: Business is offered in partnership with BU’s Questrom School of Business, a top 20 undergraduate business program. This course combines interactive lectures, case studies, and local field trips. You will work in teams to design and carry out your own New Product Development (NPD) Business Plan. At the end of the course, each team will present their work to their peers as well as selected BU Questrom School of Business faculty.

2026 AIM calendar
 

Session 1 Courses:
Experimental Psychology & Business
Residential	June 28 – July 17
Commuter	June 29 – July 17
Session 2 Courses:
Medicine, Business, & Creative Writing
Residential	July 19 – August 7
Commuter	July 20 – August 7
View the Full Calendar

The big picture
For three amazing weeks, you will reside make new friends, enjoy lots of planned social activities, and gain valuable, hands-on experience in the field of medicine, psychology, creative writing, or business. Academic Immersion is open to both commuter and residential students.

Explore Program Activities

Zero in
If you’re an engaged, motivated high school student who wants to focus intensively on a specific subject for three weeks, AIM is for you. All AIM courses combine classroom work and theoretical studies with practical applications and experiential activities including field trips, guest speakers, and group projects. In addition to experiencing college life, you’ll gain invaluable insight into potential career paths.

The AIM courses are open to residential and commuter students who are entering their junior and senior years of high school.

enhanced_description: Boston University’s Academic Immersion (AIM) is a three-week program designed for motivated high school students entering their junior or senior year who wish to engage in intensive study of a specific academic subject. Available to both residential and commuter students, the program combines traditional classroom work and theoretical studies with hands-on experiential activities such as lab work, simulations, field trips, and group projects. Participants can choose from four distinct tracks: Introduction to Experimental Psychology, which focuses on designing research experiments; Introduction to Medicine, a premedical program exploring various medical fields; Creative Writing, which offers genre-specific workshops and craft discussions with published authors; or Business, where students work in teams to develop and present a new product business plan. Beyond academic rigor, students participate in planned social activities and gain valuable insight into potential career paths while experiencing college life alongside peers who share their passions.

title: SHINE Poster Session
subtitle: USC
raw_text: The USC Viterbi SHINE program offers high school students a chance to explore STEM fields through hands-on activities and workshops. Participants engage in projects related to engineering, technology, and science, working with USC faculty and industry professionals. The program includes a poster session where students present their work and receive feedback. SHINE aims to spark interest in STEM careers and provide students with valuable experience in these fields. The program fosters creativity and technical skills in a supportive and educational environment.

title: Youth Employment Program
subtitle: NYC
raw_text: The Summer Youth Employment Program (SYEP) is the nation’s largest youth employment program, connecting NYC youth between the ages of 14 and 24 with career exploration opportunities and paid work experience each summer. Through SYEP, participants can explore different interests and career pathways, develop productive workplace habits, and engage in learning experiences that strengthen their social, civic, and leadership skills. By participating in structured project and work-based opportunities, NYC youth are better prepared for careers of the future

title: High School Internship
subtitle: CLA
raw_text: Looking to explore the world of business, professional services, or accounting and gain hands-on experience with real projects and clients? Discover your passions and pave the way for your future career with CLA’s high school internship program. Designed for students aged 16 to 18, this summer internship provides the opportunity to develop new skills, understand your strengths, and get paid for your hard work. Internship opportunities are available in select locations nationwide starting in June.

title: Network For Teaching Entrepreneurship
subtitle: Rutgers
raw_text: In an innovation economy, there are no traditional paths to success. To activate the entrepreneurial mindset in young people, NFTE’s Pathway begins with igniting the imagination and takes students through the journey of creating and refining an original business concept. Students are guided by NFTE’s expert entrepreneurial Teacher Corps, and supported by entrepreneurs and successful business professionals.

title: US Academic Decathlon
subtitle: USAD
raw_text: The United States Academic Decathlon (USAD) is a national academic competition that features a range of subjects, including mathematics, science, literature, and art. High school students compete in teams to demonstrate their knowledge across various academic disciplines. The competition aims to promote academic excellence and teamwork among students. It provides opportunities for students to showcase their talents and gain recognition in a competitive environment. USAD fosters intellectual growth and preparation for future academic pursuits.

title: McIntire Business Program
subtitle: UVA
raw_text: In just two weeks you’ll gain a new mindset you can use anywhere life takes you. Learn business fundamentals to elevate your problem-solving skills, to grow and strengthen your ideas, and even to launch your own startup. Working on a project of your choosing, you’ll gain important skills in strategy, marketing, accounting, and finance as you develop the broad mindset that will give you the power to accomplish important things on your own and with a team. Great for students preparing to apply to college, curious about the world of business, and interested in knowing what makes great companies thrive and energizes the best teams to accomplish big goals. The McIntire Business Institute will give you a new perspective to pursue pathways in business and beyond.

title: AIMI Summer Health AI Bootcamp
subtitle: Stanford University AIMI
raw_text:
Program Overview

Join us for an enriching and engaging educational experience focused on machine learning in healthcare. Designed for high school learners of all technical levels, this virtual bootcamp offers a curated curriculum that covers the fundamentals of machine learning in healthcare settings. The day-to-day schedule for this virtual 2-week program will consist of:

Online learning modules
Group discussions
Breakout activities with other students
Social activities
"Meet the Expert" sessions with guest speakers representing academia, industry, non-profit, government. etc.
Students who attend the entirety of the Bootcamp will receive a Certificate of Completion once the program is complete. 
Concurrently, we hold the Summer Research Internship program for high school students. Learn more about the Internship here.

We will be adhering to Stanford's policies for Protection of Minors.

Key Learning Topics

Why Machine Learning in Healthcare?
Concepts and Principles of Machine Learning in Healthcare
Evaluation and Metrics for Machine Learning in Healthcare
Strategies and Challenges in Machine Learning in Healthcare
Best Practices, Teams, and Launching your Machine Learning Journey
Foundation Models and Generative AI for Healthcare
enhanced_description: This educational bootcamp provides high school students of all technical levels with a comprehensive introduction to the fundamentals of machine learning within healthcare settings. The program features a curated curriculum delivered through online learning modules, group discussions, breakout activities, and "Meet the Expert" sessions with guest speakers representing academia, industry, government, and non-profit sectors. Participants will explore essential topics such as machine learning principles, evaluation metrics, implementation challenges, and the application of foundation models and generative AI in medical contexts. Students who attend the entirety of the program receive a certificate of completion, and the bootcamp operates in alignment with Stanford’s policies for the protection of minors while running alongside a separate summer research internship opportunity.

title: Business and Leadership Academy
subtitle: Georgetown University HOYA Summer High School Sessions
raw_text:
Georgetown's Business & Leadership Academy introduces you to the ins and outs of the business world. You'll spend your time engaged in a combination of classes, workshops, simulations, group discussions, and activities preparing you with practical skills and critical thinking abilities that will benefit you in your future academic and professional endeavors.

This program provides you with a framework to help you understand important business principles and explains how to go about recognizing business opportunities, challenges, problems, and solutions. Each class day will begin with a business briefing discussing domestic and global issues. To understand a business education framework, it is important to introduce you to business decision-making, investing, strategy, finance, management, marketing, international business, law, ethics, communications, writing a business plan, and, most importantly, leadership.

The Business & Leadership Academy gives you a broad overview of business fundamentals. The program should be of interest to high school students who want to pursue a business education at the undergraduate level.

As a student in the Business & Leadership Academy, you’ll spend your time engaged in a combination of class sessions, field trips, hands-on workshops, group discussions, and extracurricular activities. Throughout the program, you will have the opportunity to explore a number of subject areas, including:

Recognizing business opportunities, challenges, problems, and solutions
Decision-making and strategy
Investing and finance
Marketing
Business management
Ethics and law
AI for business
enhanced_description: Georgetown's Business & Leadership Academy is designed for high school students interested in pursuing undergraduate business education by providing a comprehensive overview of business fundamentals and leadership. Participants engage in a dynamic learning environment featuring a mix of classroom sessions, hands-on workshops, simulations, field trips, and daily business briefings on domestic and global issues. The curriculum covers a wide range of essential subject areas, including finance, marketing, management, ethics, law, and AI for business, while emphasizing practical skills like writing business plans and strategic decision-making. By exploring these diverse topics through group discussions and extracurricular activities, students develop the critical thinking abilities and professional framework necessary to recognize and solve complex business challenges.

title: UConn
subtitle: UConn Summer LEAD Program
raw_text: The UConn Summer LEAD Program is designed for high school students to explore college life and gain leadership skills through interactive workshops and activities. Participants will engage in hands-on learning experiences that promote personal growth and community engagement while experiencing the vibrant campus of UConn.

title: Advanced Bacteriophage Therapy – An Alternative to Antibiotics
subtitle: UMass
raw_text: Our competitive Research Intensives program places high-achieving high school students in professional working labs alongside distinguished faculty, graduate and undergraduate students. Advanced Bacteriophage Therapy – An Alternative to Antibiotics (Koo Lab). Antibiotics have been used successfully to treat bacterial infection in both humans and animals for many years. In livestock, antibiotics are used for growth promotion, feed efficiency and veterinary medicine. Unfortunately, extensive use of antibiotics has led to the proliferation of novel antimicrobial resistance mechanisms. Therefore, there is an urgent need to address this global issue with the use of alternative therapies that can eliminate the risks posed by antibiotic treatments at the primary production level.

title: Mayo Clinic
subtitle: Mayo Clinic S.P.A.R.K. Program
raw_text: The S.P.A.R.K. program offers high school students a unique opportunity to explore research in science and medicine through hands-on experiences mentorship and exposure to various scientific fields. Participants engage in interactive activities and gain insights into the research process at one of the leading medical institutions.

title: Pre-College
subtitle: UCSB
raw_text: UC Santa Barbara Summer Sessions offers two premier pre-college programs that provide students with unique opportunities to earn college credit while engaging in interdisciplinary research. Simultaneously, these programs are designed to shape each student's academic, professional, personal, and social development. Our programs challenge high school students by exposing them to the academic excellence of UC Santa Barbara while immersing them in the university’s environment.  The Research Mentorship Program (RMP) and the Summer Research Academies (SRA) allow participants to deep-dive into an interdisciplinary subject while discovering new knowledge through university-level research. These transformative summer experiences help students get ahead and hone skills that prepare them to excel in higher education.

title: Discover Accounting
subtitle: UNL
raw_text: Are you a rising or graduating high school senior who has an interest in building relationships and understanding the foundation of business? Take the first step toward finding your future career and apply for the free Discover Accounting high school program. No prior coursework in accounting or business necessary.

title: CCRI - Climate Change
subtitle: NASA
raw_text: The Hudson Estuary is comprised of key tidal marshes, which serve to provide many ecosystem services to the large population of this important coastal region, including NYC. These services include fish nurseries, coastal protection, water purification, paleoclimatic archives, and carbon sequestration repositories. We seek to understand the records of past droughts, cold intervals, floods, and vegetation shifts along with the past shifts in carbon storage. From this information, we can better understand our present snapshot of climate/carbon, and predict future accumulation rates as climate warms and sea level rises.

title: Summer Art Intensive
subtitle: NYU
raw_text: The NYU High School Summer Art Intensive creates a close-knit community of young artists who experience the NYU Art Department much like our matriculated art majors during the academic year. We admit 54 students to our highly competitive in-person program; the group is divided into three intimate cohorts who take all studio classes together. Students will work directly with practicing art professionals who bring a level of expertise in the field that only NYU can offer. We expect students to engage their courses rigorously to create ambitious works beyond a scope they may have previously explored at the high school level while learning about the New York world of contemporary art.

title: Carver Summer Research Internship
subtitle: Iowa State
raw_text: Students accepted into the program will spend eight weeks on Iowa State’s gorgeous campus. Scholars will conduct research alongside various faculty mentors spanning diverse research areas. In addition to research, mentors will investigate and experience several food systems, agricultural processes, and the area food industry. Mentors will challenge scholars to address their potential barriers to entry and shortcomings. Lastly, scholars can take advantage of several opportunities to participate in professional development workshops. Stipends, travel, housing, and meals will be provided. Further details of funding will be released upon acceptance into the program.

title: National High School Institute
subtitle: Northwestern
raw_text: Since 1931, the National High School Institute has brought outstanding students to Northwestern University’s Evanston campus for immersive educational experiences. Students are affectionately known as “Cherubs,” a name given to them in the 1930s by Northwestern Dean Ralph Dennis whose goal, “to bring together gifted young people and superior teachers in an atmosphere of affection, knowledge, and trust,” is still upheld today. The oldest and largest university-based program of its kind, NHSI offers studies in Theatre Arts, Film & Video, Debate, and Playwriting.

title: Research Intern
subtitle: Echinacea Project
raw_text: The Echinacea Project has conducted research experiments on tallgrass prairie plants and insects in the Kensington-Hoffman area since 1995. Prairie used to cover this landscape, but it is now restricted to small patches. We devote a lot of effort to Echinacea angustifolia, the species of purple coneflower native to Minnesota. But we also investigate other plants and insects, including native bees, to gauge the health of native prairies in their current fragmented habitat. Plants and insects in these small habitats face both ecological and genetic threats, and we conduct long-term cutting-edge research experiments to assess whether these populations will persist.

title: Camp Shule
subtitle: UMD
raw_text: Camp Shule combines fun, friendships, and adventure of camp with the excitement of intellectual inquiry and discovery. Camp Shule provides an opportunity for youth to explore academic, artistic, and athletic interests in a relaxed and creative environment. Camp Shule encourages a life-long, love-of-learning with a combination of the best aspects of traditional camps close friendships, activities, and adventure with an element of intellectual inquiry and exploration. Camp Shule is based on the fundamental belief that children are good-decision makers, and make choices about their daily schedules which builds self-confidence, independence and maturity.

title: Vanderbilt University
subtitle: Short-term Research Training Experiences
raw_text: This program offers paid research internships for undergraduate students interested in medical research. Interns will work closely with faculty mentors on various projects in a collaborative environment. The program aims to enhance students' research skills and provide valuable experience in the medical field.

title: SLE Summer Program
subtitle: West Point
raw_text: ed by current West Point cadets, Summer Leaders Experience (SLE) is a week-long immersion into the academic, military, and social life of a West Point cadet.  At SLE, you will explore West Point from all angles, including our high-tech educational facilities, team-building athletic activities, and realistic military training.    SLE gives you a taste of the character, determination, commitment to excellence, and leadership skills required to become a cadet at West Point. Applications for SLE Summer 2025 will open on February 1st 2025.  An SLE application doubles as the first step of a West Point application; however, please keep in mind that completing an SLE application is not an obligation to complete a West Point application or attend West Point.

title: Law Academy
subtitle: Georgetown University HOYA Summer High School Sessions
raw_text:
From nationally recognized attorneys and prosecutors to politicians and judges, many of the nation's lawmakers and legal experts received their education at Georgetown. As a student in the Law Academy, you will follow in the footsteps of these distinguished legal professionals and explore your passion for the law with expert faculty, enthusiastic mentors, and talented peers who share your interests.

Through lectures, guest speakers, and discussion sections, our program offers not only an introduction to jurisprudence but also a look at how laws are adjudicated and administered. You’ll examine the most controversial issues of our day and explore how America's legal institutions change as popular values, standards, and perspectives evolve. You will also learn from Georgetown University faculty and other legal experts and get a chance to sample the Georgetown undergraduate experience.

As a student in the Law Academy, you'll spend your day immersed in a blend of lectures, activities, and group discussions. Throughout the week, you'll have the opportunity to explore the following subject areas:

Punishment for minors vs. adults
Victim rights vs. prisoner rights
Arrests and sentencing
Constitutional law and interpretation
The jury system
Criminal justice debates
Careers in the law
Supreme Court cases and controversies
enhanced_description: The Georgetown Law Academy offers students an immersive introduction to the legal field through a curriculum led by university faculty, legal experts, and professional mentors. Participants engage in a daily schedule of lectures, guest speaker presentations, and group discussions that explore how laws are adjudicated and how legal institutions evolve alongside societal values. The program covers a diverse range of topics including constitutional law, the jury system, criminal justice debates, and Supreme Court controversies, while also examining specific issues like the rights of victims versus prisoners and the differences between adult and minor sentencing. By sampling the Georgetown undergraduate experience, students gain valuable insight into potential legal careers and the practical administration of jurisprudence alongside a cohort of talented peers.

title: Medical Youth Science Program
subtitle: Stanford SMYSP
raw_text: The Stanford Medical Youth Science Program is a five-week immersive enrichment program focused on science and medicine that is open to low-income, first-generation high school juniors who live in Northern California.

title: Pre-College
subtitle: CCA
raw_text: At CCA’s Pre-College Program, you’ll join a diverse group of creative thinkers and makers who share your passion for art and design. The program is open to all interested participants, those with little art and design experience and those with advanced skills. We offer on-campus housing as well as meal plans for residential and commuter students. Participants will have the opportunity to take studio-focused, college-level courses to help push beyond concepts to portfolio-ready pieces while earning 3 college credits

title: Georgia Institute of Technology
subtitle: Georgia Tech STEP Program
raw_text: The STEP program at Georgia Tech offers high school students the opportunity to engage in hands-on STEM activities and gain exposure to engineering and technology fields. Participants will work on team projects and develop skills that are essential for future academic and career success.

title: ASPIRE Scholars Program
subtitle: UNLV
raw_text: ASPIRE is a college pipeline collaboration between the Nevada Department of Education, NSHE, CCSD, and UNLV for current 7th -10th graders at selected Title I schools interested in STEM or health sciences and looking for support and opportunity for their high school and early college careers.

title: Stem-Rising
subtitle: Brown
raw_text: If your idea of summer fun is a deep-dive into the STEM fields, join other rising 9th and 10th grade students who are as passionate about advancing their knowledge of the STEM disciplines as you are for two weeks of hands-on team research projects, experiments and design-build challenges. You’ll choose from a range of interesting and engaging courses in the STEM disciplines. Each course combines rigorous academic content, laboratory or field exercises and a research project or design challenge that serves as a focus for academic work. You may also have the opportunity to engage with Brown graduate students and learn about graduate-level research projects. To complete the STEM experience, you’ll give a final presentation that showcases your project for your peers, families and instructors. You will experience the satisfaction of advanced academics and indulge your love of learning, without the pressure of formal grades.

title: TAMU
subtitle: High School Research Academy
raw_text: The High School Research Academy at Texas A&M University offers students a unique opportunity to engage in research projects under the guidance of faculty mentors. Participants will gain hands-on experience in various STEM fields and enhance their understanding of scientific inquiry and methodologies.

title: UNM Health
subtitle: CURE Program
raw_text: The CURE Program offers high school students the opportunity to explore careers in cancer research and health care. Participants engage in hands-on research projects and gain valuable experience while working alongside professionals in the field. The program aims to inspire future generations of scientists and health care providers.

title: Bowdoin College
subtitle: Bowdoin International Music Festival
raw_text: The Bowdoin International Music Festival offers an immersive experience for musicians of all levels to study with renowned faculty. Participants engage in masterclasses performances and chamber music while developing their skills in a supportive environment. The festival fosters artistic growth and collaboration among students from diverse backgrounds.

title: Summer Academy for Math & Science
subtitle: Oregon State
raw_text: The OSU-Cascades Summer Academy offers academic and recreational programs designed for pre-college students. These programs aim to provide a blend of educational enrichment and fun activities, fostering both intellectual and personal growth. The academy typically includes a variety of courses and workshops across different subjects, along with outdoor and social activities to create a well-rounded experience for participants.

subtitle: UVA

Engage in classes that are small, intensive, and taught by leading UVA faculty.
Access the support services and facilities available to resident UVA students, including libraries, sports facilities, dining halls, the Student Health Center, and more.
Prepare for success in higher education.
Develop friendships with students from around the commonwealth, country, and world.
